completion:
I am thrilled to introduce the very first State of Youth Report. This report is the result of input from nearly 1,000 young people from all walks of life across Canada. It celebrates the valuable contributions of young people and recognizes their potential to shape a brighter future for everyone. 

The youth in Canada are actively involved, resourceful, and resilient. They are not just the leaders of tomorrow, but also the leaders of today. They understand the key challenges our country faces and have innovative ideas and solutions to address them. 

The report focuses on their top priorities, which include truth and reconciliation with Indigenous peoples, environmental and climate action, health and wellness, leadership and impact, employment, as well as innovation, skills, and learning. It outlines their perspectives on these issues and presents their vision for a better Canada that benefits all.

The past year has been tough for everyone due to the global pandemic, and young people in Canada have been particularly affected. They have made significant sacrifices to protect their loved ones. As we rebuild and recover from this crisis, it is crucial that we prioritize the needs of our youth. That's why the Canadian government has invested in supporting vulnerable youth, including those facing employment barriers. We are also making it easier for young people to pursue education, reduce student debt, and find training and work opportunities.

The future of Canada lies in the hands of our youth. When we invest in them, we are investing in the success and long-term prosperity of our country. I want to express my gratitude to the hundreds of young people who contributed to this report, as well as everyone involved in its creation. As the former Minister of Youth, I am committed to advancing this important work through my youth council and the continued implementation of Canada's first-ever youth policy.

The government will continue to listen to the voices of young people, work alongside them, and take action to empower them to drive change in their communities and achieve their dreams. This State of Youth Report is unique in many ways and serves as a reminder that young people throughout the country are brimming with fresh and innovative ideas to tackle even the most complex issues in our country.

The recommendations in this report were shaped through engagement sessions with around 1,000 young people, including those from First Nations, Métis, Inuit, Black, racialized, and LGBTQ2 communities. Many of these young people face barriers to meaningful participation in society. In my role as the Minister of Diversity and Inclusion and Youth, I have had the privilege of meeting many of these inspiring youth and witnessing their dedication to building a better Canada. Just like Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, I believe in the power of youth, which is why it was so important to create this report "for youth, with youth, and by youth."

While this may be the first report of its kind, it is part of our government's ongoing commitment to creating a brighter future for young people in Canada. It is essential to remember that youth in Canada come from diverse backgrounds and face unique circumstances based on where they live, their life stage, and their background. These intersectional identities contribute to the rich diversity of our country but can sometimes hinder young people from reaching their full potential.

With this important context in mind, I invite you to read this report, reflect on the recommendations, and gain a deeper understanding of the lives of young people in our country, including the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. I truly believe that by listening to and hearing from our young leaders, we can build a better future for all Canadians. END

When Ewan Reid talks about his software going to the moon next year, it's hard to believe that he almost became a banker. However, an exciting opportunity at an aerospace company and landing a job as a shuttle flight controller at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida in 2008 changed his path and led him to the aerospace industry. Reid is now the founder and CEO of Mission Control, a space exploration and robotics company based in Ottawa that was established in 2015. From its humble beginnings to producing software that will be used on the moon, the company has achieved great success and will reach a significant milestone next year.

Mission Control has partnered with the Mohammed bin Rashid Space Centre in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, to assist a small rover in navigating the moon's terrain. The company's cutting-edge artificial intelligence software operates robots remotely through the internet. On Earth, the software will send real-time data to scientists at four Canadian universities who will collaborate with the Dubai Space Centre team to determine the rover's path. This partnership with the Mohammed bin Rashid Space Centre gives Mission Control the opportunity to demonstrate their technology in space for the first time.

"I'm really proud of our team and honored to represent Canada on the Emirates' lunar mission," said Reid. "This is the first Canadian software, the first Canadian computer, and the first Canadian artificial intelligence to go to the moon."

Mission Control is fully prepared for their first venture into space, which could open up numerous opportunities for the company. They have been practicing using their software with a small "space" setup in their office—an impressive 4,000-square-foot room designed to resemble the moon's surface—where they drive rovers. Dubbed the "Moonyard" by the company, this testing facility is equipped with sand, rocks, craters, black walls, and simulated sunlight, allowing Mission Control and its partners to practice before embarking on real moon explorations.

In 2021, Mission Control proudly shared their world-class facility and software in Dubai. Reid and several colleagues attended Expo 2020 Dubai and the International Astronautical Congress to showcase their work to a global audience.

"It's crucial in the space industry to collaborate with international space organizations. Almost no space missions can be accomplished by a single country," explained Reid. "Participating in events like Expo is essential for us to establish relationships, partnerships, and successfully execute exciting and important space missions."

Mission Control has received support from Canada's Trade Commissioner Service (TCS) to explore markets in Israel, Italy, Japan, Mexico, and the United Arab Emirates. During a trade mission to the United Arab Emirates in 2019, Reid met with officials from the Mohammed bin Rashid Space Centre for the first time. Additionally, the TCS introduced Reid to iSpace, a lunar exploration company in Japan that plays a crucial role in the Mohammed bin Rashid Space Centre mission. An iSpace lander will transport the space centre's rover and Mission Control's software to the moon. The TCS has ensured that Mission Control had a smooth entry into international markets, enabling them to form new partnerships and reach new heights. END

completion:
On August 1, 2023, we will be commemorating the 50th anniversary of the opening of the Lester B. Pearson Building. This building holds great significance as a symbol of Canada's involvement on the international stage. Located at 125 Sussex Drive in Ottawa, it serves as the headquarters of Global Affairs Canada and is home to approximately 3,300 employees. 

Let us take a moment to celebrate the rich history and enduring legacy of this remarkable building! The Lester B. Pearson Building is situated on the traditional and unceded territory of the Algonquin Anishinaabeg people. It holds a prominent position on Sussex Drive, which is part of the ceremonial route from Parliament Hill to Rideau Hall, the Governor General's residence. 

With its four office towers, this building has become an integral part of Canada's architectural and governmental heritage. Designed by the firm Webb Zerafa Menkès Housden and constructed between 1970 and 1973, it was named in honor of Lester B. Pearson, an esteemed Prime Minister, diplomat, and Nobel Peace Prize winner. Pearson's visionary leadership played a crucial role in historic contributions to peacekeeping, including the establishment of the United Nations Emergency Force. 

"It is fitting that Canada's first physical representation of its relations with the world be named after Mr. Pearson," stated a government spokesman to the New York Times in 1973. The architectural brilliance of the building showcases the late modern movement and incorporates elements of brutalism. The design aimed to evoke a sense of tranquility, dignity, precision, and restraint. This vision is reflected in the strong horizontal lines, organic form, and use of dark materials. 

The Lester B. Pearson Building stands as a landmark and leaves a lasting impression on all who visit the bustling neighborhood. Over the past five decades, it has served as the epicenter of the department now known as Global Affairs Canada. Its halls have witnessed historic events, state visits, and significant diplomatic engagements. The building was officially opened on August 1, 1973, by Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II, who expressed her joy at the ceremony taking place on the eve of her first Commonwealth Heads of Government meeting. This timing underscored the significance of the moment for the Commonwealth nations. 

The dedicated foreign service officers and diplomatic leaders who work within the building have played a pivotal role in promoting and safeguarding Canada's interests on the global stage. Throughout the past 50 years, the Lester B. Pearson Building has housed public servants who have championed causes such as human rights, gender equality, and peacekeeping worldwide. The department has advanced Canada's foreign policy objectives, showcased the nation's values, and provided a strong voice in international forums. 

As the world evolves, so does this esteemed federal heritage building. In 2017, a large-scale rehabilitation project was announced to enhance its environmental performance. Upgrades to plumbing and electrical systems are being made, with a goal of achieving Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design Gold certification. Furthermore, the interior spaces are being transformed to align with the new government of Canada standard for offices, which emphasizes collaboration and flexibility and was announced in 2022. 

As we celebrate the Lester B. Pearson Building's 50th anniversary, let us pay tribute to its remarkable heritage. This iconic structure remains a steadfast embodiment of Canada's commitment to diplomacy, collaboration, and global engagement. Let us draw inspiration from the values and principles it represents as we move forward, working to foster peace, prosperity, and cooperation on the world stage. END

Canada was at the forefront when it implemented its feminist international assistance policy in 2017. But what does it mean to have a feminist approach to international assistance? It certainly doesn't mean leaving men and boys behind to prioritize women. In fact, the feminist international assistance policy (FIAP) addresses the root causes of poverty through an intersectional, human rights-based, and feminist lens. This means that it recognizes and takes into account the various and overlapping forms of discrimination that different groups and individuals face when in extreme poverty, vulnerability, and marginalization.

The FIAP aims to level the playing field by tackling the barriers that hinder equality. This is crucial because we cannot eradicate poverty without considering the needs of all people. Approximately 55% of the global population faces poverty and instability. Women and girls are disproportionately affected by entrenched gender inequalities, both in Canada and around the world. This disparity is particularly evident for women and marginalized groups pushed to the outskirts of society. To create a more peaceful and prosperous world for everyone, it is essential to address these inequalities so that individuals, regardless of their gender identity or expression, sex characteristics, or other identity factors, can fully enjoy their human rights.

The ultimate goal of the feminist policy is to reduce poverty worldwide. Interventions that promote gender equality have been proven to make significant progress toward this goal. A United Nations study found that closing the gender gap in farming and agrifood systems would boost global gross domestic product by almost a trillion US dollars and reduce the number of food-insecure people by 45 million. This is just one statistic that highlights the current inequality.

To support this cause, Canada funds projects like SeedChange. Through SeedChange, women comprise 50% of leadership positions in collective enterprises such as farming co-ops, and participation in traditionally male-dominated areas is increased. SeedChange focuses on regions such as the Central American Dry Corridor, Burkina Faso, Mali, and Ethiopia, where it has helped enhance seed, food, and economic security for 26,046 small-scale farm households. As a result of the project, these households have been able to grow more fruits, vegetables, and diverse crops, providing more food for families living in poverty. Data collected over five years has shown that the project has led to healthier diets, improved livelihoods, enhanced climate resilience, and greater autonomy within the communities. More than 100 women's groups and nearly 40 youth-run co-ops have shattered barriers to enter the marketplace.

In Gaza, where traditional gender roles dominate and female-headed households are more likely to live in poverty and face inequality, the Canada-funded Salalem Leadership Institute has made a difference. Sarah, a single parent of two, joined an 8-week entrepreneurship training program and received support for her agricultural startup through this program. Sarah's passion for farming was nurtured from a young age, and with the help of her mother and brothers, she successfully started her dream business, providing a secure future for her children. Salalem provided mentorship support to Sarah, enabling her to improve her farming practices and expand her business. Sarah has now harvested crops for six consecutive farming seasons and, after a year of successful business operations, she was able to rent a larger piece of land to diversify and increase her farming production. She also ventured into animal breeding and production, purchasing goats to establish this new line of business.

Through initiatives like SeedChange and the Salalem Leadership Institute, Canada is actively working towards reducing poverty and empowering individuals, regardless of their gender, to achieve their dreams and build a better future. END

The commercial building you choose will have a significant impact on your business. Ideally, it should enhance your operations in terms of size, layout, location, and appearance, while still adhering to zoning and environmental regulations. Commercial buildings come in various shapes, locations, and prices, so it's important to understand your needs and budget. If you've already worked on a business plan, you probably have an idea of the amount you can allocate for rent, mortgage, utilities, and taxes. Conducting a cash-flow analysis will help determine if purchasing a commercial property is feasible or if renting is a more viable option. Renting may allow you to retain more working capital for your business operations. However, it's important to consider potential rent increases. On the other hand, owning your property provides stability with fixed monthly mortgage payments and the advantage of building equity. When deciding to buy or lease your commercial space, make sure to carefully evaluate your options. In the meantime, here are five tips to guide your search for the right location for your business:

1. Tailor your selection to your business needs: For retailers, factors such as ample parking, pedestrian traffic, and attractive decor are important. Being situated near popular stores can attract walk-by customers. If you sell high-end clothing, it's best to avoid discount malls and opt for a location near other high-end retailers like shoe stores or jewelers. While location and decor may be less critical for small wholesale or manufacturing operations, it's essential to comply with zoning regulations. Additionally, consider the availability of qualified employees within a half-hour commute of your potential location.

2. Assess modification requirements: If you find a suitable building in a good location, consider what modifications may be necessary to make it ideal. The question then arises of who will bear the cost. If you're renting a space that requires modifications, negotiate with the owner and ensure a clear contract is in place, specifying the work, deadlines, and penalties for delayed completion. If you decide to purchase, hire an accredited inspection company to identify any defects or environmental contamination on the property. Defects can be points of negotiation, while some changes may require approval from local boards or authorities.

3. Take into account local taxes and infrastructure: Municipalities have varying tax rates, with some offering preferential rates to attract businesses. Your commercial real estate agent should be able to provide information on taxes, as well as the availability of infrastructure and utilities such as internet access, garbage pickup, roads, electricity, and natural gas at the potential locations you are considering. END

National parks are Canada's natural treasures. They are a testament to the incredible power of our environment, which has not only shaped our country's geography but also influenced our history and the experiences of those who live and visit here. These parks are established with the purpose of safeguarding and showcasing exceptional examples of natural landscapes and phenomena found in every unique region of Canada, as outlined in the national parks' system plan. When establishing new parks, we also consider factors such as ecological connectivity with other regions and whether the area is well-represented in the system plan.

Our national parks can be found in every province and territory, offering a diverse range of environments from mountains and forests to lakes and glaciers. They protect the habitats, wildlife, and ecosystem diversity that define these natural regions. Stretching across the coasts, interior mountains, plains, and great lakes, these parks come in various sizes, from the small Georgian Bay Islands National Park of Canada spanning 14 km² to the vast Wood Buffalo National Park of Canada, encompassing almost 45,000 km². Well-known names like Banff and Jasper coexist with more recently established parks such as Ivvavik and Vuntut.

Parks Canada is dedicated to both preserving the ecosystems within these magnificent areas and managing them to ensure visitors can appreciate and enjoy them without compromising their integrity. By immersing ourselves in the awe-inspiring scenery and natural surroundings of national parks, we can better connect with nature, develop a deep respect for it, and commit to its protection. Each national park serves as a sanctuary for the human spirit, telling the stories of how these lands came to be, with mountains rising, lakes forming, rivers flowing, forests growing, glaciers shifting, and grasslands evolving. They also offer glimpses of ongoing natural processes, from floods and fires to the migration of species. Through national parks, we have the opportunity to connect with nature, connect with people, and understand the events that have shaped the people of this land.

Visitors can embark on incredible experiences, such as paddling along rivers flowing through canyons carved over thousands of years, observing birds as they rest during their migratory journeys, and walking through vibrant forests rejuvenated by fire. These moments are truly unforgettable, and Parks Canada provides rich experiences to enhance them. Our priority is to protect the ecological integrity of our national parks by maintaining or restoring the health and balance of their ecosystems. We aim for a state where biodiversity, structures, and functions remain unimpaired and sustainable.

The national parks of Canada are a source of great pride for Canadians and an integral part of our identity. They celebrate the extraordinary beauty and boundless variety of our land. The national parks system plan serves as a guide for the protection of each unique natural region in Canada. It has shaped the expansion of our parks' system for many years. If you would like a PDF copy of the national park system plan (1997), please contact us at information@pc.gc.ca. END

completion:
Can you imagine the incredible journey monarch butterflies make across Lake Erie? It may seem impossible for us, but somehow these tiny creatures manage to do it. Not only do they travel across the Great Lakes, but they migrate across entire countries. However, this amazing journey is becoming increasingly difficult for them each year.

In the fall, monarch butterflies escape the cold by migrating from southern Canada all the way down to Mexico, where they spend the winter. Then, in the spring, a new generation of butterflies travels thousands of kilometers back from Mexico, crossing the United States, fields, mountains, and even the Great Lakes to return to Canada and start the cycle again.

Now, imagine if these butterflies arrived in Canada only to find asphalt and mowed grass everywhere. They would have no food and nowhere to rest and recover. That's why Parks Canada is working hard to ensure this doesn't happen, and they need your help!

Thankfully, when many monarchs cross Lake Erie from the United States, they are met by Point Pelee National Park. This park, located at the southernmost point of mainland Canada, is the most ecologically diverse national park in the country. Here, the butterflies can find an abundance of food and shelter to rest after their long journey.

Some butterflies will then continue north and east throughout Ontario, finding summer homes in other Parks Canada administered places like Bruce Peninsula National Park, Rouge National Urban Park, and Georgian Bay Islands National Park. However, these are just stops along their migration. As they move beyond national parks, they face a fragmented landscape, with habitat lost and broken up by urban development, roads, and industrial agriculture.

To support these at-risk species, Parks Canada is restoring ecosystems to provide stepping stones of habitat. These stops help birds and butterflies move more freely and easily in their natural environment. By planting native trees, grasses, and wildflowers in protected areas, Parks Canada is creating food and habitat for migrating species to rest and refuel before continuing their journey.

In the last five years, Parks Canada, along with indigenous communities, partners, and volunteers, has restored over 40 hectares (98.8 acres) of meadow, coastal sand dune, and savannah habitat in Ontario's national parks. These habitats are crucial for pollinators. Together, we have also planted over 145,000 native shrubs and trees, as well as almost 18,000 native grasses and wildflowers.

Parks Canada's work to conserve and restore healthy ecosystems that provide important habitat is just one piece of a larger puzzle. You can be part of the solution to habitat loss by providing your own habitat "stepping stones" too! Just imagine if, after leaving a national park, a monarch butterfly found your yard, garden box, or balcony filled with native plants. There, it could stop, rest, and refuel before continuing its journey to another protected area.

You don't need a big yard to make a difference. Even planting a small garden or a few native plants on your balcony is important, especially in urban areas. If you don't have space at home, you can join a community garden in your neighborhood. To help pollinators, we recommend planting a variety of native plants and wildflowers. Milkweed is especially beneficial for monarchs, as it is the only plant their caterpillars eat.

You can find ecoregional planting guides and a native plant finder tool on Pollinator Partnership Canada's website. Additionally, the Canadian Wildlife Federation's Canadian Native Plant Suppliers list can help you find local businesses to purchase your plants and seeds. Together, we can make the journey easier for these beautiful butterflies and other pollinators by creating habitats that support them. END

completion:
Wetlands are unique and beautiful places that exist between land and water. Unfortunately, they are often overlooked and underappreciated. This is partly because they don't fit neatly into the category of either land or water. Dr. Chantal Vis, an expert in aquatic ecosystems, explains that studying wetlands is challenging because you can only do so much research from the safety of solid ground or a boat.

Another reason wetlands are underloved is that many people consider them to be wasted land. Throughout history, wetlands have been drained to make room for agriculture and development. Sadly, this trend continues today. In fact, Southern Ontario has lost up to 68 percent of its wetlands, while urban areas in the prairies have lost up to 96 percent.

Popular culture often portrays wetlands as dark and mysterious places, associated with snakes and monsters. However, this is far from the truth. Wetlands actually provide numerous benefits to both the environment and humans. They are like nature's kidneys, filtering out pollutants and purifying water. Wetland vegetation, such as cattails and bulrushes, can even remove toxic substances like heavy metals and fertilizers.

Additionally, wetlands play a crucial role in flood and erosion control. They absorb and slow down excess water, preventing flooding in nearby areas. During dry periods, they release the stored water to replenish the surroundings. Wetlands also have a significant impact on our global climate. They absorb carbon dioxide, a greenhouse gas that contributes to climate change. Bogs, in particular, contain peat, which further enhances their ability to store carbon.

Furthermore, wetlands are incredibly biodiverse and provide habitats for a third of all North American species at risk. They are like ecological supermarkets, supporting a wide range of plants and animals. In many parts of the world, wetlands also serve as a vital source of fuel and building materials.

Recognizing the importance of wetlands, organizations like the Rouge National Urban Park in Ontario are working diligently to restore and recreate these valuable habitats. By partnering with the Toronto and Region Conservation Authority, schools, community groups, and indigenous communities, they have successfully restored over 60 hectares of wetland, stream, and riverbank habitats since 2015. Their restoration efforts involve careful planning and mimicking the natural processes that would have existed in the past. By thinking like beavers, they create wetlands that can effectively filter agricultural runoff and reduce flooding on farmers' fields.

The work at the Rouge National Urban Park and other national parks highlights the vital role of wetlands as natural engineering systems that support the health of our living world. Dr. Chantal Vis emphasizes that wetlands deserve more recognition and appreciation for the crucial services they provide. Perhaps someone should write a song to spread the word about the importance of wetlands. END

completion: The european green crab, known as the marine cockroach or green menace, has been labeled one of the world's most unwanted species. However, this despised crustacean may hold the key to solving the global issue of plastic pollution. Parks Canada has joined forces with Dr. Audrey Moores, a chemistry professor at McGill University, to explore a method of creating biodegradable plastic from the shells of these crabs. It's a perfect collaboration that brings together a common enemy, the green crab, with the cause of "green chemistry." The journey began when Dr. Moores published a paper on using the material from insect and crustacean shells, called chitin, to produce biodegradable plastic. This caught the attention of Gabrielle Beaulieu, the coastal restoration project manager at Kejimkujik National Park and Historic Site in Nova Scotia. They approached Dr. Moores with the idea of turning their green crab problem into a solution. Dr. Moores was immediately intrigued and saw the potential. The partnership has already achieved success with a crowdfunding campaign through the Fathom Fund, a project of the Marine Environmental Observation Prediction and Response Network (MEOPAR). Parks Canada has pledged $20,000 to the project, which will be used to hire a full-time researcher near Kejimkujik. Kejimkujik National Park has been combating the green crab invasion since 2007 when they noticed the disappearance of eelgrass, which serves as a vital habitat for marine life. The loss of eelgrass had a ripple effect, impacting not only the marine species but also the birds that rely on them for food. The green crabs were responsible for ripping out the eelgrass to access their food sources. Kejimkujik implemented a trapping and removal program, including a citizen science initiative called "Gone Crabbin'," which allows park visitors to contribute to the control program. So far, they have successfully removed 2 million green crabs from the park's estuary locations. As a result, almost 40% of the original eelgrass beds have returned, and overall biodiversity has improved. Kejimkujik had already found success in creating a demand for the green crab as lobster bait and as an edible product. This new partnership will create a year-round demand for the crustacean, benefiting both coastal communities and ecosystems, and potentially improving the health of the ocean. Traditional plastic is a major problem for the world's oceans as it doesn't break down and can harm marine life. Approximately one-third of the world's plastic ends up in the ocean. Biodegradable plastic is already being made from chitin, but on a small scale and with potentially harmful methods. Dr. Moores' approach, using green chemistry, aims to produce the plastic cleanly and on a larger scale. Therefore, the despised european green crab may actually contribute to the health of our oceans. It's always satisfying to see a villain become a hero, or at least provide ingredients for the heroes' work. END

Additionally, social assistance recipients, who constitute approximately 5% of Canada's population (or 1 in 20 people), were legally obligated to apply for CERB and faced penalties if they failed to do so. The benefits received from these pandemic programs were largely deducted from other benefits they were entitled to. As a result of the aftermath, the rules pertaining to pandemic benefits were significantly tightened.

First, the $5,000 income threshold was restricted only to the incomes specified in the legislation, which was more restrictive than what was conveyed on websites. For example, honorariums were initially mentioned as qualifying income online but were not covered in the CERB legislation. 

Second, the requirement for the $5,000 income was not just earning it but actually receiving it. Many individuals worked during the pandemic but experienced delays or failures in receiving their pay due to business distress. However, these individuals are retroactively deemed ineligible for CERB. This rule seems unfair, as the Canada Revenue Agency (CRA) often refuses to accept explanations for difficulties in obtaining documentation of earnings unless it is brought to tax court.

Third, CERB claimants were retrospectively expected to provide detailed bookkeeping to prove their eligibility, almost to the level of forensic accounting. If individuals were unable to provide such accounts, they were often disqualified.

Fourth, there were no exceptions or room for judges to determine eligibility for claimants who narrowly missed meeting the requirements. Most programs have some form of exceptionality, but it is entirely absent when it comes to pandemic benefits.

Fifth, the hardship rules that would typically apply to extend payment terms are being significantly restricted.

Lastly, over $50 million in new funds were allocated in the federal budget to investigate low-income individuals who were found ineligible for benefits, despite the discrepancies in communication and administration. 

Unfortunately, all of these factors combined are causing significant harm and overshadowing the fact that Canada achieved its poverty reduction goals nine years ahead of schedule. Instead of celebrating this remarkable achievement, some perceive it as a failed experiment in protecting our most vulnerable residents, which is far from the truth. END

Working in open government means understanding the importance of listening to citizens and stakeholders. When it comes to citizen engagement in Canada, we have consistently heard that it must be genuine and valuable. To help us achieve this goal, we have created a set of principles and guidelines to ensure that our engagement on policy issues is transparent, relevant, inclusive, accountable, and adaptable.

Our journey towards these principles began in 2013 when we conducted a large engagement process to support the development of Canada's second action plan on open government. Through conversations with Canadians, we learned about their concerns regarding meaningful engagement, and we turned that feedback into a commitment to develop principles and standards for public consultations, in collaboration with citizens and civil society.

To fulfill this commitment, we researched practices from across the globe and engaged with various communities. We held workshops with the federal government's regulatory community, who are required to consult on proposed revisions or changes. We also discussed the issue with the academic community at the congress of humanities and social sciences in June 2015.

The next step was the Canadian Open Dialogue Forum, where we collaborated with over 200 participants from civil society, government, academia, and business during a two-day conference in March 2016. Through extensive discussions and idea-sharing, we developed a draft list of 16 principles. We continued to consult, refine, and edit the principles to ensure that both the government and our community were satisfied with a document that truly embraced openness.

Throughout this process, we made some mistakes and needed to make adjustments, even after thorough discussions. For instance, at GovMaker in 2016, we suggested that "participants should know what's on and off the table" to enhance relevance. However, the room agreed that if the process is genuinely "open," nothing should be entirely off-limits. We also received feedback that the principles seemed to place decision-making solely in the hands of the government of Canada, rather than promoting co-creation and shared accountability. We have since incorporated these suggestions into the principles.

The outcome of our efforts is a set of principles for engagement between the government and citizens. We are currently experimenting with applying these principles to public consultations and working on providing more detailed guidance on their implementation. Additionally, we are exploring how to measure the effectiveness of different types of public engagement activities conducted by the government of Canada.

One area of great importance is our ongoing work towards building effective relationships and engagement with Indigenous peoples and nations. Stay tuned for a future blog post on measuring the effectiveness of the principles and examining the relationship between engagement and trust in government.

Thank you for your support, and we are excited to continue learning and growing together.

Thom Kearney and the Open Government Team END

As the minister responsible for open government, I want to personally invite you to join in celebrating Open Government Week with citizens and governments from all over the world. This is an exciting opportunity for you to learn about open government, connect with others who are passionate about civic life, and find ways to strengthen our communities and democracy.

Open Government Week is part of a global movement led by the International Open Government Partnership (OGP). We are honored that Canada has been chosen as the lead government chair for the OGP for 2018-2019. Our goal is to raise the standards and collaborate with our international partners to use open government to improve the lives of people everywhere.

We firmly believe that increased citizen participation and oversight of government operations will lead to better programs and services for all. By being persistent, we can deepen civic engagement, build trust, and ultimately strengthen our democracy. That's why Canada is making a deep investment in open government.

Take a look at our portal, where you'll find tens of thousands of data sets that showcase our work. You can also explore our open government tracker to see the progress happening across our government. Additionally, we are committed to supporting other countries in their own open government journeys because we believe that investing in the success of modern democracies worldwide is vital.

We have outlined our priorities for our term as co-chair of the OGP: participation, impact, and inclusion. These priorities will guide our efforts to enhance civic space globally and strengthen our own democracy in Canada, setting an example for others to follow. We also recognize that government belongs to the people it serves, so we will work with governments to make public engagement and civic participation key components of policy development.

Transparency is essential to our mission, which is why we will publish our targets, measure our impact, and openly share our accomplishments and challenges. This way, we can learn and grow together. We are also committed to ensuring that under-represented citizens, regardless of gender, race, or sexual orientation, have an active role in policymaking. We want to support women and girls in gaining meaningful access to decisions that directly impact their lives for the better.

Inclusivity is crucial because when faced with complex problems, we need a diversity of perspectives, experiences, and ideas to find the best solutions. Open Government Week is an opportunity to showcase the various ways to create space for dialogue and improve Canada as a whole. When we say open government, we mean open to everyone. We hope you'll join us in making this change by sharing your ideas, collaborating on our next action plan, and holding us accountable for our progress. You can do all of this by visiting open.canada.ca.

Canada has a strong track record of leading global open government initiatives, thanks to the input and involvement of Canadians like you. During Open Government Week, I invite you to explore, participate, and engage with other Canadians and individuals around the world. Join events and take part in the #opengovweek conversations that interest you. Together, we can build a better Canada and a better world. Thank you for your contribution to this important cause. END

In my first blog post, I want to share my thoughts on the important work of our organization and explain our role, goals, and day-to-day tasks. Our work goes beyond tracking commitments and reporting outcomes, although I will go into more detail about that in my next post.

Firstly, we focus on preparing materials for the Prime Minister and the Cabinet Committee on Agenda, Results, and Communications. These materials, like dashboards, heat maps, and progress reports, highlight progress on key priorities and identify areas that may require attention. For example, our reports have shown progress in gender-based budgeting and analysis, as well as improving the recruitment of underrepresented groups in Canada's uniformed and security agencies. We also identify areas where more progress is needed. Having meetings with the Prime Minister and key leaders with data has been a valuable way to accelerate progress. As a result, there is now greater clarity that the Prime Minister expects targets to be met and rigorous gender-based analysis and budgeting on all new proposals. This means that proposals will be thoroughly assessed for their impact on different groups, such as women or racialized communities. We will soon be sharing these reports publicly to showcase the results we achieve for the Prime Minister.

Secondly, we assist departments in preparing new policy and program submissions by asking three simple questions: What are you hoping to achieve? How will you achieve it? How will you evaluate and adjust if needed? We offer advice on their submissions to the Cabinet and sometimes delve deeper into their programs. Recently, we have worked with departments on various issues, including reducing homelessness, expanding broadband coverage, addressing the opioid crisis, improving job training programs, and reducing the carbon footprint of the federal government.

Thirdly, we collaborate closely with departments on a day-to-day basis to help ministers overcome obstacles and ensure successful delivery of their initiatives within the system. Instead of allowing problems to persist, we address them promptly, guide them to the appropriate decision-making forums, and strive to expedite progress. In some cases, we conduct thorough investigations into high-priority issues that are not progressing as expected. This involves examining the entire delivery chain, including partners and policies, such as procurement and contracting rules, as well as identifying any barriers to success. An example of this is the long-standing boil water advisories on reserves. To resolve this complex issue, a joint team consisting of representatives from departments, the Prime Minister's Office, and communities is mapping out the delivery chain and identifying challenges.

These three functions were not previously performed systematically across the federal government. Although they were addressed in specific situations, they were not consistently practiced. All of our efforts are aimed at shifting the culture of the federal government towards a greater focus on implementation and outcomes. This means investing more in people who can successfully deliver programs and projects, as well as investing in data and evaluation to determine the results being achieved. So, "Results & Delivery" is not just the name of our unit - it represents our mission every day. I like to think of us as an autonym. In this blog, I will share our activities and discuss the challenges the public service faces as we work towards becoming a more outcomes-focused organization. In my next post, I will delve into our approach to public reporting and what lies ahead. END

I have had the privilege of teaching policy at various levels, from community workshops to organizations like ODSP and OW, foundations, governments, agencies, and volunteers. In many of these settings, I have also taught about benefit design. To make it easier, I created a guide on understanding benefit design and the ten principles of good benefit design.

Now, when it comes to the CERB and CRB programs, it's important to note that they do not adhere to four of these principles. However, I don't blame the designers for this. Designing such a large suite of programs without making mistakes and taking shortcuts is nearly impossible. That being said, Canada should still be commended for the magnitude, effective delivery, and speed at which the pandemic benefits were rolled out.

When speed is a top priority, it's understandable that principles of effective benefit delivery may not be at the forefront of decision-making. But as I mentioned before, two wrongs don't make a right. Mistakes made in the initial design can be rectified through appeals, just as the government has done for students, the self-employed, and low-income seniors. This is the crux of my objections in this series.

So, let's examine the violations that occurred when the CERB and CRB were quickly implemented. The first principle is aligning program objectives with design. The main objective of pandemic benefits was to ensure people's safety and keep them indoors during the early stages of the pandemic. Another objective was to assist those who lost their jobs and couldn't return to work. However, the CERB and CRB used the $5,000 threshold of 2019 earnings as a proxy to determine eligibility for pandemic benefits. This means that individuals who earned less than $5,000 but still suffered job loss were left out. Additionally, many had to continue working during the most dangerous part of the pandemic. The $5,000 threshold seemed arbitrary and did not align with our values.

This brings us to the second principle, aligning Canadian values with design parameters. Nowhere in the Canadian value system can we find a stipulation that pandemic benefits should only be given to those who earned over $5,000. Canadians believe in helping individuals who have lost their jobs, as evident through programs like EI and welfare. The $5,000 threshold seemed to come out of nowhere and did not align with our values.

Moving on to the third principle, understanding benefit structure. The CERB and CRB were innovative, but it's difficult to determine if they reached the intended recipients. The rules kept changing, such as what counted as income, who was eligible, when the benefits were paid, and how they were paid. It's hard to say if the CERB and CRB violated the principle of understanding benefit structure because there was simply not enough time to thoroughly study it.

Lastly, the fourth principle is perhaps the most important - understanding the four elements of an income test. In the case of the CERB and CRB, there is no recovery or tax back rate on income. It's a binary system where you are either eligible or ineligible. Missing the threshold by even one cent makes you ineligible, while adding a cent makes you eligible. This lack of an on and off ramp, which is present in other income-tested benefits like GIS, CCB, CWB, and all income assistance programs, goes against a fundamental principle of design, even when designing under time constraints.

In conclusion, while there were some shortcomings in the design of the CERB and CRB programs, it's important to recognize the challenges faced in creating such programs during a crisis. We can learn from these experiences and use them to improve future benefit design efforts. END

Investing in public transit is a smart way to invest in Canadians. By creating projects that connect people to their destinations, we help commuters save valuable time and money. Additionally, these initiatives generate good jobs for the middle class and contribute to a cleaner environment for future generations.

Today, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, along with Quebec Premier François Legault, Montreal Mayor Valérie Plante, and Charles Emond, President and CEO of Caisse de dépôt et placement du Québec, gathered in Montreal for the launch of Phase 1 of the Réseau express métropolitain (REM), a significant public transit project that links multiple suburbs to downtown Montreal.

With the launch of Phase 1, five stations now provide public transit services from Brossard Station on the south shore to Central Station in downtown Montreal, crossing the iconic Samuel de Champlain Bridge over the St. Lawrence River. This project, the largest of its kind in Quebec in the past 50 years, is the result of extensive partnership, including a record investment from the Canada Infrastructure Bank.

Once fully completed, the REM will double the length of the existing metro system and connect the West Island (Sainte-Anne-de-Bellevue) and the North Shore (Laval and Deux-Montagnes) to downtown Montreal. It will also provide a rapid link to Montreal-Trudeau International Airport, reducing travel time from downtown to the airport to just 25 minutes, regardless of traffic. 

The REM, which operates as a fully electric metro, will significantly cut emissions by 100,000 tonnes per year – equivalent to removing 30,000 cars from our roads on a daily basis. It is expected to boost the Greater Montreal area's economy, creating 34,000 jobs during construction and 1,000 permanent jobs. Additionally, over $2 billion in wages will be paid in Quebec as a result of this project. The REM is projected to accommodate up to 170,000 users per day.

Projects like the REM are crucial to our efforts to combat climate change, create high-quality jobs, and improve our communities. Today's announcement means that Montrealers will experience faster commutes, spend less time in traffic, breathe cleaner air, and have more money in their pockets.

To summarize:
1. Phase 1 of the REM allows approximately 30,000 commuters per day to travel 16.6 kilometers in just 18 minutes.
2. Upon completion, the REM will add 26 stations and 67 kilometers of tracks, doubling the length of Montreal's current metro system.
3. The Canada Infrastructure Bank is investing a record-breaking $1.28 billion into the REM project and an additional $300 million for the construction of the REM terminus station at Montreal-Trudeau International Airport. The Government of Canada's Airport Critical Infrastructure Program is also investing an extra $100 million in the airport's REM station.
4. The total project cost for the REM is currently $6.9 billion, made possible through collaboration between the Government of Canada, CDPQ Infra, REM Inc., the Government of Quebec, Aéroports de Montréal, and Hydro-Québec.
5. Established in 2017, the Canada Infrastructure Bank seeks to invest in large-scale, transformative infrastructure projects that generate revenue and benefit the public, promote clean economic growth, and contribute to the sustainability of Canada's infrastructure.
6. Since 2015, the Government of Canada has invested over $22 billion in more than 1,800 public transit projects across the country. These investments will result in the construction of over 400 kilometers of new subway and light rail lines, the purchase of over 3,000 zero-emission buses, and the creation of almost 1,700 kilometers of active transportation trails, bike lanes, and recreational paths. END

The digital transformation office recently conducted a research project to better understand how people navigate the government of Canada's website. We collaborated with various departments, including Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship, Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada, Veterans Affairs Canada, and Statistics Canada, to explore how users interact with the global theme and topic menu on Canada.ca. Our goal was to address the concerns raised by some institutions regarding the menu's ability to meet their complex navigation needs, which was preventing them from adopting the Canada.ca design.

To find a solution, we went beyond the menu and examined overall navigation habits to ensure that institutions could effectively meet user needs. The wayfinding project included a baseline study to identify and assess findability issues, as well as a comparison study to test potential solutions. The insights gained from this research have informed changes to the Canada.ca design.

During our research and prototyping activities, we explored options to remove the menu while still maintaining or improving the effectiveness of global navigation. We wanted to preserve the trust and confidence that users have in the Canada.ca site brand. Our prototype included several design elements for testing:

1. A global header without a menu
2. Theme links from the menu moved to the footer
3. A sign-in button in the global header
4. More prominent breadcrumb links
5. A simplified theme page template

We applied the new design to pages that were already using the Canada.ca design, as well as pages that weren't. Task success remained consistent, and there was even an improvement in navigating between themes. Breadcrumbs were found to be more frequently used than the global menu for navigation, as they provide clear links to theme-level pages, leading users directly to their desired destination. Additionally, we discovered that people often use the menu to find a way to sign in to their accounts. To address this, we placed a contextual sign-in button at the top-right, just below the global header, where users typically expect to find it. This change proved successful in our testing.

By implementing these design changes, we were able to maintain or improve task success rates in the comparison round of testing. For more detailed information, please refer to our research summary.

We understand that these are significant changes to a website that people rely on daily. To minimize disruption, we are taking a transitional approach to implement these design improvements to our navigation. Some work has already been completed, and we are currently working on the remaining updates.

Here is our roll-out plan:

1. Updates to the Canada.ca homepage: After analyzing usage patterns, we found that certain footer links were frequently used on the homepage but rarely accessed elsewhere on the site. To make these links more visible and free up space in the footer, we have moved them into the content section of the Canada.ca homepage.

2. Contextual sign-in button: The global header now includes an optional contextual sign-in button. This button will be displayed on pages where users are likely looking to sign in to their accounts. We observed that many users accessed the sign-in page through the global menu. By presenting the sign-in button in the top-right of the content area, signing in becomes more obvious and easy to find. As users become accustomed to seeing and using the sign-in button consistently, they will rely less on the menu for accessing their accounts.

3. Footer updates: To further reduce dependency on the theme and topic menu, we have made adjustments to the global footer. The new global footer will consist of three content bands.

We hope that these changes will enhance the user experience and make navigating the government of Canada's website easier and more efficient. END

"Designing with users" is an important principle in the Government of Canada's digital standards. However, it can be challenging to prioritize user needs when faced with tight deadlines and financial constraints. Understanding who your users are and how your service impacts their lives is crucial for creating effective digital services. One valuable resource for gaining insights into user experiences is your call centre. Call centre agents have access to valuable feedback, including complaints, praises, and product insights from your diverse audience. Whether you have an in-house call centre or outsource to a trusted partner, involving agents can help you improve your web content and services with real people in mind.

Let me provide an example of how collaborating with call centre staff helped us quickly enhance our service on canada.ca. In March 2020, there was a surge in calls and emails related to employment insurance (EI) and the Canada Emergency Response Benefit (CERB). The high volume of inquiries overwhelmed the Government of Canada's main helpline and email managed by Service Canada, causing delays and frustration for concerned Canadians. To address this issue, Service Canada sought assistance from the Digital Transformation Office (DTO) to improve their phone and email contact pages. The goal was to encourage more self-service options on the website, building on our successful experience with the Canada Revenue Agency.

We used web analytics and call volumes in early April 2020 to measure the effectiveness of our interventions. At that time, call wait times exceeded several hours, and many people couldn't get through. Email response times were also delayed beyond the standard 48-hour window. The public health agency's call centre had to transfer hundreds of calls daily regarding CERB and EI topics alone.

To address these challenges, we focused on designing the contact page based on user behavior. The original page had a lengthy alert at the top about call wait times and included links to other pages. However, we suspected that people were not reading the long alert and were reluctant to leave the contact page because they had already made up their minds about needing assistance. We hypothesized that they didn't feel compelled to search for answers elsewhere since the helpline phone number was readily available.

To test our ideas, we created prototypes and conducted user testing. First, we tried a smaller alert banner at the top of the page, reducing the length and removing the distracting links. The new alert simply encouraged people to check the information on the page before contacting support. Second, we implemented an expand/collapse pattern, displaying answers to frequently asked questions at the top of the page. Users could expand only the answer they needed, eliminating the need to leave the page. This approach allowed us to keep the page concise while providing the most essential content.

The results of our testing were positive. People actively searched for answers on the page and found them. By optimizing the contact page based on user behavior, we were able to improve the user experience and reduce the burden on call centres. END

Dear School Boards,

We are pleased to inform you of the revised provincial code of conduct, which we would like to communicate to you through this memorandum. The purpose of this revision is to include a new restriction on the use of personal mobile devices during instructional time. However, we want to assure you that the use of personal mobile devices during instructional time is still permitted under certain circumstances.

Firstly, students may use their personal mobile devices for educational purposes as directed by an educator. Secondly, they may use them for health and medical purposes. Lastly, personal mobile devices may be used to support special education needs. It is important to note that school boards have a duty under the Ontario Human Rights Code to provide appropriate accommodations to all students and employees, including educators. If someone requires the use of a personal mobile device as an accommodation, school boards are obligated to allow it.

Furthermore, this memorandum provides guidance to school boards on reviewing their own codes of conduct as well as the local codes of conduct in their schools. It is essential that boards review their codes of conduct to ensure that they align with the revised provincial code of conduct. Additionally, we would like to draw your attention to subsection 301(2) of Part XIII of the Education Act, which outlines the purposes of the provincial code of conduct. According to subsection 301(3.1), if a board enters into an agreement with a third party regarding the rental of school space or the provision of before- and after-school programs, the agreement must include a requirement for the other party to follow standards consistent with the provincial code of conduct.

A positive school environment is one that promotes responsibility, respect, civility, and academic excellence within a safe learning and teaching environment. We believe that a positive school climate can be achieved when all members of the school community feel safe, included, and accepted, and actively promote positive behaviors and interactions. Building and maintaining a positive school climate is indeed a complex challenge, but one that can be met with evidence-informed solutions. A whole-school approach, involving all members of the school community, is crucial in supporting efforts to create safe, inclusive, and accepting schools. This approach is effective in making systemic changes that benefit all students and the broader community.

All students, parents, teachers, and other school staff have the right to be safe and feel safe within their school community. With this right comes the responsibility to contribute to a positive school climate. To foster such a climate that supports student achievement and well-being, we recommend that school boards focus on prevention and early intervention strategies to address inappropriate behavior. The provincial code of conduct sets clear standards of behavior that apply to students in various settings – whether they are on school property, in a virtual learning environment, on school buses, at school-related events or activities, in before- and after-school programs, or in any other circumstances that may affect the school climate. These standards also apply to all individuals involved in the publicly funded school system, including principals, teachers, early childhood educators, other school staff, parents, school bus drivers, volunteers, and members of various community groups.

Responsible citizenship entails appropriate participation in the civic life of the school community. Active and engaged citizens are not only aware of their rights, but they also accept the responsibility of protecting their rights and the rights of others.

In light of these requirements, we ask that all school boards ensure their codes of conduct are:

1. Up to date and consistent with the provincial code of conduct outlined in this memorandum.
2. Compliant with all Ministry of Education policies, as well as the requirements of the Education Act, its regulations, and all other applicable legislation, including the Ontario Human Rights Code.
3. Made available to the public, either on the school board's website or through another appropriate means, if the board does not have a website.

Thank you for your attention to this matter. We believe that by working together, we can create safe, inclusive, and accepting school communities that promote student success and well-being.

Sincerely,
[Your Name] END

completion:
A memo was sent out by senior officials at Queen's Park to remind political staffers about conflict-of-interest rules. This reminder comes after an auditor-general's report found that certain developers were favored by the government's removal of lands from the protected greenbelt. The memo, signed by Premier Doug Ford's chief of staff, Patrick Sackville, and Ontario's top civil servant, Secretary of the Cabinet Michelle Diemanuele, was shared with reporters to ensure transparency.

The memo highlights the importance of following the Public Service of Ontario Act, which includes rules regarding conflict of interest and political activity. Public servants are reminded to disclose any actual or potential conflicts of interest. It also mentions that a comprehensive response to the auditor's report is being prepared, with a working group overseeing its implementation.

The purpose of the memo is to address several recommendations made by Auditor-General Bonnie Lysyk. Lysyk's report stated that the greenbelt decision was biased and seriously flawed, lacking necessary environmental and financial analysis. The government has accepted all but one of her recommendations, which involves revisiting the greenbelt decision itself.

In the memo, ministers' chiefs of staff are cautioned that proposals submitted to cabinet or its committees must provide accurate and complete information, including options and risks. It also emphasizes the importance of consultation, including with indigenous leaders. Lysyk had previously pointed out that vital details about the greenbelt proposal were missing, and that the land selection was mostly done by Ryan Amato, the chief of staff to the Municipal Affairs and Housing Minister, rather than apolitical civil servants. The report revealed that Amato, appointed by the premier's office, received submissions from developers that accounted for the majority of the removals from the greenbelt.

The premier's office, in response to another recommendation, has asked the integrity commissioner to investigate if Amato broke any rules in his dealings with developers. Lysyk's report also highlighted the use of strict non-disclosure agreements, which prevented civil servants involved in the greenbelt decision from consulting municipalities or experts. Chiefs of staff are now required to report any proposed use of confidentiality agreements to the cabinet office or the treasury board secretariat. The memo also reminds them to follow existing requirements to document any materials or proposals received from external sources.

The opposition NDP dismissed the memo as government spin, claiming that the government is attempting to deflect blame for the greenbelt removals. They accuse Premier Doug Ford and Housing Minister Steve Clark of being wholly responsible for the corrupt actions. Despite the criticism, the government remains firm in their decision to remove 3,000 hectares from the protected greenbelt. Finance Minister Peter Bethlenfalvy defended the decision, stating that it was necessary due to the housing crisis and the influx of new residents to the province.

The release of the memo coincided with Finance Minister Bethlenfalvy's announcement of the province's first-quarter financial results. He addressed concerns raised by reporters and reiterated the government's stance on the greenbelt removal. Despite expert reports suggesting that there was already enough land for housing, Bethlenfalvy presented recent numbers indicating a significant increase in the province's population. END

Hello, my name is John Stapleton. I am a resident and a voter in Scarborough North. I have been studying social and economic policy for quite some time now. In fact, I have lived in northern Scarborough for a remarkable 44 years. 

In the new millennium, I had the privilege of serving as president of a Canadian non-profit board and as chair of an Ontario agency. Currently, I am honored to chair an Ontario commission. Through these experiences, I have gained a deep understanding of what it's like to live within government rules and constraints. 

However, I firmly believe that we still have choices, even within these constraints. It seems to me that you have only apologized for the limitations under which you must operate, rather than making proactive choices. As someone who has witnessed numerous electoral boundary changes, I can confidently say that in 2018, Scarborough achieved a level of electoral transparency and fairness that we had never seen before. For the first time in living memory, all our Scarborough electoral boundaries across different levels of government became aligned.

And yet, now your commission is proposing changes not only within Scarborough, but also to Scarborough's own boundaries. This suggestion comes after the electoral boundary changes made in 2013. These moves not only diminish our participation in democracy in Scarborough, but they also reduce Toronto's overall involvement. 

At the Scarbrough Community Renewal Organization (SCRO), we do understand why you are proposing these changes. We comprehend the algorithm for change, the shifts in population, and the constraints you face in proposing new boundaries and a reduction in seats. However, whether other boundaries remain the same or change, it inevitably leads to either confusion or upheaval. It's a challenging situation to navigate.

If provincial and municipal boundaries change, it brings about more upheaval. On the other hand, if they remain the same, the boundaries fall out of sync. Trying to find the balance is no easy task. 

I won't delve into the grave and damaging consequences of the proposed changes, as I'm sure you are aware of them. But let me touch on some key points highlighted in recent media reports. Since 2011, the population of the City of Toronto has grown by more than 179,000 residents. To put that in perspective, that's more people than live in Prince Edward Island. Yet, PEI is represented by four seats in the House of Commons and will maintain that number in the next election. Despite adding more people than the population of PEI, Toronto is set to lose a seat.

Over the past decade, Ontario has welcomed almost two million new residents, which is greater than the combined populations of New Brunswick and Saskatchewan. For a population of around 1.2 million, Saskatchewan has 14 seats, meaning approximately 84,000 residents per riding. Similarly, New Brunswick, with 789,225 people, has 10 seats, averaging around 79,000 people per riding. Meanwhile, in 2011, Ontario, with 12.9 million people, was entitled to 121 seats, or around 106,000 people per riding. So, after growing by almost two million people, how many new seats is Ontario gaining? Just one.

The commission explains that it must reduce Toronto's districts by one but add two outside the city limits due to faster population growth in the suburbs. The objective is to correct significant disparities in voter equality that have emerged across the province in the past decade, as stated by Justice Lynne Leitch, the commission's chairperson.

With this proposed change, Scarborough-Agincourt is being split up, redistributing a substantial part of our community into North York and erasing any reference to the historical neighborhood of Agincourt in the process. Moreover, Scarborough is losing an entire riding. This proposal eliminates a significant portion of Scarborough North and Scarborough-Agincourt, merging our community into a new riding called Scarborough Northwest.

I hope this helps shed some light on the concerns we have regarding the proposed changes. We understand the complexities you face in making these decisions, but it's important to carefully consider the impact they may have on our community and the overall participation of Toronto. Thank you for taking the time to listen. END

completion:
Smoke from wildfires in forests and grasslands can be a significant source of air pollution for Canadians. It's not uncommon for communities across Canada to experience wildfire smoke events, and unfortunately, this is expected to continue. Canada is warming at a faster rate than the rest of the world, which creates ideal conditions for more frequent and longer-lasting wildfires. 

Wildfire season typically runs from early April to late October, and during this time, the fires can produce dense smoke. Unfortunately, it's difficult to predict when fires will occur, how big they will be, how much smoke they will generate, or what direction the smoke will travel. In fact, smoke from wildfires can be carried hundreds or even thousands of kilometers from the fire zone, which means communities in Canada can be impacted by smoke from other parts of the world. 

Certain groups of people are at higher risk of health problems when exposed to wildfire smoke, including seniors, pregnant individuals, smokers, infants and young children, those who work outdoors, people involved in strenuous outdoor exercise, and those with existing illnesses or chronic health conditions. However, it's important to note that during heavy smoke conditions, everyone is at risk, regardless of age or health. 

If you find yourself in a wildfire smoke event, it's crucial to take care when spending time outdoors. Check local air quality conditions regularly to determine if it's safe to be outside. Pay attention to the Air Quality Health Index (AQHI), special air quality statements, and other indicators of smoke levels in your community. Limit outdoor activities and strenuous physical exercise as much as possible. If you experience any symptoms, listen to your body and reduce or stop activities accordingly. 

To ensure clean air in your home, stay indoors and keep windows and doors closed. If it's too warm, consider using air conditioning if available. If you don't have air conditioning, and it's too warm to keep windows closed, seek out local cooling or clean air spaces. You can also use a portable air purifier in a room where you spend a lot of time to decrease the fine particles from wildfire smoke. Additionally, limit the use of exhaust fans when not cooking. If you can't maintain cool, clean air inside your home, be aware of locations in your community where you can find clean air and take a break from the smoke. Libraries, shopping malls, community centers, and cleaner air shelters are typically safe places with air conditioning and filtered air. For the most up-to-date information on publicly accessible locations, contact your local health or emergency authorities.

It's common to feel anxious, stressed, sad, or isolated during a smoke event. Taking care of yourself by eating well, getting enough sleep, exercising indoors, and staying in contact with friends can help alleviate these feelings. If you're struggling to cope with symptoms of stress, anxiety, or depression, don't hesitate to seek help from a healthcare provider. Remember, although a wildfire smoke event may last awhile, it will eventually come to an end. Maintaining a positive outlook and attitude will help you get through it.

If you must spend time outdoors, consider wearing a well-fitted respirator type mask, such as a NIOSH-certified N95 or equivalent respirator. These masks can help reduce your exposure to the fine particles in smoke, which pose the greatest risk to health. However, it's essential to note that respirators do not reduce exposure to the gases present in wildfire smoke. Listen to your body and reduce or stop activities if you experience symptoms. If smoke persists for more than a few days, try to stay active when you can. Find a place with clean air to exercise indoors, like a gym, community center, or even your own home. If you need to work outdoors, consult with your provincial or territorial occupational health and safety organization or your local health authority. They can provide guidance on how to work safely outdoors during wildfire smoke events. END

The opening of a new session of parliament is marked by a significant event called the Speech from the Throne. This speech serves as an introduction to the government's direction and goals, outlining their plans for achieving them. In order for the Senate and the House of Commons to conduct public business, it is essential for Canada's head of state or their representative to read the speech.

Traditionally, the Governor General, as the Queen's representative in Canada, reads the speech from the throne. However, on two occasions in 1957 and 1977, the Queen herself was present in Canada and personally delivered the speech. It is referred to as the Speech from the Throne because the Governor General reads it from the seat - or the throne - in the Senate chamber, which is reserved for the Queen or her representative in Canada. During the reading of the speech, members of the House of Commons, Senators, Justices of the Supreme Court of Canada, and other invited guests are in attendance.

The Governor General has two crucial roles in the opening of a new session of parliament. First, on the advice of the Prime Minister, the Governor General issues a proclamation summoning parliament. This proclamation is necessary for the Senate and the House of Commons to officially begin a session of parliament. Additionally, the Governor General reads the speech that is prepared by the government. They may also add their own introduction to the speech, outlining their own activities.

The Usher of the Black Rod, a senior parliamentary officer, plays an important role in the Senate chamber. Appointed by the Governor General upon the recommendation of the Prime Minister, the Usher of the Black Rod has various ceremonial and security-related responsibilities in support of the Senate. One of their duties includes assisting in the delivery of the Speech from the Throne, which is read in the Senate. Before the Governor General reads the speech, the Usher of the Black Rod leaves the Senate chamber and knocks three times with the Black Rod on the doors of the House of Commons. This signals to the members of Parliament that they are being called to the Senate chamber. The position of the Usher of the Black Rod traces its origins back to approximately 600 years ago in England. In Canada, the title "Gentleman Usher of the Black Rod" was used until 1997 when Mary C. McLaren became the first woman to hold the position. Since then, the title used in Canada has been gender-neutral.

After the Governor General delivers the Speech from the Throne, the new session of parliament officially begins. Public business can now commence in both the Senate and the House of Commons. The first order of business is for the Prime Minister to introduce Bill C-1 in the House of Commons. Similarly, a Senator introduces a corresponding bill, Bill S-1, in the Senate. These bills demonstrate the independence of the House of Commons and the Senate from the crown, asserting their right to meet and debate without strictly adhering to the agenda presented in the Speech from the Throne. The bills are given the first reading but not the second reading. Following the first reading, the House of Commons and the Senate engage in debates regarding the Speech from the Throne. END

Recognizing the challenges faced in organizing and celebrating Pride, we are empowering organizers worldwide by open-sourcing our entire pride campaign design. All year round, we recognize the numerous ways this diverse community contributes to and influences innovation at Microsoft and beyond. Join us in celebrating by visiting "Inclusion is Innovation" and exploring powerful employee stories of strength, community, and leadership.

In March, we introduced Microsoft 365 Copilot, a helpful tool for work. We are thrilled to take the next step in our journey by bringing Copilot to more customers and adding new features. Additionally, we are sharing new data and insights from our 2023 Work Trend Index, which explores how work is evolving in the age of AI.
