Their feedback has been overwhelmingly positive, with many stating that Copilot has the potential to revolutionize the way we work. They have highlighted how it is a game-changer for meetings and is starting to transform their creative processes. They have also provided valuable suggestions on how we can further assist people in adapting to this new way of working, such as the need for more natural and interactive conversations. As we continue to make Copilot available to more customers, we will rely on this feedback to refine the tool and guide users as they adapt to this innovative approach.

Today, we are excited to announce the Microsoft 365 Copilot Early Access Program. This invitation-only, paid preview will initially roll out to 600 customers worldwide. Additionally, to help every customer prepare for AI integration, we will introduce the Semantic Index for Copilot, a new feature available in Microsoft 365 E3 and E5. The Semantic Index is a sophisticated map of user and company data. For instance, when you inquire about the "March sales report," it not only searches for files with those words in the name or body but also comprehends that sales reports are created by Kelly on the finance team using Excel. This knowledge allows Copilot to determine your intent and help you find the information you need. The Semantic Index for Copilot is crucial for providing relevant and actionable responses. Furthermore, it enhances enterprise search results for E3 and E5 customers, whether they use Copilot or not.

The 2023 Work Trend Index reveals that the shift towards AI in the workplace is well underway. Just as customers turned to Microsoft for assistance with the transition to remote and flexible work, they now seek our guidance on how AI will further transform work. Our survey, which involved 31,000 people across 31 countries, and the analysis of productivity signals in Microsoft 365 and labor market trends on LinkedIn, provides valuable insights into the impact of AI on work.

The data clearly shows that the pace and volume of work have significantly increased, and employees are struggling to keep up, jeopardizing innovation. Both leaders and employees are eager for AI to alleviate this burden. Satya Nadella, Chairman, and CEO of Microsoft said, "This new generation of AI will remove the drudgery of work and unleash creativity. There is a great opportunity for AI-powered tools to help reduce digital debt, enhance AI skills, and empower employees."

The report highlights three important insights that business leaders should consider when adopting AI responsibly. Firstly, digital debt is impeding innovation. The overwhelming amount of data, emails, and chats has surpassed our capacity to handle them effectively. Every minute spent managing this digital debt takes away from valuable creative work. In a world where creativity drives productivity, digital debt is more than just an inconvenience – it negatively impacts businesses. When 62% of employees report spending too much time on information search, communication, and coordination, they have less time for deep thinking, creativity, and collaboration. Nearly two out of three employees state that they do not have enough time and energy to perform their jobs effectively. These employees are also 3.5 times more likely to struggle with innovation and strategic thinking. END

Space captivates people of all ages, igniting their curiosity about the great unknown. With NASA's remarkable progress towards their upcoming lunar missions, a whole new generation of Americans will have the privilege of witnessing the breathtaking power and sheer joy of a moon landing. Not only does this inspire individuals from diverse backgrounds, but it also encourages them to pursue rewarding careers in space-related fields such as science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). As part of this endeavor, Microsoft is honored to join forces with NASA to host our inaugural Space Education Day on Tuesday, June 20 at our office in Arlington, Virginia. Microsoft's Minecraft Education recently partnered with NASA and the Challenge Center to equip students with essential skills for the next era of space exploration. 3. NASA MSI Space Accelerators: Partners will discuss the objectives and goals of the NASA Space Accelerator program, which aims to connect minority-serving institutions with mentorship opportunities and funding from both NASA and Microsoft.

Toronto Public Health (TPH) has recently reported its first probable case of West Nile virus (WNV) in an adult resident this year. WNV is an infection that is spread through mosquito bites. Currently, the risk of getting infected in Toronto is low. However, TPH wants to remind residents to take precautions before the long weekend in August to avoid mosquito bites and potential infection. Here are some simple steps you can take:

1. When you're outdoors, wear light-colored clothing, long pants, and long-sleeved shirts. This will help protect you from mosquito bites.
2. Use insect repellent that contains N, N-diethyl-meta-toluamide (DEET) or icaridin. Follow the instructions on the label to ensure proper use.
3. Be extra cautious during the peak mosquito-biting hours, which are dusk and dawn. Apply repellent and cover up to minimize your risk. Also, make sure your home has screens on Windows and doors that fit tightly to keep mosquitoes out.
4. Eliminate any standing water on your property where mosquitoes can breed. This includes items such as pool covers, buckets, planters, toys, and garbage/recycling containers.

The symptoms of WNV usually appear between two and 14 days after a person is bitten by an infected mosquito. These symptoms may include fever, headache, nausea, vomiting, body aches, skin rash, and swollen lymph glands. Older individuals and those with compromised immune systems are at a higher risk of severe illness. If you experience any of these symptoms or have concerns, please contact your healthcare provider.

TPH conducts mosquito surveillance and monitoring every year from mid-June to mid-September. This involves setting up mosquito traps across Toronto and sending the collected mosquitoes to a laboratory for identification and testing. So far in 2023, 20 batches of mosquitoes have tested positive for WNV. With the recent hot weather in Toronto, there is an increased risk of infected mosquitoes transmitting the virus.

In 2022, there were 14 confirmed batches of mosquitoes carrying the virus and 14 laboratory-confirmed human cases of WNV. For more information on WNV and ways to reduce the risk of infection, please visit the city's West Nile virus webpage.

Dr. Eileen de Villa, the Medical Officer of Health, emphasizes that while the risk of WNV infection remains low in Toronto, it's important to remind residents of the steps they can take to avoid mosquito bites when enjoying the beautiful summer weather. Remember to apply insect repellent, wear light-colored clothing, long pants, and long-sleeved shirts, and take extra care between dusk and dawn, which are peak mosquito-biting hours.

Toronto is a vibrant city with a population of over three million people, known for its diversity and livability. As the fourth-largest city in North America, Toronto is a global leader in various fields such as technology, finance, film, music, culture, innovation, and climate action. This is due to the investments made by its government, residents, and businesses. For more information, you can visit the city's website or follow us on Twitter, Instagram, or Facebook. END

Exciting news for Toronto residents! The city is expanding the Fair Pass transit discount program to make transit more affordable for an additional 50,000 low-income individuals. Starting today, the program will prioritize residents between the ages of 20 and 64 who are living in deep poverty, such as low-wage workers, part-time workers, newcomers, and unemployed individuals receiving employment assistance. We are also extending the program to residents on the waitlist for subsidized housing and child care, providing immediate financial support for their transit costs.

The Fair Pass program offers a 12-month discount on TTC travel, including Wheel-Trans. Currently, the program provides a 36% discount on single adult fares (which amounts to $2.10 per fare) and a 21% discount on monthly passes (bringing the cost of an adult monthly pass to $123.25). To avail of these discounts, riders simply need to add a discount code to their Presto card.

This marks the beginning of the program's third phase, where any Toronto resident who meets the age and income criteria can receive the discount. Based on the latest thresholds, a single individual with an after-tax income below $20,514 or a family of four with an income below $41,028 would be eligible for the discount. While the income threshold has been temporarily reduced to 75% of the low-income measure, the program aims to return to the original threshold of the low-income measure plus 15% as soon as possible.

If you receive assistance through Ontario Works (OW), the Ontario Disability Support Program (ODSP), or a Toronto child care fee subsidy, you can continue providing your program identification number when applying for the Fair Pass program. For all other applicants, you will need to provide income documents to assess your financial eligibility. Applying for the Fair Pass program is easy – you can do it online or by calling 416-338-8888.

To make it even more convenient for residents to get a Presto card when applying for the Fair Pass program, we have partnered with the Toronto Public Library's complimentary Presto card initiative. Free Presto cards are available at participating library branches while supplies last.

The Fair Pass program is a key initiative of the city's poverty reduction strategy, approved by Toronto City Council in 2016. It aims to make transit more affordable for low-income adult residents. If you want more information about the city's poverty reduction strategy, you can find it on the city's webpage.

This expansion of the Fair Pass program is the third time eligibility has been extended. Phase one in 2018 included OW and ODSP recipients, and in 2019, the program expanded to include Toronto Children's Services' child care fee subsidy recipients. Just this year, it expanded again to include rent-geared-to-income (RGI) subsidy recipients.

The Fair Pass transit discount program directly targets low-income working-age adults in Toronto, providing them with a much-needed discount on TTC fares. We understand that low-income residents rely heavily on public transit to access essential services like education, employment, social and health services, and opportunities outside their immediate community. By offering a transit discount, the Fair Pass program helps alleviate some of the financial burdens that low-income residents face on a daily basis.

As the fourth-largest city in North America, we are recognized as a global leader in various fields, including technology, finance, film, music, culture, innovation, and climate action. These achievements are the result of the collective efforts of our government, residents, and businesses.

We are thrilled to expand the Fair Pass program and continue making Toronto an inclusive and accessible city for all. END

completion:
Apple has just announced an exciting update on its racial equity and justice initiative (REJI). Over the past three years, Apple has more than doubled its initial financial commitment, now totaling over $200 million. This long-term global effort aims to advance equity and expand opportunities for Black, Hispanic/Latinx, and Indigenous communities.

Since launching REJI in June 2020, Apple has been actively supporting education, economic empowerment, and criminal justice reform work across the United States. And now, their efforts have expanded to Australia, the United Kingdom, and Mexico. It's an incredible step forward at a crucial moment when protests against racial injustice have swept the nation.

REJI builds upon Apple's ongoing work to create greater access to opportunity and promote equity for underserved groups. They have established a dedicated entity that deeply engages with schools and communities to accelerate progress. Apple's CEO, Tim Cook, emphasizes the urgency of this work and their commitment to collaboration and a common sense of purpose.

Through REJI's education grants, Apple has already reached over 160,000 learners through in-person courses and out-of-school offerings. Additionally, they have committed over $50 million to historically Black colleges and universities (HBCUs) and Hispanic-serving institutions (HSIs) to support science, technology, engineering, arts, and math opportunities.

In the realm of economic empowerment, REJI funds financial institutions that support Black, Hispanic/Latinx, and Indigenous entrepreneurs and businesses. This includes venture capital firms, community development financial institutions, and minority depository institutions. These investments aim to break down barriers and provide much-needed support to underrepresented communities.

Furthermore, REJI's criminal justice reform grants have made a significant impact by supporting legal services, safe housing, identification services, healthcare access, and other vital reentry services for over 19,000 justice-impacted individuals.

Lisa Jackson, Apple's Vice President of Environment, Policy, and Social Initiatives, highlights the importance of continuing to build on the progress made and ensuring equitable opportunities for Black and Brown communities in the US and around the world.

As part of their expanding work, Apple has also announced a new partnership with the Brother's Keeper Alliance (MBKA), a program of the Obama Foundation. Through this partnership, Apple aims to close opportunity gaps faced by boys and young men of color. They will support training for community leaders and MBKA staff, expand programming, and strengthen the network through targeted community impact microgrants. It's a collaboration that aims to nurture creativity, foster innovation, and transform the lives of boys and young men of color across the country.

Lastly, Apple is committed to increasing their investments in minority-owned businesses. They have recently pledged an additional $25 million to three venture capital funds - Collab Capital, Harlem Capital, and VamosVentures. This brings their total venture capital support to $50 million and overall financing to mission-aligned diverse businesses and financial institutions to over $100 million. These investments are part of REJI's economic empowerment pillar, which focuses on addressing systemic barriers, creating opportunities, and providing funding to underrepresented communities and businesses of color.

Apple's dedication to this initiative is commendable, and their efforts will undoubtedly have a positive and lasting impact on creating a more just and equitable world. They remain committed to their values and will continue to expand their efforts to create opportunities, uplift communities, and build a better future for all. END

Apple's world-class services play a vital role in the daily lives of millions of users. These services help users discover new artists on Apple Music, stay updated with current events through Apple News and Apple Podcasts, and navigate and explore the world using Apple Maps. Exciting news is on the horizon for Apple device users worldwide! In the coming months, they will be able to enjoy new features and enhancements with iOS17, iPadOS17, macOS Sonoma, watchOS10, and tvOS17.

Eddy Cue, Apple's Senior Vice President of Services, expressed, "Apple's services enrich the lives of millions of users every day, so we constantly strive to provide the best experience possible." Our aim is not only to make services more powerful but also more enjoyable. I am immensely proud of the incredible lineup of new features we are launching this fall, including collaborative playlists on Apple Music, offline maps on Apple Maps, and new experiences on Apple Podcasts.

Let's take a look at some of the most exciting tools and experiences that users can look forward to:

1. Listen and collaborate with family and friends using collaborative playlists. Apple Music subscribers can join forces to create and edit playlists together, even adding emoji reactions to specific songs.

2. Immerse yourself in an enhanced Apple Music sing experience with Continuity Camera. With Apple Music sing and Continuity Camera, users can see themselves onscreen and apply brand-new camera filters as they sing along to their favorite songs.

3. Discover the artists behind your favorite songs with song credits in Apple Music. Fans can now access comprehensive data about the artists who contributed to their favorite tracks, including their roles and the instruments they played.

4. Share the music playing in your car with SharePlay. Apple Music is introducing SharePlay for car use, making it easy for everyone to contribute to the music selection. Trusted iPhone devices in the car will automatically suggest joining the session. Listeners can control the music from their own devices, even without an Apple Music subscription.

5. Stream the entire catalog of Apple Music radio shows on Apple Podcasts. Subscribers can now listen to the complete collection of award-winning, commercial-free Apple Music radio shows on Apple Podcasts. They can follow individual shows to automatically download and be notified of new episodes as soon as they are released.

6. Browse offline maps with just a tap using Apple Maps. Users can select an area on their device and download it with a simple tap. While offline, users will have access to turn-by-turn navigation for driving, walking, transit, and cycling. They can also view their estimated time of arrival, find places on maps, and more.

7. Stay updated on real-time electric vehicle charging availability. Maps users with electric vehicles can now see real-time charging station availability filtered by charging network, plug type, and more. Users with compatible vehicles can designate a preferred charging network.

8. Explore thousands of park trails with ease. Maps now makes it simpler than ever to discover thousands of trails in parks across the United States. Detailed place cards provide information such as trail length, type, difficulty, and elevation gain.

9. Build a custom workout or meditation routine with custom plans on Apple Fitness+. Custom plans offer a personalized workout or meditation schedule based on the day, duration, workout type, and more.

10. Queue up Fitness+ workouts and meditations with stacks. Fitness+ introduces stacks, allowing users to select multiple workouts and meditations to do back-to-back, seamlessly transitioning to the next activity without interruptions. Stacks can be saved in a user's library for future use.

With these exciting additions and improvements, Apple is dedicated to delivering an exceptional experience to its users. We are always striving to make our services more powerful and enjoyable, ensuring that they continue to enrich the lives of millions every day. END

Introducing the new 15-inch MacBook Air, the ultimate 15-inch laptop in the world. With its stunning 15.3-inch liquid retina display, powerful M2 chip, and up to 18 hours of battery life, this MacBook Air combines both performance and portability. It's also the thinnest 15-inch laptop available, making it incredibly sleek and lightweight.

Let's talk about the brilliant 15.3-inch liquid retina display. This spacious high-resolution display enhances the viewing experience, allowing users to see more content. With its impressive brightness of up to 500 nits and support for 1 billion colors, the liquid retina display makes visuals incredibly rich and vibrant, with razor-sharp text. It's twice the resolution and 25 percent brighter than comparable PC laptops. 

In terms of portability, the new MacBook Air takes the lead as the thinnest 15-inch laptop, measuring only 11.5 mm thin. Weighing just 1.51 kg (3.3 pounds), it's easy to carry around without sacrificing durability. It's almost 40 percent thinner and half a pound lighter than comparable PC laptops. Additionally, the MacBook Air features MagSafe charging, two Thunderbolt ports for connectivity, a 3.5 mm headphone jack, and it comes in four stunning finishes: Midnight, Starlight, Space Gray, and Silver. 

When it comes to performance, the M2 chip in the 15-inch MacBook Air is outstanding. It's up to 12x faster than the fastest Intel-based MacBook Air. Compared to the best-selling 15-inch PC laptop with a Core i7 processor, the new MacBook Air is up to twice as fast. The M2 chip includes a powerful 8-core CPU, a 10-core GPU for fast graphics, and a 16-core neural engine. With 100 GB/s of memory bandwidth and support for up to 24 GB of fast unified memory, multitasking and handling complex tasks is a breeze. Whether you're working, playing, or creating, the performance of the M2 chip enables you to do it all, anywhere you go. 

The MacBook Air also features a 1080p FaceTime HD camera, perfect for video calls and conferences. With the advanced image signal processor on the M2 chip, users will look fantastic on video calls. The three-mic array captures clean audio using beamforming algorithms, ensuring that your voice comes through loud and clear. You can even pause video playback during FaceTime calls on the MacBook Air. 

With macOS Ventura, productivity reaches new heights. Messages and Mail have been improved, Safari is the fastest browser on Mac, and it brings a passwordless future with passkeys. Continuity Camera brings video conferencing features to any Mac, including Desk View, Center Stage, and Studio Light. Stage Manager helps you stay organized, automatically arranging apps and windows for a more focused workflow. iCloud Shared Photo Library allows you to create and share a separate photo library among your family members, and the Freeform app provides a flexible canvas for enhanced productivity and self-expression. Seamlessly switch between your Mac and iPhone with continuity features like Handoff, AirDrop, Universal Clipboard, and Messages. 

In summary, the 15-inch MacBook Air is the ultimate combination of power, portability, and performance. Its stunning liquid retina display, thin and lightweight design, exceptional battery life, and impressive M2 chip make it a remarkable laptop for all your needs. Order yours today and experience the unrivaled world of the MacBook Air. END

Apple has exciting news to share! They have just announced the M2 Ultra, a powerful new system on a chip that brings significant performance improvements to the Mac lineup. The M2 Ultra is the biggest and most advanced chip ever created by Apple, making the new Mac Studio and Mac Pro the most powerful desktop computers they have ever made.

The M2 Ultra utilizes cutting-edge technology, including Apple's groundbreaking Ultrafusion, which connects two M2 Max chips to double the performance. With a second-generation 5-nanometer process, the M2 Ultra boasts an impressive 134 billion transistors, 20 billion more than its predecessor, the M1 Ultra.

One of the standout features of the M2 Ultra is its unified memory architecture, which supports an incredible 192 GB of memory capacity, a 50 percent increase from the M1 Ultra. The memory bandwidth has also doubled to 800 GB/s, surpassing the capabilities of the M2 Max.

When it comes to performance, the M2 Ultra truly takes things to the next level. Its CPU is 20 percent faster than the M1 Ultra, while the GPU offers a 30 percent improvement. The neural engine is also 40 percent faster, making it perfect for demanding workflows and tasks. Additionally, the media engine of the M2 Ultra is twice as capable as the M2 Max, offering blazing ProRes acceleration.

Apple's Senior Vice President of Hardware Technologies, Johny Srouji, expressed his excitement, stating that the M2 Ultra delivers incredible performance and capabilities for professional users, all while maintaining Apple Silicon's renowned power efficiency. Srouji goes on to say that the M2 Ultra is the most powerful chip ever created for a personal computer, thanks to its impressive CPU, GPU, and neural engine performance, as well as its massive memory bandwidth.

Moreover, Apple's Ultrafusion technology, which connects the two M2 Max dies, is an industry-leading packaging technology that allows the M2 Ultra to appear as a single chip to software. This means that software doesn't have to be rewritten to take advantage of the M2 Ultra's immense power, making it truly unique in the industry.

The M2 Ultra's 24-core CPU consists of 16 high-performance cores and eight high-efficiency cores, resulting in up to 20 percent faster performance compared to the M1 Ultra. For creative professionals using programs like DaVinci Resolve, they can expect up to 50 percent faster video processing on a Mac Studio powered by the M2 Ultra.

The GPU of the M2 Ultra can be configured with either 60 or 76 cores, providing up to 30 percent better performance compared to the already powerful GPU of the M1 Ultra. When rendering 3D effects with programs like Octane, users can experience up to 3 times faster speeds on the Mac Studio with the M2 Ultra.

Apple's unified memory architecture, a hallmark of Apple Silicon, delivers exceptional bandwidth, low latency, and unmatched power efficiency. With an impressive 800 GB/s of system memory bandwidth, the M2 Ultra surpasses anything found in a PC. It can also be configured with a massive 192 GB of unified memory, enabling workflows that are simply not possible on a PC. For example, the M2 Ultra can handle massive machine learning workloads in a single system, surpassing even the most powerful discrete GPUs in this regard.

The M2 Ultra integrates Apple's latest custom technologies directly onto the chip, optimizing performance and efficiency. It features a 32-core neural engine, delivering an impressive 31.6 trillion operations per second, making it 40 percent faster than the M1 Ultra. The media engine of the M2 Ultra is twice as capable as the M2 Max, allowing for accelerated video processing. It supports dedicated hardware-enabled encoding and decoding for formats like H.264, HEVC, and ProRes, enabling the M2 Ultra to playback up to 22 streams of 8K ProRes 422 video, surpassing any PC chip's capabilities. Furthermore, the display engine can support up to six Pro Display XDRs, driving over 100 million pixels. Lastly, Apple ensures best-in-class security with the latest secure enclave and hardware-verified secure boot and runtime anti-exploitation technologies.

In conclusion, the M2 Ultra is an extraordinary chip that pushes the boundaries of Mac performance. It brings immense power to professional users while maintaining Apple's commitment to energy efficiency. With its advancements in CPU, GPU, and neural engine performance, as well as its exceptional memory capacity and bandwidth, the M2 Ultra is truly the most powerful chip ever created for a personal computer. END

The internet has become an essential tool for news organizations, enabling them to communicate quickly, conduct research effortlessly, and reach a global audience with their work. In fact, it often serves as the primary distribution channel for critical and investigative reporting that exposes wrongdoing, creates awareness, and brings about positive change in society and the economy.

Unfortunately, there are individuals who aim to hinder this important journalism by silencing it when it is most needed. Initially, we tested Project Shield with a select group of trusted individuals, and now we are excited to expand it to all news sites worldwide. Our goal is to protect these sites from DDoS attacks and eliminate DDoS as a form of censorship.

Through our early testing phase, we not only managed to keep websites online during attacks that would have otherwise taken them offline, but we also gained valuable insights into how these attacks occur and how we can enhance our services to better defend against them.

Furthermore, Project Shield is not solely focused on safeguarding journalism. It also aims to improve the overall health of the internet by mitigating a significant threat faced by publishers and individuals who want to share content that some may find inconvenient. Good morning! My name is Sabrina Geremia, and I am the Vice President and Head of Google in Canada. Today, I am joined by Jason Kee, an expert on search, news, and ads. We are here to answer your questions about our approach to bill C-18 and our news product tests. 

Google has been proudly present in Canada for over 20 years, with offices in Montreal, Toronto, Ottawa, and Waterloo, which is a Canadian center of engineering excellence. We also have remote colleagues all across the country. We truly consider these Canadian communities as our own, which is why we have made significant investments in them over the years. 

At Google, we work closely with the news industry. Through various programs, products, and partnerships, we are one of the world's largest financial supporters of journalism. We provide significant value and funding to news organizations in Canada and around the globe. Just last year, we linked to Canadian news publishers over 3.6 billion times, completely free of charge. This helped them generate revenue through ads and new subscriptions, resulting in an estimated value of $250 million for Canadian publishers. Additionally, we have paid agreements with more than 150 publications across the country, in both official languages, including Le Devoir, CN2i, Torstar, The Globe and Mail, Black Press Media, Métro Média, Postmedia, Village Media, and many others. These agreements support Canadian newsrooms of all sizes, enabling them to deliver comprehensive general-interest and local news to their communities. 

We understand that innovation is crucial to the future of news. That's why through the Google News Initiative, we provide tools, training, and funding to support Canadian news organizations, independent journalists, and journalism students. We are committed to helping them adapt, innovate, and thrive. In fact, we have made a three-year commitment to train 5,000 Canadian journalists and journalism students on strengthening digital skills in newsrooms. Last year alone, we trained over 1,500 Canadian journalists from different newsrooms, including students, independent journalists, and those serving underrepresented communities. 

We share the government's goal of promoting a healthy, innovative, and diverse news ecosystem in the digital age. Throughout the process of bill C-18, we have been constructive and transparent about our concerns. We have actively worked with parliamentarians to improve the bill and offered reasonable and balanced solutions. Unfortunately, the bill has some serious issues. The provision in C-18 that puts a price on linking to webpages sets a dangerous precedent. It threatens the open web and the free flow of information. Moreover, it could incentivize the creation of low-quality clickbait content instead of supporting quality journalism. The exemption and eligibility criteria in the bill have also significantly shifted, requiring subsidies for media companies even if they do not produce news, are not online, and regardless of whether we link to their content. The lack of a clearly defined commitment to a code of ethics for eligibility also compromises the standards of journalism in Canada. Unreasonable timelines and unfair arbitration provisions have been added as well, creating a framework that discourages good faith negotiations. Instead of supporting local journalism, C-18 would end up subsidizing large legacy organizations and broadcasters, hurting emerging and innovative organizations that provide quality local news in communities all across Canada. It is clear that this bill is no longer about supporting journalism. 

Under C-18, platforms like Google would be held financially liable for providing free links to news that Canadians are searching for, with no cap on the financial burden. This raises concerns about how Canadians will find and share news online. As the bill has progressed, we have had to consider potential changes to our products to comply with it. These changes would need to be tested before implementation. END

Hello everyone! In recent weeks, the world has been confronted with violent and racist attacks against the black community, which has shed light on the deeply ingrained structural and systemic racism that black people have endured for generations. I personally embarked on a journey to find answers within our own organization. By listening to the personal stories shared by members of our black leadership advisory group and our black+ googlers, I have been even more convinced of the harsh reality faced by black communities. Systemic racism has seeped into every aspect of their lives, from encounters with law enforcement to access to housing, finance, healthcare, education, and employment.

As a company, and as individuals who came together to create products that benefit everyone, Google is fully committed to transforming the energy of this moment into lasting and impactful change. Today, we are proud to announce a series of concrete commitments that will drive progress both internally and externally. We aim to build sustainable equity for Google's black+ community and ensure our products and programs are genuinely helpful during the critical moments that matter to black users.

Developing sustainable equity and bringing about meaningful change must begin within our own company. By strengthening our dedication to racial equity and inclusion, Google will be able to create even more helpful products for our users and the world. To achieve this, we are making several commitments to promote sustainable equity within our black+ community.

Firstly, we will work towards increasing black+ representation at senior levels and set a goal to improve leadership representation of underrepresented groups by 30 percent by 2025. To achieve this objective, we will advertise senior leadership positions externally as well as internally, and invest more in cities such as Atlanta, Washington D.C., Chicago, and London, where we already have offices. We will adopt a similar approach in other regions, using location-specific strategies to recruit and hire more underrepresented googlers in communities that already foster a sense of belonging and contribute to an improved quality of life.

Secondly, we will address representation challenges more comprehensively, with a focus on hiring, retention, and promotion at all levels. To guide these efforts, I will establish a talent liaison within each product and functional area, responsible for mentoring and advocating for the progression and retention of underrepresented googlers. Additionally, I am assembling a task force comprising senior members of our black+ community at Google. Their mission will be to develop concrete recommendations and proposals to ensure accountability across all areas that impact the experience of black+ googlers, including recruitment, hiring, performance management, career progression, and retention. I have requested that the task force present their specific proposals, including measurable goals, within 90 days.

Thirdly, we will strive to create a stronger sense of inclusion and belonging for all googlers, with a particular focus on our black+ community. Our internal research has shown that feelings of belonging are influenced by various aspects of our work experience, including the psychological safety we feel within our teams, the support provided by our managers and leaders, fair people processes, and opportunities for personal and professional growth. In all these dimensions, we are committed to building more inclusive practices and policies, and we will be open to revisiting and refining them when necessary. For instance, we have recently realized that our security practice of googlers monitoring for unauthorized visitors, known as "tailgaters," can be susceptible to bias. Over the past year, our global security and resilience team, in collaboration with a cross-functional working group, conducted extensive research and listened to the experiences of black googlers. Together, they developed and tested new security procedures to ensure the safety and security of the Google community without relying on this type of enforcement. As we prepare to return to the office, we will no longer require googlers to check each other's badges and will instead rely on our already robust security infrastructure.

These commitments demonstrate Google's unwavering dedication to creating a more equitable and inclusive environment. We recognize that there is still work to be done, and we are committed to making the necessary changes to better support our black+ community and all of our googlers. We believe that by implementing these actions, we can create a more just and inclusive society that benefits everyone. END

In water-scarce regions like California, every drop of water is valuable. However, millions of gallons of water are wasted every year due to leaky toilets, a common but easily preventable cause. That's why we recently partnered with other organizations to fund a pilot project in Los Angeles. The project aims to install water-saving technology in three multifamily buildings, specifically targeting common leaks like toilets that continue to run water when not in use. These small leaks can really add up over time.

Our pilot project is making great progress and is on track to save 6.4 million gallons of water per year in the Los Angeles watershed, where we operate. This supports our commitment to replenish 120% of the water we consume across our offices and data centers by 2030. We are proud to be working with partners from the California Water Action Collaborative (CWAC), a network of over 25 organizations, including private companies like Google, as well as environmental NGOs and nonprofits. Together, we are dedicated to improving water security across the state.

Let's take a closer look at how this project is making a difference. The Los Angeles Department of Water and Power estimates that the average household loses up to 10,000 gallons of water each year due to unnoticed leaks in toilets. The good news is that although these leaks can be difficult to detect, they are actually quite easy to fix.

For our pilot project, CWAC members Pacific Institute and Bonneville Environmental Foundation tackled this challenge in three low-income multifamily housing buildings operated by nonprofit organizations. They worked alongside the Metropolitan Water District of Southern California and other local water utilities. Toilets in these buildings were equipped with small, low-cost, low-power sensors developed by Sensor Industries. When a toilet leaks, the sensors immediately alert building management, who can then arrange for repairs. Usually, the fix is as simple as readjusting or replacing the toilet flapper.

This simple intervention has led to significant savings in water, money, and energy, as estimated by the Pacific Institute. First, the pilot is reducing building water use by an estimated 15% to 25%. The expected savings of 6.4 million gallons of water per year is equivalent to the total annual water use of about 40 single-family homes. These savings also benefit other customers who rely on the same public utility, as it reduces overall water demand and improves water reliability and affordability across the system.

Second, the water savings also translate into cost savings on water and wastewater bills of 15% to 25%. This amounts to tens of thousands of dollars saved each year, which the nonprofit building operators can use to make necessary improvements. Essentially, they can pass these savings along to the residents.

Lastly, by reducing the demand for water that is imported from distant sources, the project also helps to cut back on energy consumption and associated greenhouse gas emissions. In Southern California, it requires a significant amount of energy to pump water over the mountains surrounding the L.A. basin and treat it for household use. Therefore, by reducing the demand for this water, we are also reducing energy consumption.

In addition to these savings, there are other advantages to this approach. Residents don't have to do anything as the non-invasive system detects problems and notifies the building management. Facility managers can quickly identify the cause of the leak, such as a stuck flapper, which helps them fix it faster. This means less time wasted on tracking down leaks and more time focused on addressing more urgent issues.

Overall, this pilot project is making a significant impact in saving water, money, and energy. It highlights the potential for collective action models to address the rising water challenges we face. By working together with various organizations and utilizing innovative technology, we can make a real difference in water conservation and create a more sustainable future. END

At Spotify, our Community Experience team, known as CommunityX, strives to foster connections among our employees. By building a robust web of connections, we strengthen the fabric of our culture, ensuring its endurance even during challenging times or potential storms.

Last week, Walmart Inc. CEO Doug McMillon had the pleasure of attending the grand opening of a state-of-the-art green hydrogen plant at Walmart's Quilicura distribution center in Santiago, Chile. This exciting project exemplifies our ongoing dedication to renewable energy and marks a significant step forward for Walmart Chile in achieving our goal of net-zero emissions.

This groundbreaking plant, developed in collaboration with Engie, is the first of its kind in Latin America. It's a testament to our commitment to sustainability and will play a crucial role in our journey towards becoming a regenerative and zero-emission company by 2040. We were honored to have esteemed guests like Walmart Chile CEO Cristián Barrientos, Chile Minister of Finance Mario Marcel, Chile Minister of Energy Diego Pardow, and Engie Chile Chief Corporate Affairs Officer Pablo Villarino join us for this momentous occasion.

We see tremendous potential in this green hydrogen technology and are eager to expand its use across all our distribution centers throughout the country. Our aim is for our logistics network to operate 100% with green hydrogen by 2025. We're already exploring its application in transportation and emergency services, where we have ongoing pilot programs.

In its initial stage, the green hydrogen plant will enable the Quilicura distribution center to replace the lead-acid batteries of 200 forklift cranes with hydrogen energy cells. This switch will eliminate 250 tons of toxic waste annually. Over the course of the 15-year project, we expect it to reduce CO2 emissions by 17,100 tons, equivalent to planting 34,200 trees.

Our journey with hydrogen fuel began back in 2012 when we introduced a fleet of 50 vehicles and forklifts in the U.S. Since then, we've grown that number to over 9,500 forklifts. With over a decade of experience and progress, we're excited to invest in Chile's potential as a producer of clean energy and green hydrogen. The Chilean government's focus on renewable energy has resulted in significant growth in solar and wind power sectors, with up to 70% of their electrical grid projected to be renewable-powered by 2030. This presents a fantastic opportunity for Chile to develop a thriving green hydrogen industry powered by low-cost renewable resources and foster a sustainable economy.

Walmart has made substantial strides towards our climate goals by incorporating renewable sources through self-generation and the purchase of certified renewable energy. Currently, 84% of Walmart Chile's consumption comes from clean energy sources, and our 390+ facilities are well on track to achieve 100% renewable energy use even before our global commitment deadline of 2035. We are determined to become a regenerative company, one that leaves the world better than we found it.

The energy transition our world needs may be challenging, but by working together, we can achieve it. Walmart is proud to be at the forefront of this movement, and we will continue to make a positive impact on our environment and communities. END

1. Core inflation remained stubborn due to strong consumer demand, tight labor markets, and high inflation expectations.
2. Supply bottlenecks improved, and manufacturing slowed down as demand for goods weakened, but there was still strong demand for services.
3. Despite significant monetary policy tightening, underlying inflation pressures persisted, leading major central banks to signal the need for further tightening to address inflation.

The members discussed the stronger-than-expected economic activity in the United States, primarily driven by robust consumer spending. On the other hand, growth in the euro area stalled in the first half of 2023 due to weak consumer demand for goods and tighter monetary policy. However, the services sector remained robust, partly due to pent-up demand.

Slower global growth negatively impacted manufacturing and exports, while the Chinese property sector remained weak. The council agreed that the risk of global banking strains had diminished but was still present. Yields on government bonds in Europe and North America had increased, while overall equity prices had been stronger since June.

As for the Canadian economy, the council members reviewed the evidence and discussions from their previous decision in June. They focused on the dynamics of consumer spending and inflation. They concluded that the strength in consumer spending in the first quarter of 2023 could be attributed to several factors:

Good morning! I'm excited to be here today with Senior Deputy Governor Carolyn Rogers to discuss some important updates. We have made the decision to raise our policy interest rate by 25 basis points to 5%. Additionally, we will continue implementing our policy of quantitative tightening.

This decision is based on two important factors. Firstly, our monetary policy has been effective in combating inflation, but we are still facing some persistent inflationary pressures. While we have made significant progress in reducing consumer price index (CPI) inflation from its peak of 8.1% last summer to 3.4% in May, the underlying inflationary pressures have proven to be more stubborn than anticipated. Therefore, it is necessary to raise interest rates to slow down the growth of demand in the economy and relieve price pressures.

Secondly, we are carefully balancing the risks associated with tightening or loosening monetary policy. If we don't take sufficient action now, we may have to take more drastic measures later. On the other hand, if we tighten too much, it could unnecessarily burden everyone with difficult economic conditions. We have made significant progress thus far, and it is crucial that we continue on this path to restore price stability for Canadians.

Let me provide some further insight into our considerations and highlight a few key points from the governing council's discussions. Global economic growth has exceeded our expectations since the beginning of the year, mainly due to lower energy prices and smaller price increases for goods. However, we are still experiencing inflationary pressures in the services sector, driven by strong demand and tight labor markets. The bank predicts that global economic growth will be stronger this year compared to our initial projections in January and April. A similar trend is observed in Canada, where the economy has shown surprising strength and remains in a state of excess demand. Consumer spending on services continues to be robust, and while spending on goods sensitive to interest rates has slowed, it hasn't slowed down as much as we anticipated. The housing market has also seen an increase in activity.

Several factors contribute to this solid household spending. The labor market remains tight, with a historically low unemployment rate and wage growth between 4% and 5%, which is higher than what is consistent with price stability. Moreover, many households have been able to save during the COVID-19 pandemic, acting as a buffer and supporting consumer spending. It is worth noting that rapid population growth contributes to both supply and demand in the economy. Newcomers entering the labor force alleviate the labor shortage, but they also contribute to consumer spending and housing demand.

Regarding inflation, while CPI inflation has decreased relatively quickly, a large part of this decline can be attributed to lower energy prices and base-year effects as the significant price increases experienced last year are no longer factored into annual inflation. However, we continue to observe substantial price increases across a wide range of goods and services. Our measures of core inflation, which help us gauge underlying inflationary pressures, have decreased but not as much as we expected. Core inflation rates have remained around 3.5% to 4% since September, indicating limited downward momentum. Although consumer and business expectations for near-term inflation are moderating, they still remain high. Businesses are also reporting more frequent price increases compared to pre-pandemic levels.

Overall, we are taking necessary steps to address inflationary pressures and maintain stability in the economy. By carefully managing monetary policy and considering various factors, we aim to create a favorable environment for both consumers and businesses. END

This is a report on the discussions of the Bank of Canada's Governing Council leading up to their monetary policy decision on January 25, 2023. During this stage of the decision-making process, the Council reviewed all staff briefings and recommendations. The policy decision-making meetings began on January 18, with Governor Tiff Macklem presiding over the meetings. Other members in attendance included Senior Deputy Governor Carolyn Rogers, Deputy Governor Paul Beaudry, Deputy Governor Toni Gravelle, and Deputy Governor Sharon Kozicki.

The Council started by discussing recent international developments. They noted significant declines in global energy prices and ongoing improvements in global supply chains. They also discussed the lifting of COVID-19 restrictions in China. Overall, global economic activity, especially in the United States, the Euro area, and China, was slightly better than expected based on the October Monetary Policy Report.

Council members anticipated a slowdown in global growth for 2023 as pent-up demand subsides and higher interest rates begin to impact economic activity. Inflation, while still high, had started to decrease in many countries. The Council engaged in a detailed conversation about how market narratives regarding the global economy and inflation were shifting.

The Council reviewed the revised outlook for the United States. They observed that US consumers remained resilient, but growth was expected to be relatively flat in 2023. The labor market remained tight, and inflation was coming down due to lower energy prices. Signs of broader moderation in inflation were also becoming apparent. However, the ongoing debt ceiling negotiations posed a risk of financial volatility if an agreement could not be reached.

Regarding the Euro area, the Council saw signs of a mild recession, despite some unexpected resilience thus far. Uncertainty related to the Russian war in Ukraine continued to impact the region, and higher interest rates were affecting economic growth.

The Council devoted significant time to discussing the situation in China. They considered China's rapid shift in approach to COVID-19 as a new source of uncertainty. They also noted that there was an upside risk to oil prices if Chinese demand rebounded more than expected, which could put renewed pressure on Canadian and global inflation.

The Council reviewed financial conditions and observed that despite continued tightening by central banks, conditions had eased somewhat since October. This was likely due to a decline in risk premiums across various asset classes, driven by a decrease in headline inflation and a reduced perception of a deep recession. The Canadian dollar to US dollar exchange rate had remained fairly stable at around 74 cents.

The Council then turned to domestic economic developments in Canada and the outlook for inflation. They reviewed recent data, survey inputs, staff analysis, and projections. Canada's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) grew by 2.9% in the third quarter, surpassing the Bank's expectations. While household spending had softened, strength in commodity exports offset the decline. Data suggested that GDP growth in the fourth quarter would also be higher than previously projected. Despite the slowdown, there was more excess demand in the economy than anticipated.

The labor market continued to show tightness, with the December labor force survey reporting unexpectedly strong job gains. This, along with other indicators, indicated persistent tightness in the labor market, a sign of excess demand in the economy. The Council concluded that wage growth was plateauing within the range of 4% to 5%. However, they noted that sustained wage growth within this range would not align with achieving the 2% inflation target unless productivity increased significantly above historical trends. END

Inflation is on the decline, but there is still work to be done, according to Tiff Macklem, the Governor of the Bank of Canada, at a recent lunch in Kelowna. Macklem acknowledged that higher interest rates can be tough for Canadians, but emphasized that they are necessary to combat the potentially worse consequences of persistently high inflation. The Bank of Canada occasionally holds meetings outside of Ottawa to connect with different communities and understand their concerns. During the lunch, Macklem delivered a brief speech and engaged in a fireside chat with Carolyn Rogers, the Senior Deputy Governor, where they discussed various topics including the bank's response to the pandemic, confidence in Canadian and U.S. banks, and the future of digital currency.

Macklem acknowledged that inflation in Canada has reached levels not seen in almost four decades. Although inflation is decreasing, it still remains too high. Macklem addressed the recent decision to raise the policy rate by one-quarter of a percentage point, noting that it is the most rapid increase in interest rates in the country's history. However, he also emphasized that the impact of these rate increases takes time to ripple through the economy. The bank had taken a pause in January to assess whether the previous interest rate hikes had been effective in curbing inflation, but recent indicators suggest that the economy is still overheated. While headline inflation is decreasing, underlying inflation, which excludes volatile factors like food and energy prices, remains stubbornly high. Macklem expressed concern that the decline in inflation might stall, leading to the decision to raise interest rates once again. He remains optimistic that inflation will come down to around three percent this summer.

Unlike inflation, the Bank of Canada does not have a specific target rate for unemployment. However, Macklem explained that a well-balanced labor market is important in achieving their inflation target. When the labor market is tight and companies struggle to find workers, shortages occur, causing prices to rise and fueling inflation. Therefore, a reasonably healthy labor market is typically associated with inflation being close to the target rate.

While traditional industries like agriculture, forestry, mining, and manufacturing continue to be strong, Macklem highlighted the growing importance of the tech sector. Despite the positive developments and numerous opportunities, the area, like the rest of the country, faces challenges with labor shortages. Affordable housing is also a concern in Kelowna, but Macklem emphasized that this issue is not unique to the area. While the Bank of Canada considers the housing market in their monetary policy decisions, their main focus is on inflation when determining interest rates. END

This is a report on the discussions of the Bank of Canada's Governing Council leading up to the monetary policy decision on January 25, 2023. During this stage of the decision-making process, council members reviewed staff briefings and recommendations. The meetings, presided over by Governor Tiff Macklem, began on January 18 and included Senior Deputy Governor Carolyn Rogers, Deputy Governor Paul Beaudry, Deputy Governor Toni Gravelle, and Deputy Governor Sharon Kozicki.

The discussion started with an overview of recent international developments. Some highlights included the significant decline in global energy prices, the ongoing easing of global supply chain bottlenecks, and the sudden lifting of COVID-19 restrictions in China. Overall, global economic activity, particularly in the United States, the Euro area, and China, exceeded the bank's expectations from the October Monetary Policy Report (MPR). However, council members still anticipated a significant slowdown in global growth in 2023 as pent-up demand diminishes, and higher interest rates restrain activity. While inflation remained high and widespread, it had decreased from its peak in many countries. Council members also acknowledged a shift in market narratives regarding the global economy and inflation.

The council assessed the revised outlook for the United States and noted that while US consumers had shown resilience, growth was expected to be relatively flat in 2023. The labor market remained tight, and inflation was decreasing, mainly due to lower energy prices. Signs of broader moderation in inflation were also becoming apparent. However, the impending debt ceiling negotiations posed risks of financial volatility if an agreement could not be reached. The council continued to see the Euro area heading towards a mild recession, despite its surprising resilience thus far. Risks related to the Russian war in Ukraine contributed to uncertainty, and higher interest rates were affecting growth.

Considerable time was spent discussing the situation in China, particularly the sudden shift in their approach to COVID-19, which added a new source of uncertainty. The outlook for oil prices was identified as an upside risk due to China's reopening. If Chinese demand rebounded more than anticipated, oil prices could rise substantially, putting renewed upward pressure on Canadian and global inflation.

The council also reviewed financial conditions and observed that despite ongoing policy tightening by central banks, conditions had eased somewhat since October. This was attributed to a decline in risk premiums across various asset classes, as headline inflation had decreased and the perceived risk of a severe recession had diminished. The Canadian dollar to US dollar exchange rate remained relatively stable at around 74 cents.

When considering Canadian economic developments, the council examined recent domestic data, survey inputs, staff analysis, and projections. Canada's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) grew by 2.9% in the third quarter, surpassing the bank's expectations. Although household spending and housing activity were softer, the strength from commodity exports offset these declines. Furthermore, the data suggested that GDP growth in the fourth quarter would likely be higher than previously projected, indicating more excess demand in the economy than anticipated. The labor market continued to show tightness, with the December Labor Force Survey reporting unexpectedly strong job gains. This, along with other indicators, indicated that the tight labor market persisted, reflecting an economy still experiencing excess demand. The council concluded that wage momentum was stabilizing within the range of 4% to 5%. However, persistent wage growth within this range was not seen as consistent with achieving the 2% inflation target, unless productivity increased significantly above historical trends. END

Inflation is decreasing, but there is still work to be done. That was the message conveyed by Tiff Macklem, the Governor of the Bank of Canada, during a lunch in Kelowna last week. The event included community leaders and business people, providing an opportunity for Macklem to connect with the local community and understand their concerns.

Macklem acknowledged that higher interest rates can be challenging for Canadians. However, he emphasized that the monetary policy is effectively addressing the issue, albeit not as effortlessly or swiftly as desired. He explained that while higher interest rates may cause some discomfort, persistent high inflation would be far worse.

During the lunch, Macklem delivered a brief speech and engaged in a fireside chat with Carolyn Rogers, the Senior Deputy Governor at the Bank of Canada. They discussed various topics, including the bank's response to the pandemic, confidence in US and Canadian banks, and digital currency.

Macklem highlighted that inflation in Canada has reached levels unseen in almost 40 years. Although it is gradually decreasing, it remains too high. He also addressed the bank's recent decision to raise its policy rate by a quarter of a percentage point. He recognized that this was the most rapid increase in interest rates in history and acknowledged that it takes time for these higher rates to impact the economy.

The bank had paused rate increases in January to evaluate whether interest rates had been raised enough to bring inflation back to the two percent target. However, recent indicators have shown that the overheating economy has persisted more than expected. While headline inflation, which includes all factors, is decreasing, underlying inflation, which excludes volatile elements like food and energy prices, remains stubborn. Macklem expressed his disappointment, stating that it is not decreasing as much as anticipated. The economy is still overheated, and companies are struggling to find enough workers.

Macklem emphasized the risk of inflation decline stagnating and explained that this concern led to the decision to raise interest rates once again. However, he remains optimistic that inflation will decrease to around three percent this summer.

Unlike inflation, Macklem clarified that the Bank of Canada does not have a specific target rate for unemployment. However, they do consider the labor market when aiming to achieve their inflation target. A healthy labor market indicates balance, as tight labor markets lead to worker shortages and price increases, contributing to inflation. Typically, when inflation is close to the two percent target, the labor market is also reasonably healthy.

After the lunch, Macklem had a one-on-one discussion with the Daily Courier, where he shared his observations about the local economy. He recognized the significant immigration and the draw of the university campus, attracting young people to the central Okanagan region. He expressed admiration for the traditional strengths of the economy, such as agriculture, forestry, mining, and manufacturing. Additionally, he acknowledged the growing importance of the tech sector. However, he noted that the area, like the rest of the country, faces challenges with labor shortages. Affordable housing was also identified as an issue, although Macklem emphasized that it is not unique to Kelowna. While the Bank of Canada considers the housing market in monetary policy, their primary guide for interest rates is inflation. END

Canadian companies are taking significant action to address climate change by reducing their greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. RBC, for example, has set an ambitious goal to decrease its GHG emissions in its operations by 70% by 2025. One important step towards achieving this goal is sourcing 100% of its electricity from renewable and non-emitting sources like wind and solar power.

According to Julia-Maria Becker, Senior Manager of Sustainable Enterprise Operations at RBC, there are various ways they can accomplish this. However, investing in new renewable energy projects that directly contribute to Canada's energy transition is key. This is where power purchase agreements (PPAs) come into play. A PPA is a long-term contract with a renewable energy project owner to purchase energy at a fixed price from a solar or wind farm that is connected to the electrical grid. 

PPAs have had a significant impact on renewable energy development in North America, as stated by Grant Arnold, President and CEO of BluEarth Renewables. Corporate buyers like RBC have played a crucial role in driving the growth of renewables over the past five years. In 2020, RBC signed a PPA with BluEarth Renewables to support the construction of two new utility-scale solar farms in Alberta. They also signed a PPA in March 2022 with Berkshire Hathaway Energy Canada (BHE Canada) to aid in the development of the Rattlesnake Wind Power Project in Medicine Hat, Alberta. 

By entering into a PPA, the project owner gains greater certainty since the purchaser has agreed to a fixed price. This guarantee provides the confidence needed to proceed with construction. Chris Deakin, Manager of Corporate Development with BHE Canada, explains that PPAs help by providing income certainty, enabling necessary investments. As a renewables' developer, BHE Canada's strategy is to own and operate long-term projects that create a meaningful impact.

The benefits of PPAs are widespread. For RBC, they contribute to progress towards their climate goals by providing predictable access to renewable electricity while supporting the construction of renewable energy facilities in Canada. Deakin highlights that the benefit for energy consumers is the long-term predictable supply of electricity. Communities also reap advantages, including job creation during construction. The Bluearth Yellow Lake and Burdett Solar Project alone created over 300 new construction jobs, while BHE Canada's wind project provided approximately 150 new construction jobs at its peak. In the long term, these projects stimulate the local economy, with the partners estimating an injection of $200 million into Alberta's economy. 

In terms of climate impact, the clean electricity purchased by RBC from these projects is expected to prevent 41,200 tonnes of emissions each year. This is equivalent to approximately 680,000 tree seedlings grown for 10 years or 167 million fewer kilometers driven. Moreover, the advancement of these projects demonstrates that renewable energy is cost-competitive in an open market. PPAs also facilitate green investment in the Alberta economy. Contrary to popular belief, renewables have become more affordable, with wind power dropping 72% in price since 2009 and solar power decreasing by 90%, making it the cheapest form of new energy, according to the International Energy Agency's World Energy Outlook 2020. END

completion:
The ombudsman for the Department of National Defence and the Canadian Forces, Mr. Gary Walbourne, has released his report today on the treatment of army cadets affected by a tragic grenade explosion that occurred at a Canadian Forces base in Valcartier, Quebec, during a summer camp for cadets on July 30, 1974. Sadly, six cadets aged between 14 and 15 lost their lives, and many others were injured. The incident took place when inert explosive devices were being passed around the class, and a live grenade was accidentally mixed in. Despite the instructor's assurance that it was safe, the grenade exploded, causing devastation.

Immediate action was taken, and the victims were rushed to the base hospital. Those with more serious injuries were stabilized and then transported to nearby civilian hospitals. Alongside the tragic loss of life, one cadet was left permanently and totally disabled. Several others suffered permanent disabilities such as the loss of an eye, shrapnel wounds, loss of hearing, and psychological trauma. This incident prompted several investigations, including a coroner's report in 1975 that ruled the deaths of the six cadets were caused by negligence.

Background: The office of the ombudsman received its first complaint about this matter in April 2013, followed by an additional 51 complaints over a three-month period. These complaints mainly focused on issues such as access to medical care for long-term injuries, lack of support for those still suffering, recognition from the government of Canada, the need for a formal apology, and financial compensation.

The ombudsman's mandate does not cover events that occurred before June 15, 1998, unless the Minister of National Defence deems it in the public interest to investigate. However, due to the compelling issues and perceived discrepancies in treatment, the office recommended to the Minister of National Defence that a pre-mandate investigation be conducted. Former Minister Rob Nicholson agreed on May 5, 2014.

Objectives of the investigation: Our objective was twofold: to determine whether those present at the time of the explosion were treated fairly and compassionately based on the standards in place at that time, and to establish the present-day responsibility, if any, of the Department of National Defence and the Canadian Armed Forces toward the individuals affected by this tragic event.

Findings and recommendations: The ombudsman's office discovered that many of the cadets who survived the explosion continue to suffer from physical and psychological injuries. However, these cadets did not receive the same level of assistance as the military members who were also impacted by the incident. This discrepancy goes against the principle of fairness. The report states that the Canadian Forces and the Department of National Defence should have done more to help the young boys under their care. Therefore, it is recommended that, following a thorough assessment of the long-term needs of the affected individuals, the Department of National Defence, under the minister's guidance, provide them with immediate and reasonable financial compensation in line with similar situations in the legal system. This is essential to ensure they are treated in a manner that reflects Canadian values. END

completion:
Ottawa, July 11, 2023 - Mr. François Boileau, the taxpayers' ombudsperson, recently reached out to the Canada Revenue Agency (CRA) with a request for service improvements. He kindly asked them to update their processes and information on Canada.ca to ensure that taxpayer right 15 of the taxpayer bill of rights, "you have the right to be represented by a person of your choice," is respected.

At the recent Chartered Professional Accountants Forum North, we were made aware of concerns regarding the CRA's approach in their assisted compliance program. Upon examining their webpage, we discovered that some content was suggesting that Canadians should contact the CRA before reaching out to their tax preparer, who may also be their authorized representative. This could potentially create an issue, as taxpayers often rely on their representatives for tax planning and may not fully understand the intricate details themselves.

A similar issue was identified during our examination of the CRA's audit process for charities. We found that auditors were directed to contact a director of a charity instead of the authorized representative, even when previously informed to contact the representative for financial matters. While we understand that there may be instances where contacting the authorized representative is not the most efficient approach, such as with undisputed debt collection, it is crucial for the CRA to respect a taxpayer's request to contact their representative.

Therefore, in our service improvement request, we asked the CRA to update their publicly available information to remove any instances where they suggest that a taxpayer contact them first instead of their chosen representative. We are pleased to report that after receiving our request, the CRA promptly informed us that they were already in the process of updating their assisted compliance program webpage. We were delighted to see that the flagged content has been removed. However, we believe that the CRA shouldn't stop there and should continue to seek opportunities to enhance the ease of interaction between taxpayers and their representatives.

To provide some background, the office of the taxpayers' ombudsperson operates independently of the CRA. Canadians can submit complaints to our office if they feel they are not receiving appropriate service from the CRA. Our main goal is to improve the service provided by the CRA to taxpayers and benefit recipients. We achieve this by reviewing individual service complaints and addressing service issues that affect multiple people or specific segments of the population. As the ombudsperson, it is our duty to assist, advise, and inform the Minister of National Revenue on matters relating to the services provided by the CRA. We ensure that the CRA respects eight of the service rights outlined in the taxpayer bill of rights.

Overall, we are optimistic about the progress made in updating the CRA's assisted compliance program webpage. It is essential for the CRA to continue seeking ways to make interactions with taxpayers and their representatives easier. END

completion:
Low power wide area networks (LPWANs) are becoming increasingly popular for connecting numerous devices through the Internet of Things (IoT). These solutions offer several advantages over traditional mobile networks, including lower battery consumption and extended connectivity range. However, it's crucial to note that not all LPWAN technologies are equal. Let's take a closer look at the various services available and what factors to consider when selecting the right one for your business.

LPWAN Options: Unlicensed vs. Licensed
There are two main categories of LPWAN technologies. Unlicensed LPWANs operate on proprietary technologies that utilize unlicensed radio spectrum. This means that anyone can use the frequency. These networks are primarily designed for transmitting small messages in urban areas. On the other hand, licensed LPWANs, also known as Mobile IoT by the GSMA, use radio spectrum exclusively licensed to specific carriers. These networks adhere to international standards, enabling seamless and reliable connections across different networks. One example of a licensed LPWAN is LTE-M, which leverages the existing LTE infrastructure to provide extensive coverage.

Important Criteria to Consider
When selecting an LPWAN technology, organizations must ensure that it fully supports their IoT goals. Peter Wilcox, the Director of IoT and Business Solutions at Bell Canada, highlights four key criteria to consider:

1. Coverage: The distribution of your IoT devices plays a crucial role in determining the suitable technology. Do you require coverage over a limited or wide area? Are your devices located in challenging areas, such as underground or below ground? Are they stationary or mobile? If you don't need extensive coverage (e.g., less than 10 kilometers in urban areas) and your devices are easily reachable or mobile, an unlicensed LPWAN may be a cost-effective option. On the other hand, if you need to reach devices distributed across a wide area or in challenging locations like deep inside buildings or underground, LTE-M services are better suited. These makes licensed LPWANs ideal for smart city applications that monitor devices below ground, such as water pressure sensors. The transportation industry, which requires mobile asset tracking, should consider a licensed LTE-M service as it enables quick and seamless data transfer from moving vehicles.

2. Security: Data sensitivity is a crucial factor when choosing an LPWAN technology. Organizations should consider the level of sensitivity of the transmitted data in terms of both privacy and business importance. Unlicensed networks, like LoRa, offer two layers of security and encryption. However, they use shared frequencies and are susceptible to interference and attacks. If data sensitivity is a concern, licensed LTE-M networks ensure message integrity and only allow valid devices to communicate over the network, similar to current cellular networks.

3. Reliability: Does your IoT solution require fast or real-time data delivery? Not all applications necessitate high speed. For those that don't, an unlicensed network may suffice. Generally, unlicensed networks experience latency of up to 30 seconds compared to 50 milliseconds on LTE-M, as stated by Wilcox. LTE-M is better suited for mission-critical applications or those that require real-time information delivery. As Wilcox suggests, if a utility company needs to make a real-time decision based on sensor data, a licensed network may be the optimal choice.

4. Flexibility: Organizations should also consider the flexibility they might require in the future. Will there be a need for periodic software updates on the devices? Is adaptability to future technology trends, such as 5G, necessary? Unlicensed networks are based on proprietary technology and may be suitable for organizations that don't require a high degree of flexibility. Licensed networks, on the other hand, are standards-based and more suitable for organizations that prioritize flexibility. For example, Bell's 5G-ready LTE-M network allows remote software updates, which cannot be done on an unlicensed network.

By carefully considering these criteria, organizations can make an informed decision when selecting an LPWAN technology that aligns with their IoT goals and business requirements. END

This constant communication has numerous benefits, including ensuring accurate and timely deliveries, allowing for real-time re-routing based on changing road conditions, and contributing to regulatory compliance. The report titled "Canada's Energy Future 2023 Energy Supply and Demand Projections to 2050" presents three scenarios: global net-zero, Canada net-zero, and current measures. Each scenario reflects the pace of climate action in Canada and globally, with two specifically aimed at achieving net-zero greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions in Canada by 2050.

To meet the increased electricity demand, Canada would generate more clean electricity from sources like wind, nuclear, and hydro. Additionally, global climate action would impact global demand and prices for oil and gas, leading to a decline in production in Canada by 2050, especially in the global net-zero scenario.

However, fossil fuels would still have a role in Canada's energy system, particularly in industrial facilities equipped with CCUS or for non-energy purposes like asphalt and petrochemicals. Achieving net-zero emissions would require significant contributions from all sectors, with the largest reductions expected in the transportation, electricity, and oil and gas sectors.
