At Shopify, we are dedicated to making a positive impact on our planet by reversing climate change. We understand that simply stopping emissions is not enough, as there is still an excessive amount of carbon in the atmosphere. It is clear that no single solution can solve this problem alone. That's why we recognize the need to further develop and scale carbon removal technologies.

Since the launch of our sustainability fund in 2019, Shopify has been actively investing in carbon removal as a way to support and nurture a growing industry. Today, we are thrilled to announce that, in partnership with Stripe, we are purchasing $11 million worth of carbon removal from six new companies: Arbor, Captura, Carbon to Stone, Cella, Crew, and Inplanet. This is an exciting development in our ongoing fight against climate change, and we are inspired by the caliber and rapid growth of these new companies entering the market. Through our purchases, we are providing them with the opportunity to showcase their impact and expand their operations. With these additions, a total of 28 companies are now backed by Shopify.

These recent purchases are just a part of our commitment to accelerate the market for carbon removal. In 2022, Shopify's sustainability fund made significant progress by adding nine new businesses to our portfolio. Our investments have helped these companies bring their innovative solutions to market and drive widespread adoption. Through our fund activities, we have facilitated over $50 million in capital raising for multiple companies, resulting in a fivefold increase in their employee count. This growth has enabled them to expand their carbon removal capacity by more than 1000 times.

Another key initiative we launched this year is Frontier, an advanced market commitment (AMC) in partnership with Stripe, Alphabet, Meta, and McKinsey Sustainability. As founders of Frontier, we have pledged to spend a combined $925 million on carbon removal by 2030. This commitment sends a strong signal to innovators, investors, and project developers that there is a market for carbon removal, and it is crucial for all of us to work together to scale the industry.

In June, we introduced Shopify Planet, an app that allows our merchants to offset their shipping emissions. Planet calculates the estimated shipping emissions for each order, and merchants have the option to fund carbon removal projects supported by Shopify to neutralize these emissions. Since its launch, over 8,000 Shopify merchants have used Planet to offset shipping emissions on more than six million orders, resulting in over 5,000 tonnes of carbon removal.

We also understand that supporting carbon removal can be challenging for some individuals and businesses. That's why we recently published "Buying Carbon Removal, Explained," a comprehensive guide that provides assistance to anyone interested in supporting carbon removal but facing obstacles along the way. This guide covers everything from researching suppliers to negotiating carbon removal contracts and addressing concerns from finance teams. We are committed to creating demand for carbon removal, helping new companies prove their impact and scale, and investing millions of dollars each year to drive down future prices.

I had the privilege of speaking about these initiatives at the TED Countdown London session. If you're interested, you can watch my talk at go.ted.com/stacykauk.

That's all for now. Don't forget to subscribe to our mailing list for updates from us in 2023. We have even more exciting plans in store for the coming year as we continue our mission to create a sustainable future. END

We continuously evaluate and enhance the accessibility of our products to provide a seamless banking experience for everyone. Our goal is to ensure that all our customers can access barrier-free banking with dignity and independence.

Our aim is to prioritize the needs of people with disabilities and ensure that they are at the center of our decision-making process.

We encourage customers, shareholders, and community members to review our accessibility plan and provide feedback through our accessibility feedback process. At Scotiabank, we strive to create an inclusive workplace where employees with disabilities are respected and can flourish. Our ultimate aim is to increase the representation of people with disabilities by 20% by 2025. END

Air Canada has successfully brought over one thousand Canadians back home safely from Maui after the devastating wildfires on the island. As local authorities advised against visitors coming to Maui, we canceled our outbound flights and instead operated a ferry flight down with no passengers onboard. Our flights back to Toronto were then scheduled as regular flights on the wide-body aircraft, allowing us to bring back as many passengers as possible.

Today, the Taxpayers' Ombudsperson, Mr. François Boileau, has released a report called "Charity Begins with Fairness: More to Explore." This report was created in response to a request from Minister Diane Lebouthillier, the Minister of National Revenue, following the Government of Canada's National Summit on Islamophobia in August 2021. The Minister asked the Ombudsperson to look into concerns raised by certain Muslim-led charities and engage with other registered charities led by racialized communities to learn about their experiences with the Canada Revenue Agency (CRA). The report also clarifies the CRA's role in national security.

In line with our commitment to independence, we took the time to listen to all perspectives, deepen our understanding, examine the facts, and identify areas where the CRA can improve its service to Canadians. To ensure a comprehensive examination, we met with various stakeholders, including charities, experts, CRA employees and executives, lawyers from the Department of Justice Canada, and academics.

Although we faced some legislative and administrative obstacles that limited our access to necessary information, we firmly believe that this report highlights opportunities for the CRA to enhance its service to charities. While we were unable to conduct a full examination, we did identify one crucial area for improvement. Recognizing the impact of bias, the Taxpayers' Ombudsperson recommends that the CRA:

1. Develop an unconscious bias training course for employees in the Charities Directorate.
2. Focus this training on those involved in the audit process.
3. Make this training mandatory for all employees involved in the audit process, including decision makers.

It is important to note that the Office of the Taxpayers' Ombudsperson operates independently of the CRA. Canadians can submit complaints to our office if they believe they are not receiving appropriate service from the CRA. Our main objective is to improve the service provided by the CRA to taxpayers and benefit recipients. We accomplish this by reviewing individual service complaints and addressing systemic service issues that affect multiple individuals or specific segments of the population.

As the Taxpayers' Ombudsperson, we work to assist, advise, and inform the Minister of National Revenue on matters related to CRA services. We specifically ensure that the CRA upholds eight service rights outlined in the Taxpayer Bill of Rights.

If you would like to learn more about our ongoing examinations, please visit our website at [insert website link]. END

In the 1990s, I had a casual meeting with a senior civil servant in Alberta. It's important to maintain positive relationships with frequent contacts, and on this particular occasion, he didn't seem too thrilled to see me. I noticed smoke coming from his desk, even though just a few months prior, the provincial government had prohibited smoking in enclosed offices for civil servants. Just as an investigator from the ombudsman's office approached, he quickly hid his ashtray and cigarette in his desk drawer. We both found the situation amusing when we got caught. I was relieved that our relationship remained intact.

As an investigator for the Alberta ombudsman, I expected to be treated professionally and with respect. Building good relationships was crucial for me to fulfill the ombudsman's mission of promoting fair treatment in the public sector. The ombudsman, an independent officer of the legislative assembly, investigates complaints of unfair treatment in the delivery of public services. Back then, senior civil servants were mostly men, and female investigators like me were rare. The most common hire was a retired policeman over the age of 50. When I joined at 34, one of my new colleagues warned me that I was too young for the job. Older investigators were preferred because they were seen as experienced and credible when dealing with a civil service that often operated without strict rules.

Even in the "real world," achieving goals often meant adopting practical approaches rather than strictly following policies. However, things have thankfully changed since then. In the 1990s, I interviewed two civil servants who made decisions that seemed unfair based on common sense. When I asked if they had policies to guide their decisions, they had to consult with a superior. They eventually reassured me that the department did have policies but couldn't show them to me at the time because the policy book was in Calgary. Basic concepts were often overlooked back then. I recall one regional manager in social assistance who had a sign on his wall stating, "In this office, 'no' is a complete sentence." Looking back from 2022, I'm embarrassed to admit that I didn't object. I understood that the sign was condescending and sent the wrong message to staff and clients, but I didn't yet have the vocabulary or awareness of fairness principles to speak up.

After 36 years of advocating for administrative fairness, I can confidently say that all decisions are subject to review, and a simple "no" is never sufficient. The more significant a decision, the more important it is to explain how the outcome was reached based on the facts of the case and relevant legislation and policy. Even expert-led boards can sometimes fail to provide adequate reasons for their decisions. A typical decision might conclude with "based on the evidence above, the benefit is denied." But what evidence exactly? The list of evidence may include some supporting the appellant and others supporting the government. Readers shouldn't be expected to guess what the panel deemed important and why. Thankfully, improvements have been made. Hiring practices are more inclusive, and the creation and adherence to policy are now essential practices. In the era of open government, many policies are published online. New hires receive proper training instead of being thrown into the deep end. The advancement of technology, particularly in the last 15 years, was inevitable. Decisions that used to take days or weeks can now be made instantly. However, we must balance the benefits of automation with the challenges it brings. No computer program can exercise discretion, and it has become harder than ever for Albertans to receive personal advice and review when denied services. Sometimes, template computer responses just aren't enough. END

At P&G, we're committed to creating a company and a world where everyone has equal opportunities and is respected and included. That's why we've introduced our Equality & Inclusion Action Plan in Canada, with the goal of representing the diversity of Canada at every level by 2025. We want to increase indigenous, black, and French representation within our company.

Currently, we recognize that indigenous peoples (First Nations, Inuit, and Métis) make up almost 5% of the Canadian population, but none of our P&G Canada employees self-identify as indigenous, and we don't have any employee affinity groups specifically representing them. However, we're taking steps to change that.

In May 2021, we launched the Indigenous Professional Network (IPN) as part of our Canadian Equality & Inclusion Action Plan. Our mission is to support P&G in fulfilling the Truth and Reconciliation Commission's Call to Action #92, which calls on companies to foster respectful relationships, support economic opportunities, build representation, and create an inclusive workplace for indigenous peoples.

So far, our actions have focused on three key areas: community engagement, employee awareness, and recruiting.

In terms of community engagement, we're proud to partner with Indigenous Works, a non-profit organization dedicated to increasing indigenous engagement in the Canadian economy. They've been helping us develop our workplace employment and inclusion strategies. We've also donated $100,000 to GlobalMedic, our long-standing partner, to distribute P&G hygiene kits to indigenous communities that have been disproportionately impacted by COVID-19. To raise employee awareness, we organized a Canada-wide speaker event on National Indigenous People's Day, featuring Dr. Lana Potts, an advocate for indigenous health. We also held a film screening of "We Were Children" followed by discussions to shed light on the intergenerational harm caused by the legacy of the residential school system. In December, we published a list of indigenous-owned charities and organizations where employees could donate their time and money.

In terms of recruiting, we launched the Indigenous Student Internship program nationally, partnering with over 7 campuses to drive awareness and applications. We're proud to say that we've recruited 2 indigenous interns, a first-ever for P&G Canada. Additionally, we've developed a partnership with the University of British Columbia for consultation on job postings and campus recruitment strategies. We were also the spotlight session sponsor for Indspire's "Soaring Indigenous Youth Empowerment Gathering," reaching over 900 high school students and teachers across Canada.

We're encouraged by the positive response from our employees, with over 150 Canadians attending our events and discussions. Furthermore, we're excited to continue our efforts to create a more inclusive and diverse workplace at P&G Canada, where everyone has equal access to learn, grow, succeed, and thrive. END

Water scarcity is a global issue that affects every continent. While some people may not see its impact in their own communities, others are facing extreme water stress. In fact, almost one-third of people already live in water-stressed regions, and this number is expected to rise to two-thirds of the global population by 2025. 

We are excited to announce a major expansion to our ambition 2030 sustainability efforts, focusing on climate, nature, waste, and water. As part of this extended effort, we aim to make more water available in water-stressed areas around the world. We have developed a global portfolio of water restoration projects that will offer various solutions to protect ecosystems, replenish groundwater supplies, reduce water diversion, and improve water quality for communities and wildlife that rely on them.

Water is a vital natural resource, yet it is often taken for granted. For years, we have been dedicated to reducing water use in our operations and creating innovative solutions to help consumers use less water at home. However, there is still much more we can all do. Together with our partners, we are expanding our efforts to improve, manage, and protect water resources in stressed areas, ensuring a sustainable future for generations to come.

To demonstrate the significance of our commitment, we have set a first-of-its-kind goal to restore more water than is consumed when using our products in the water-stressed metropolitan areas of Los Angeles and Mexico City. Our strategy focuses on reducing water use in manufacturing, addressing water challenges through innovation and partnerships, and supporting projects in 18 water-stressed areas worldwide, including new projects announced today.

In addition to our existing comprehensive program, we have added two new goals to our agenda. We will achieve these goals through partnerships with organizations and restoration projects that improve, manage, and protect water resources. These goals specifically target the water that does not return to local systems from our operations and, for the first time in our industry, from consumer use of our products. We have collaborated with the World Resources Institute (WRI) Water Program to ensure that our targets align with the best science and practices in setting water goals.

Our focus on making a greater impact continues with the announcement of six new restoration projects in the Bear River Basin in Utah and Idaho. These projects, in partnership with the Bonneville Environmental Foundation's (BEF) Business for Water Stewardship, aim to restore natural habitats, improve water quality, preserve cultural history, and enhance irrigation efficiency for local communities and important wetland habitats in the western United States. These projects complement the eight projects we started supporting in 2020 in California's Sacramento River Basin and the Colorado River Indian Tribes (CRIT) System Conservation Project in Arizona, which help mitigate declining water levels in Lake Mead. By 2030, these combined projects are expected to restore billions of liters of water for people and nature and provide other significant benefits to the surrounding communities.

In the years to come, we will continue to collaborate with new and existing partners to support a diverse portfolio of long-term projects in other water-stressed areas globally. These projects will focus on improving, managing, and protecting water resources, ensuring a sustainable and water-positive future. END

We see ourselves as a force for good and growth by reducing our impact across our business, offering superior products that are both sustainable and high-performing, and partnering with others to tackle the challenges we face today.

Do you have an old mattress lying around your house? Maybe you upgraded to a fancier, comfier option and left your old one gathering dust in the corner of your bedroom. Or perhaps you're moving and can't take your mattress with you. Whatever the reason, the decision to dispose of your old mattress may seem like a straightforward choice. But hold on a minute - did you know that mattresses are one of the most difficult items to properly get rid of?

There's a lot that goes into recycling a mattress, and as the experts in junk removal, we're here to help answer any questions you may have. Let's explore why it's so important to recycle your old mattress and the benefits that come from doing so.

Did you know that mattresses take up a lot of space in landfills? In fact, they're one of the bulkiest items, with the average mattress taking up to 40 cubic feet of space. With millions of mattresses being thrown away every year, it's crucial that we find ways to recycle them and keep them out of landfills. When you recycle your mattress, it not only helps with landfill overcrowding but also reduces associated costs like transportation and disposal fees.

A mattress can take anywhere from 80 to 120 years to decompose, which means that a mattress you throw away today will continue to impact future generations. Some materials used to make mattresses can be toxic and pollute soil and groundwater, having a long-lasting impact on the planet. Mattresses are made of various materials like foam, cotton, and synthetic fabrics. When these materials break down over time, they can release toxins into the environment. In landfills, these toxins can seep into the ground and eventually contaminate the soil and water. Recycling and upcycling mattress materials can prevent these toxins from being released and reduce the risk of contamination.

Recycling your old mattress may seem like an extra expense you could do without, but in the long run, it can be a cost-effective choice. Disposing of a mattress in a dump often incurs a fee, and some cities even fine residents who leave their mattresses out for curbside pickup. On the other hand, many recycling centers will take your mattress for free or for a small fee. Additionally, when mattresses are recycled, the materials can be repurposed into new products, saving on resources and energy.

The good news is that mattresses can be recycled! In fact, more than 80% of mattress materials are recyclable, which means that very little goes to waste. For example, the foam in a mattress can be broken down and used for making new furniture or insulation for homes. The metal springs can be melted down and turned into other items like car parts or even jewelry. The wooden frames can be used as firewood or shredded to produce landscaping mulch. Additionally, fabrics from old mattresses can be shredded and turned into stuffing for pillows or blankets.

As you choose to recycle your mattress, not only are you keeping waste out of landfills, but you're also contributing to a more sustainable future. The mattress recycling industry is growing, which means there are more job opportunities for people looking for work. Recycling mattresses requires skilled workers who can dismantle and sort the materials. Recycling centers are often staffed by people who take apart old mattresses and separate out any reusable materials for resale or donation. The growth of these facilities means that there will be more demand for workers with these skills, which is good news for the economy. END

Scientists have made significant discoveries about nicotine addiction and its connection to brain development and behavior in early life. Smoking is a widespread addictive behavior that unfortunately leads to many adult deaths. In a new study conducted by researchers from the universities of Cambridge and Warwick in the UK, as well as Fudan University in China, brain imaging and behavioral data from over 800 young people were analyzed at the ages of 14, 19, and 23.

The findings showcased that teenagers who started smoking by the age of 14 had less gray matter in a specific area of the brain associated with decision-making and rule-breaking. Gray matter is the brain tissue responsible for processing information and contains all the organ's neurons. It is worth noting that gray matter growth peaks before adolescence, although brain development continues into adulthood. Researchers believe that low gray matter volume on the left side of the ventromedial prefrontal cortex could be an inheritable indicator for nicotine addiction, which has important implications for prevention and treatment.

Furthermore, the study revealed that smokers also had less gray matter in the right part of the same brain region. Importantly, the decrease in gray matter in the right prefrontal cortex only occurred after individuals started smoking and is associated with the pursuit of sensations. The research team suggests that reduced gray matter in the left frontal lobe may impair cognitive function and lead to impulsive behavior, making individuals more likely to start smoking at a young age. Additionally, once nicotine addiction takes hold, gray matter in the right frontal lobe diminishes, potentially weakening the ability to control smoking due to the impact on hedonic motivation, which relates to seeking and managing pleasure. Excessive loss of gray matter in the right brain was also linked to binge-drinking and marijuana use.

Overall, these findings indicate a disrupted "neurobehavioral mechanism" that can prompt early nicotine use and long-term addiction. The study utilized data from the Imagen project and has been published in the journal Nature Communications. Professor Trevor Robbins, co-senior author from Cambridge's Department of Psychology, highlighted the importance of addressing smoking as a leading cause of adult mortality globally. Every year, smoking-related deaths are estimated to reach eight million worldwide, with one in five adult deaths in the US alone attributed to smoking.

The study's results provide valuable insights into the relationship between reduced gray matter in the left prefrontal cortex, rule-breaking behavior, and early smoking experiences. It is possible that this propensity for breaking rules contributes to violations of anti-smoking norms. Professor Barbara Sahakian, co-author from Cambridge's Department of Psychiatry, emphasized that the ventromedial prefrontal cortex plays a crucial role in dopamine, the brain's pleasure chemical. Dopamine not only affects rewarding experiences but has long been thought to influence self-control. Less gray matter in this region of the brain could compromise cognitive function, leading to reduced self-control and a higher likelihood of engaging in risky behaviors such as smoking.

The study utilized data from multiple European countries, including the UK, Germany, France, and Ireland. By comparing brain imaging data between individuals who started smoking by age 14 and those who did not, the researchers discovered a significant difference in gray matter volume in the left prefrontal cortex. Additionally, those who began smoking by age 19 also exhibited reduced gray matter in this area at age 14, indicating a potential causal influence.

In summary, this study sheds light on the connection between brain development, gray matter volume, and nicotine addiction. By understanding these underlying mechanisms, we can work towards effective prevention and treatment strategies. It is crucial to address smoking as a global health concern, as its impact on mortality rates is substantial. END

Researchers from the University of Cambridge have discovered a potentially groundbreaking method for detecting and measuring dark energy. By studying the movement of Andromeda, our neighboring galaxy that is slowly approaching the Milky Way, the researchers have found a way to place an upper limit on the value of the cosmological constant, which is a model of dark energy. This upper limit is five times higher than what can be detected from studying distant galaxies. Although this technique is still in the early stages, it shows promise for detecting dark energy in our own cosmic neighborhood. The results of this study have been reported in the Astrophysical Journal Letters.

Dark energy is a mysterious force that scientists believe makes up 68% of the universe. It is different from dark matter, which holds objects together. Dark energy, on the other hand, pushes objects apart. The simplest model of dark energy is known as the cosmological constant, which was added to Einstein's theory of gravity by him himself. Initially set at zero, it was later discovered that an unknown force, now known as dark energy, was causing the universe to expand at an accelerated rate.

There are two major challenges when it comes to dark energy. Firstly, we don't know exactly what it is, and secondly, we haven't directly detected it. Astronomers have developed various methods to detect dark energy, most of which involve studying objects from the early universe and measuring their movement away from us. However, due to the weak force of dark energy between galaxies, it is easily overshadowed by the stronger forces within galaxies, making it difficult to study its effects.

However, there is one exception. Andromeda, the closest galaxy to the Milky Way, is on a collision course with our galaxy. As the two galaxies draw closer, they will begin to orbit each other at an incredibly slow pace. This orbit will take a staggering 20 billion years to complete. But even before a single orbit is finished, approximately five billion years from now, the two galaxies will start merging and falling into each other.

Andromeda's unique proximity to us makes it an ideal subject for studying dark energy. By analyzing its mass and movement, we may be able to gain valuable insights into the cosmological constant and dark energy. This research has been conducted by Dr. David Benisty from the Department of Applied Mathematics and Theoretical Physics, along with professors Anne Davis and Wyn Evans. They used simulations based on the best estimates of the galaxies' mass and found evidence that dark energy is indeed affecting how Andromeda and the Milky Way orbit each other.

In conclusion, this study brings us one step closer to understanding dark energy and its role in the universe. By focusing on our cosmic neighbor, Andromeda, researchers have made significant progress in detecting and measuring dark energy. Although there is still much to learn, this discovery opens up new possibilities for unraveling the mysteries of our universe. END

Substance use had a significant impact on the Canadian economy in 2020, costing a total of $49.1 billion. This represents an increase of over $11 billion since 2007, or nearly 12% in per-person costs. These findings come from the Canadian Substance Use Costs and Harms (CSUCH) 2007-2020 report, which was released today by the Canadian Centre on Substance Use and Addiction (CCSA) in partnership with the University of Victoria's Canadian Institute for Substance Use Research (CISUR).

One of the key findings is that lost productivity alone accounted for $22.4 billion of the total costs in 2020, equivalent to $589 per person. This includes the value of work lost due to premature deaths and both long- and short-term disability. Dr. Adam Sherk, a scientist at CISUR and a researcher for the study, emphasizes that substance use is not solely a healthcare issue. He suggests that employers can support their employees by implementing supportive substance use policies and investing in prevention, harm reduction, and treatment programs.

The report categorizes substance use costs into four key areas. In addition to lost productivity (45.6% of total costs), healthcare costs amounted to $13.4 billion (27.4%). Criminal justice costs were $10 billion (20.3%), while other direct costs contributed $3.3 billion (6.7%). These figures highlight how substance use issues permeate various aspects of our daily lives and emphasize the need for solutions to address them.

Other noteworthy findings from the report include:

1. Alcohol accounted for just over 40% of the total costs at $19.7 billion.
2. The costs of alcohol and tobacco use have diverged over time, with alcohol use costs increasing by 21% and per-person costs of tobacco use declining by 20%.
3. Opioid use cost $7.1 billion in 2020, the highest of any year examined. The majority of these costs (nearly 75%) were related to lost productivity and premature deaths caused by opioid use.
4. The per-person cost of substance use increased by 11.8%, from $1,154 in 2007 to $1,291 in 2020.
5. The per-person costs of opioids and stimulants saw the highest increase among all substances since 2007, reflecting the increasingly toxic unregulated drug supply and the associated harms.
6. The per-person cost of cannabis decreased by 9.1% between 2018 and 2020 following its legalization for recreational use. This decrease is primarily due to reduced criminal justice costs.

Emily Biggar, a CCSA research and policy analyst and researcher on the project, notes that there were nearly 74,000 deaths due to substance use in 2020, averaging nearly 200 lives lost each day. Alcohol and tobacco alone accounted for over 85% of these deaths. She emphasizes that these estimates demonstrate how substance use not only affects healthcare and the criminal justice system but also hinders people's ability to work and contribute to the economy. Initiatives targeting prevention, harm reduction, and treatment are crucial to improving the health and productivity of Canadians.

This report is the third update in the Canadian Substance Use Costs and Harms project, following releases in 2018 and 2020. CCSA and CISUR developed the CSUCH report to gain a better understanding of the economic costs and harms associated with substance use in Canada. These regularly updated estimates can guide the development of relevant public policies, initiatives to address substance use harms, identification of information gaps, research needs, refinements to national data reporting systems, and ultimately, changes in policy and societal responses to substance use. END

completion:
Canada's veterans often suffer physical or mental injuries due to their service, and sometimes both. In recent years, medical cannabis has become a topic of great interest for veterans and their families as a potential treatment option. In 2022, more than 18,000 veterans were reimbursed for medical cannabis based on recommendations from their healthcare providers through Veterans Affairs Canada.

A new report titled "Insights into Veteran and Veteran Family Experiences with Cannabis and Mental Health" has been released by the Atlas Institute for Veterans and Families and the Mental Health Commission of Canada. This report summarizes conversations from a dialogue series held in May and June 2022, involving veterans, family members, service providers, and researchers. The discussions focused on their experiences and perspectives on cannabis use and mental health.

The report discovered a strong interest among veterans and their families in exploring cannabis as a potential treatment for conditions like post-traumatic stress disorder. They also expressed a desire for more research and guidance on cannabis use and mental health. Retired Major-General Glynne Hines, Chair of the Atlas Institute's Veterans Reference Group, and project advisor and moderator for the dialogue series, said, "As one of the approved veterans using medical cannabis, I was eager to participate in this collaborative project. Our knowledge of cannabis is mostly based on personal experiences, and we lack the necessary scientific research to make informed decisions on how it may impact our other treatments."

The report also highlighted several important insights:

1. Health-care professionals need more training and guidance on cannabis use for mental health.
2. There is still a significant stigma surrounding cannabis use among veterans.
3. Veterans need more information on how cannabis interacts with other substances and how it works.
4. The quality and independence of cannabis research are crucial, and veterans and their families want to be involved in the research process.
5. Knowledge, resources, and actions should consider the diversity within the veteran population.

Fardous Hosseiny, President and CEO of the Atlas Institute, acknowledged the potential of cannabis as a tool for managing mental health conditions but emphasized the need for further research on its efficacy, impacts, and best practices for veterans in Canada. He stated, "This dialogue series revealed that cannabis is a significant topic of interest. We need more research, resources, and guidance not only for veterans and their families but also for the service providers who work with them. This way, we can collectively make well-informed decisions regarding the use of medical cannabis."

Mary Bartram, Policy Director at the Mental Health Commission of Canada, agreed that this project highlighted the need for more nuanced research. She stated, "To honor the diverse experiences of veterans and their families and bridge the knowledge gaps between users and healthcare providers, we must continue to promote evidence-based research in collaboration with the veteran community." END

Mission-critical networks are the foundation of infrastructure that supports the essential functions and services of various organizations, from hospitals and first responders to power grids and air traffic control. They provide built-in redundancy, so if one route fails, data can still be moved to another, ensuring it reaches its destination. Integrated alerts help resolve issues with minimal downtime. Fiber optics, with their high capacity, resilience, and secure transmission foundation, are ideal for connected industry 4.0 infrastructure, including robotics and safety mechanisms in hazardous environments.

By leveraging modern networks and technologies, organizations can ensure resilience and security while embracing valuable applications that enhance their operations. END

Did you know that women make up 50% of the population and have had the right to vote for over 110 years? It's amazing to see how far we've come, but did you also know that it's estimated to take another 132 years to achieve full gender equality? That's a long time, and we can't wait that long to close the gender gap.

Imagine you're starting your own travel business, and you want to understand what your customers really want. Your friend John offers to help by doing some market research. After two weeks, he comes back with some interesting findings - there's a huge demand for physically demanding adventure holidays. But wait, you realize that John only spoke to his male friends at the rugby and golf club. He didn't even talk to your female friend Jane, who could have provided valuable insights. Would you base your business decisions solely on information from one specific group? Of course not! It wouldn't make sense to rely on such limited perspectives.

Unfortunately, this is exactly what many businesses and governments do every day. Our society and businesses are still predominantly male-dominated and built around a standard that favors men's attributes. This can lead to situations where women are at a disadvantage, like in car accidents. Even though women statistically have lower accident rates, they are 50% more likely to die in a crash because safety measures are often designed with men in mind. It's shocking to think that female crash test dummies were only introduced in 2011!

These imbalances and biases make it more challenging for women to thrive. The World Economic Forum's Global Gender Gap Index measures progress towards gender equality in various areas, including economic participation, education, health, and political empowerment. While progress is being made, it's projected to take another 132 years to achieve full gender parity. That's why it's crucial for us to take action now.

One area where gender inequality persists is in pay. Despite equal pay laws, women are still paid less than equally qualified male colleagues doing the same job. In the US, the average gender pay gap is 10%, while it's 13% in the EU and 15% in India. This is partly due to the underrepresentation of women in senior leadership positions and the fact that many women also do unpaid work at home, such as caring for family members. We need to recognize and value all types of work, whether paid or unpaid.

Gender equality isn't just about fairness and justice; it also brings significant socioeconomic benefits. Countries with greater gender equality tend to be happier and have higher GDP per capita. Increasing women's presence in the workforce can lead to economic diversification, income equality, and the introduction of diverse skills. Studies have shown that having more women in senior management or on corporate boards can even enhance profitability.

With all these benefits in mind, it's hard to justify inaction on gender equality. We can't afford to wait another 132 years to achieve full parity. It's time for all of us, as individuals, businesses, and communities, to take meaningful steps towards gender equality. Together, we can create a fair and equitable society, a more sustainable future, and reap the rewards of a better-performing economy. END

completion:
Our world is incredibly interconnected through a complex network of high-capacity fiber optic cables. These cables, which are as thin as a human hair, form the backbone of the internet and enable us to transmit millions of text, audio, and video communications at lightning speed. Unfortunately, when this network experiences an unexpected outage, it causes a chain reaction of costly and intricate measures to quickly restore service and repair the damage.

However, Mikael Mazur, a researcher at Nokia Bell Labs, is working to prevent this scenario from occurring. In a recent field trial, Mazur demonstrated how communication fibers can also function as environmental sensors, providing an early detection system for network failure. The real-time coherent transceiver prototype, deployed in Mazur's home country of Sweden, can detect vibrations and distortions in the fiber. This technology can be used for continuous monitoring over a 524-km live network aerial fiber, which aims to create a more versatile and robust network.

The implications of this technology extend far beyond the realm of telecom. It could also be used for ecological monitoring, helping us measure climate change through temperature shifts and ocean current swells, and even detecting earthquakes. Mazur will present these findings at the Optical Fiber Communication Conference in San Diego, California, which is the most prestigious gathering for the optical research community.

Mazur's goal is to extract environmental information from the real-time digital signal processing engine. He believes that the best way to sense what is happening in the network is to use the network itself. In other words, Mazur is working to combine the two primary functions of fiber optics, communication, and sensing. By incorporating sensing capabilities into existing communication cables, we can create a self-monitoring system similar to the fibers used in bridges, buildings, and other critical infrastructure. These fibers, known as "distributed sensing," can provide early warnings of potential issues caused by extreme weather conditions and external factors. Stretching fibers can alert engineers to take proactive measures to prevent breaks or reroute data traffic to avoid outages.

While some of this technology already exists in submarine cables, Mazur's aerial cable, deployed in harsh conditions between the Swedish cities of Gothenburg and Karlstad, is believed to be the first to be wrapped around high-voltage power cables suspended from outdoor poles. This design allows for sensing functionality that is compatible with coherent optical transceiver architectures. This is particularly important as we deploy a significant amount of fiber to the grid. By knowing in advance that a link will go down, we can ensure it does not affect the rest of the network.

This dual function of fiber optics offers an alternative to expensive, specifically designed fiber-sensing devices. It also provides vendors with a competitive advantage at a time when improving speed performance has become increasingly challenging.

In the world of optical fibers, we are rapidly approaching the Shannon limit, which is the maximum amount of error-free information that can be transmitted through any communication channel. Claude Shannon, a renowned researcher at Bell Labs, named this theoretical boundary. Since increasing speed per channel has become so difficult, Mazur believes that we need to improve fiber optics in other ways. Sensing is one such approach that can enhance their versatility.

Using multiple spatial channels with a fiber can not only increase capacities but also enable novel sensing methods. Beyond protecting the network from damage or sabotage, this new function also offers benefits beyond telecommunications, particularly in environmental monitoring such as wind, temperature, and currents. In areas prone to earthquakes, there are usually advanced seismic instruments in place. However, in other regions like the deep oceans, these sensing capabilities can be vital in providing warnings for storms, earthquakes, and tsunamis.

From Nokia's perspective, their primary interest is to protect the network, ensuring reliability and robustness. However, there is also a secondary use case. If these capabilities can be enabled, the optical telecommunications network could play an even more significant role in our society than it does today. END

Discovering the Future of Farming: How Case IH and Tim Brasil are Revolutionizing Agriculture

Case IH is at the forefront of technological advancements in Brazilian agriculture, leading with its advanced farming systems (AFS). The company is dedicated to fostering the growth of digital agriculture by collaborating with farmers to adopt new technologies. Realizing the absence of a reliable resource for farmers to digitally transform their farms, the team at Case IH took it upon themselves to drive this initiative. They developed the concept of the connected farm, aiming to harness the advantages of digital technology.

Recognizing the Benefits of Digital Agriculture: Case IH understands the significant advantages offered by digital agriculture. With technologies like digital connectivity, the Internet of Things (IoT), drones, machine learning (ML), artificial intelligence (AI), and analytics, agriculture can become more sustainable by reducing the use of pesticides, fertilizer, and water. These innovations also enable precision farming. In fact, Bell Labs Consulting predicts that if 25% of farms adopt precision farming by 2030, it could result in yearly yield increases of up to 300 million tons and a reduction in farming costs of up to US$100 billion. These figures are critical in ensuring food security for our growing global population.

Building the Connected Farm: To establish the connected farm, a laboratory for testing, learning, and gathering feedback from the farming community, Case IH required more than just their digital expertise. They needed a connectivity partner with the knowledge and experience to navigate Brazil's vast agricultural landscape. Tim Brasil, an existing partner of Case IH on another agricultural project, immediately stepped up when informed about the connected farm project. "Our focus on agriculture is crucial for the country, as it contributes to 25% of Brazil's GDP," says Paulo Gouvea from Tim Brasil.

Connecting an Expansive Continent: Tim Brasil boasts the largest mobile network coverage in the country, serving over 5,400 cities. They are committed to achieving 100% 4G coverage (or 5,570 cities) by 2023. However, their challenge lies in connecting the remote rural areas of Brazil. Gouvea states, "I would say Brazil is like a continent. With over 300 million hectares of agricultural areas, we face a significant challenge." The business model for service providers typically relies on the number of subscribers per square kilometer, which doesn't align with the needs of rural farming communities. Therefore, a new viable business model had to be developed for the connected farm project to thrive.

Finding the Perfect Location: With Tim Brasil providing the ideal connectivity, Case IH turned its attention to finding a suitable location for the project. "We wanted a location that truly represents Brazilian agriculture," explains Christian Gonzalez from Case IH. They desired to showcase how rural connectivity can enhance in-field productivity, even in already highly productive regions. Rather than creating a farm from scratch, they sought a partner who shared their vision. After careful consideration, they found the perfect partner in Água Boa, a small city in the heart of soybean production in Mato Grosso state. This area has approximately 80,000 inhabitants and is experiencing rapid agricultural development. Gouvea adds, "Água Boa translates to 'good water' in English. We chose this area to demonstrate that technology can increase production without relying on artificial means. We believed that if it worked here, it could work anywhere else in the country." END

Nokia's Unexpected Leadership in Microgrids for Climate Change and Energy Poverty

I was pleasantly surprised when I discovered that Nokia was taking an active role in promoting microgrids as a solution to combat climate change and energy poverty. As someone who has been involved in the microgrid sector for almost a decade, I hadn't expected Nokia to be involved in such an initiative. While I have covered various aspects of microgrids, including financing, regulation, and technical development, the communication infrastructure underlying these systems has not been a major focus in my consulting projects. Participating in Nokia's #realaction microgrid series offered me a chance to gain new insights into this important aspect, given Nokia's position as a market leader.

Exciting Collaboration for Real Change

Nokia has chosen microgrids as the topic for its second series of the real action campaign and has brought together a team of exceptional experts to collaborate and make a positive impact. What truly excited me about being part of Nokia's real action green, local energy - microgrids initiative was the opportunity to work alongside industry experts, each bringing their specific expertise to the table. My teammates, Leslie Labruto, Liana Jo Ault, Marilyn Waite, and our wonderful host, Jason Elliott from Nokia, made this a truly enriching experience.

Making Reliable Energy Access Sustainable

The challenge we face is significant - 789 million people worldwide lack access to electricity, and many more struggle with an unreliable energy supply. Significant investments in energy infrastructure are essential. However, the game has changed as renewable energy sources now make up the majority of newly added power generation capacity. This shift allows for a more decentralized approach to power generation compared to traditional fossil fuel and nuclear plants. Microgrids take this a step further by providing reliable energy on a local, community level. Whether it's a remote African community or an area in the global north facing energy reliability issues due to lack of grid investments or natural disasters, microgrids offer a solution. By integrating as much local renewable energy as possible, microgrids can even surpass national grid levels in achieving higher renewable shares. This is why microgrids are becoming a driving force in our journey towards full decarbonization.

Finding the Right Energy Mix

When it comes to producing energy locally, microgrids must harness the available renewable energy sources on-site effectively. While geothermal and hydroelectric sources are location-specific, wind and solar power are accessible nearly everywhere. However, solar and wind energy are intermittent and do not match the current demand directly. This necessitates combining them with flexible power units like diesel gensets or energy storage systems such as lithium-ion batteries, redox flow batteries, or hydrogen systems. Today, it is crucial to test and prove the concept of 100% renewable energy microgrids. However, for efficiency and profitability, microgrids must strike the right balance of renewable energy sources. Extreme seasonal variations in energy supply or demand would require expensive energy storage systems to achieve 100% renewable microgrids, which may not be economically viable. It might be more practical to build a larger number of microgrids that are not entirely dependent on renewables, with a smaller percentage operating on 100% renewable energy. Nevertheless, when designing microgrids, it is important to pave the way for future decarbonization steps as costs for renewables and energy storage continue to decrease. END

Transitioning into retirement can be an exciting and fulfilling time in our lives. Approximately 8 million Canadians now anticipate retiring either earlier or later due to the impact of COVID-19.

While financial planning for retirement is often emphasized, the lifestyle adjustments that come with this new chapter are sometimes overlooked. Whether you're retiring earlier, later, or on schedule, it's important to navigate this change as smoothly as possible. Assuming your financial preparations are in order, here are a few tips to help you transition gracefully into retirement:

1. Take it at your own pace: You've spent decades getting to know yourself, so trust your instincts during this transition. 2. Stay connected: Regardless of whether you're an introvert or an extrovert, maintaining contact with important people in your life is crucial. Since you may have spent more time with colleagues than family and friends throughout your working years, make an effort to nurture those relationships in your new retirement lifestyle. Next week, Nvidia will be showcased as the winner of the highly competitive 3D occupancy prediction challenge for autonomous driving development at the Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition Conference (CVPR) in Vancouver, Canada. This impressive competition received over 400 submissions from nearly 150 teams across 10 regions.

Now, let's break down what 3D occupancy prediction is. It's the process of predicting the status of each point in a 3D grid scene, known as a voxel. These voxels can be classified as free, occupied, or unknown. This technology is critical for the development of safe and reliable self-driving systems. It provides essential information to autonomous vehicles' planning and control systems using cutting-edge convolutional neural networks and transformer models, which are made possible by the incredible Nvidia Drive platform.

According to Zhiding Yu, a senior research scientist at Nvidia, the winning solution features two key advancements for autonomous vehicles. Firstly, it demonstrates an outstanding model design that excels in bird's-eye-view perception. Secondly, it showcases the effectiveness of visual foundation models with up to 1 billion parameters and large-scale pretraining in 3D occupancy prediction.

Over the years, perception for autonomous driving has evolved from simple 2D tasks to sophisticated 3D reasoning with multiple input images. This advancement allows for a more accurate representation of objects in complex traffic scenes. This precise representation is crucial to ensure the safety requirements for self-driving cars, as stated by Jose Alvarez, the Director of AV Applied Research and Distinguished Scientist at Nvidia.

On Sunday, June 18, at 10:20 a.m. PT, Zhiding Yu will present the award-winning work of Nvidia's research team at CVPR's end-to-end autonomous driving workshop. Additionally, the team will present their work at the vision-centric autonomous driving workshop on Monday, June 19, at 4:00 p.m. PT. As a bonus, Nvidia will also be receiving an innovation award at the event for their exceptional insights into the development of view transformation modules. These modules have substantially improved performance compared to previous approaches, according to the CVPR workshop committee. If you're interested, you can read Nvidia's technical report on their submission.

Let's talk more about the significance of 3D occupancy prediction. While traditional 3D object detection is important for AV perception, it does have its limitations. It lacks expressiveness and may not provide enough real-world information through bounding boxes. Additionally, it requires defining taxonomies and ground truths for all possible objects, even those rarely seen in real life. On the other hand, 3D occupancy prediction offers a wealth of rich information about the world, which is essential for a self-driving vehicle's planning stack and end-to-end autonomous driving.

One of the advantages of software-defined vehicles is the ability to continuously upgrade and enhance them with proven and validated developments over time. State-of-the-art software updates, like the ones recognized at CVPR, enable new features and safer driving capabilities. Nvidia's Drive platform offers automakers a pathway to production, providing comprehensive hardware and software solutions for secure and reliable AV development, from the car to the data center.

They were allowed to use open-source datasets and models, which encouraged the exploration of data-driven algorithms and large-scale models. The organizers provided a baseline sandbox with the latest state-of-the-art 3D occupancy prediction algorithms in real-world scenarios.

AI and Digital Twins: Revolutionizing Climate Research

In his keynote at the Berlin Summit for the Earth Virtualization Engines Initiative, NVIDIA CEO Jensen Huang emphasized the significant role AI and accelerated computing will play in advancing climate science. Huang highlighted the importance of climate modeling, quoting Richard Feynman who famously said, "What I can't create, I don't understand." He acknowledged the vital work of the attendees, recognizing their contributions to policymakers, researchers, and the industry.

The purpose of the Berlin Summit is to bring together scientists and technologists from around the world to harness the power of AI and high-performance computing in creating the climate information systems of the future. Huang outlined three essential breakthroughs needed to achieve this goal of developing Earth Virtualization Engines (EVE). Additionally, he discussed NVIDIA's collaboration with the climate science community through Earth-2, which aims to create Earth Digital Twins.

The first breakthrough required is the ability to simulate the climate rapidly and at a high resolution, enabling predictions at a local level. The second breakthrough involves using AI to emulate the physics of climate accurately, offering new ways to predict Earth's climate and interact with vast amounts of climate data in real-time. AI also plays a crucial role in transforming raw climate data into actionable information, empowering decision-making.

The third breakthrough is the interactive virtualization of massive amounts of data using NVIDIA Omniverse, ensuring accessibility for policymakers, businesses, companies, and scientists. The EVE initiative, a collaboration between different disciplines including climate science, HPC, and AI, aims to provide easily accessible kilometer-scale climate information to promote sustainable management of the planet.

Huang emphasized that Earth-2 and EVE align perfectly because they are both based on the same three breakthroughs. By coordinating climate projections at kilometer-scale resolution, the EVE initiative promises to accelerate advancements in climate and weather research. One innovative application of AI emulators is their integration with physics-based simulations, enabling rapid exploration and massive data compression. By tethering Fourcastnet to checkpoints created by a climate simulation, researchers can generate numerous weather trajectories in seconds to minutes. Nobody wants to find themselves in a situation where they can't find the medication or health product they need. Unfortunately, drug shortages have become more common in recent years due to various reasons such as global supply constraints, manufacturing issues, difficulties in accessing raw materials, and the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. However, there is some good news. Health Canada experts, led by Stephanie Di Trapani, Director of Health Canada's Drug Shortages Division, are working tirelessly to address these shortages.

In 2012, Canada faced a critical national shortage of painkillers, anesthetics, antibiotics, and hospital injectable products. This had severe consequences, with people unable to access necessary medications and surgeries being postponed or canceled. This shortage served as a wake-up call for Health Canada, highlighting the need for proactive measures and increased coordination among all stakeholders. In response, the Multi-Stakeholder Steering Committee on Drug Shortages (MSSC) was formed, bringing together federal, provincial, and territorial governments, as well as health professionals, patient groups, and industry associations. This committee aims to improve information sharing and identify actions to manage and mitigate drug shortages in Canada.

While the creation of the MSSC improved responses to shortages, more information from manufacturers was still needed to prevent and mitigate shortages effectively. Recognizing this, Ms. Di Trapani and her team worked on new regulations requiring manufacturers to report existing and anticipated shortages, as well as discontinuations of certain prescription medications. Canada was among the first countries to implement such reporting regulations. These regulations have enhanced Health Canada's ability to assess supply and demand, identify options to mitigate shortages, ensure timely communication among all stakeholders, and collaborate on strategies to strengthen the supply chain.

Despite these efforts, some shortages cannot be completely avoided or quickly resolved due to their complexity and factors beyond our control. Recently, Canada experienced a shortage of children's analgesics and antibiotics, which lasted for eight months. Ms. Di Trapani and her team worked tirelessly to find solutions. They collaborated with manufacturers to secure supplies from other countries, contacted pharmacists to manage supplies, and provided information and advice to affected parents and caregivers through health professionals. Lessons learned from this shortage are already being applied to prepare for the upcoming cold and flu season.

While Health Canada experts and stakeholders are doing everything they can to manage shortages, they cannot do it alone. They need your assistance. To learn more about how drug shortages are managed and how you can help, please refer to the infographic below. Together, we can make a difference in ensuring access to vital medications and health products for all. END

Heat waves, which bring high temperatures and humidity, can be a concern due to the potential health risks associated with them. Climate change has the ability to make these heat events longer and more intense, making it even more important to take precautions. That's where heat alert and response systems (known as HARs) come in. These systems are implemented by communities to help them prepare for and respond to extreme heat.

HARs consist of several components, including community mobilization and engagement, an alert protocol, a communications plan, a community response plan, and an evaluation plan. In a nutshell, HARs help communities and regions be ready for extreme heat events and know how to take action when they occur. Rachel Siblock, a policy analyst in Health Canada's Heat Division, explains that the first step for communities is to determine the threshold for activating their heat response plans. This usually aligns with the heat alerts and warnings issued by Environment and Climate Change Canada. Once the threshold is met, communities can then decide which activities within their plans will be implemented.

Every community is unique, so their HARs may include various activities to protect their citizens from extreme heat. Some examples include distributing bottled water, opening cooling centers, and encouraging residents to check in on vulnerable individuals at home. Rachel emphasizes that each community has the flexibility to decide what actions are most appropriate for them.

Different communities implement HARs in different ways. Urban centers may have cooling centers or splash pads that are easily accessible, while rural areas may focus on messaging that encourages people to check on their neighbors who may be more vulnerable to heat-related problems. Health Canada provides guidance and information to help local and regional health authorities develop evidence-based extreme heat plans and interventions. Rachel and her colleagues also play a connecting role, linking municipal and health officials with experts from other parts of Canada who can provide valuable insights.

Rachel notes that any action taken during a heat event has the potential to protect health, and increasing community leadership and support has proven to be effective. When people understand the impact of heat, they are usually willing to get involved. Currently, the team is collaborating with BC's Interior Health Authority on a pilot project to develop culturally appropriate and safe HARs with Indigenous communities in the region. Any community interested in developing their own HARs is encouraged to contact the Heat Division and join Health Canada's Heat Community of Practice, a network dedicated to protecting Canadians from the health impacts of extreme heat. END

In recent months, there have been significant outbreaks of vaccine preventable diseases like measles, polio, and diphtheria around the world. This may lead people to wonder why these outbreaks are happening and if they are at risk. To understand the current situation, it's important to learn more about how vaccination works as a preventive measure for public health. Today, I invite you on a journey to explore vaccines and why they are so important.

I am incredibly grateful for Canada's long history of strong vaccination programs and the positive impact they have had on improving health. Let me share a few examples with you. Vaccines have played a crucial role in saving lives and enhancing the well-being of people in Canada and across the globe by reducing or eliminating the spread of serious infectious diseases. According to the World Health Organization, vaccination prevents 3.5 to 5 million deaths annually from diseases like diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis, influenza, and measles. Early studies also suggest that COVID-19 vaccines have prevented millions of deaths worldwide. Thanks to vaccines, we have successfully eradicated smallpox, meaning that it no longer exists, and we no longer need to vaccinate against it. Moreover, other diseases have seen significant reductions in their rates.

Vaccines are vital because they help prevent and protect against specific diseases. They work with our body's natural defenses, known as the immune system, to make us less susceptible to infections and less likely to develop severe illness. Vaccines also decrease the chances of spreading infections from one person to another. By exposing our bodies to harmless parts of bacteria or viruses, called antigens, vaccines allow our immune system to develop a response against them. If we are later exposed to the same bacterium or virus, our immune system will recognize the antigen and respond more quickly, helping to prevent us from getting the disease or experiencing severe illness if we do contract it.

Some vaccines also contribute to community immunity, also known as herd immunity. This means that the more people who are vaccinated against a disease, the less likely it is to spread within a community. This protection benefits individuals who are at higher risk of severe complications from vaccine preventable diseases, including those who cannot be vaccinated or for whom a particular vaccine may not be as effective, such as those with weakened immune systems.

Let's now delve into some vaccines available to us and the significant impact they have had in Canada. In addition to the ones mentioned below, there are vaccines that can prevent various other illnesses, such as certain types of pneumonia, meningitis, chickenpox, shingles, and hepatitis B, among others. There are also vaccines specifically designed to combat respiratory viruses like influenza and SARS-CoV-2, as well as vaccines recommended for travelers depending on their destination.

Measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine is particularly crucial in preventing the spread of contagious diseases. Measles, in particular, can result in serious complications such as pneumonia and inflammation of the brain, which can lead to permanent brain damage or even death. It is also highly contagious, easily spreading among unvaccinated or previously unexposed individuals. To break the chain of transmission, approximately 95 out of 100 people who have never had a measles' infection need to be vaccinated. This emphasizes the importance of maintaining high population-level measles vaccination coverage to prevent outbreaks. Thankfully, the MMR vaccine protects against all three of these highly contagious viruses. In Canada, thanks to the introduction of these vaccines in the 1960s and their inclusion in routine vaccination programs, cases of measles, mumps, and rubella have decreased by 98% or more.

By understanding the importance of vaccines and the immense impact they have had in Canada and beyond, we can continue to prioritize vaccination as a key investment in improving population health and reducing healthcare costs. END

completion:
Keeping Canadians Safe from Botulism

Have you ever heard of botulism? While this foodborne illness may not be as well-known as others, it can have serious consequences. Luckily, botulism is very rare in Canada thanks to our safe food practices and the dedicated scientists at Health Canada. Botulism is caused by eating food and drinks contaminated with a potent toxin called botulinum toxin, produced by bacteria called clostridium botulinum.

The symptoms of botulism typically include blurred and double vision, drooping eyelids, and difficulty swallowing and speaking. In severe cases, paralysis may affect the muscles that help us breathe, requiring the use of mechanical ventilation. It can take months or even years to fully recover from the effects of botulism. Unfortunately, approximately one in ten people with botulism die from the disease.

Dr. John Austin, a research scientist at Health Canada, along with lab technicians Dr. Richard Harris and Ryan Boone, analyze botulism samples and conduct research on the disease and the bacterium that causes it. Their work is crucial in finding ways to better protect Canadians from botulism. Let's take a closer look at how their efforts help keep us safe.

Identifying the Dangerous Toxin

There are different types of botulism, but the main ones are foodborne botulism and infant botulism. Foodborne botulism can occur in environments without oxygen, such as canned foods. It can also be found in other foods like garlic stored in oil, carrot juice, salted fish, and traditionally prepared seal, whale, and walrus meat. Infant botulism occurs when the c. botulinum bacteria, sometimes found in honey, grow inside a baby's body and produce toxins. Because infants don't yet have enough good bacteria in their bodies, the c. botulinum bacteria can thrive and produce botulinum toxin.

Working with the Medical Community

"Botulinum toxin is the most potent toxin known. The oral lethal dose for a person is estimated to be approximately 70 millionths of a gram or 0.00007g, which is an tiny amount," explains Dr. Austin. Due to the dangerous nature of botulism, early intervention is crucial. Doctors prescribe antitoxins to patients suspected of having botulism and send clinical samples to the Botulism Reference Service, run by Dr. Austin and his technicians, to confirm the diagnosis. Thankfully, most samples don't test positive for botulism, but this information is still valuable for doctors to rule out botulism as the cause of illness and improve patient care. When botulism is confirmed, they work with provinces and local health units to trace the source and recall the contaminated food product, preventing further cases.

Helping Food Manufacturers and Indigenous Communities Improve Food Safety Practices

In addition to assisting the medical and public health communities, Dr. Austin and his colleagues are committed to making our food safer. "We're always searching for ways to make food safer, so that botulism becomes even rarer. That's why we continue to study new methods to eliminate the bacteria and its spores," explains Dr. Austin. One of these new methods involves using UV light to pasteurize or kill c. botulinum in foods. If proven safe and effective, this method could soon be adopted by food manufacturers for commercial foods. Additionally, Dr. Austin and his team recognized that certain traditional Indigenous foods, such as seal, can be sources of botulism. They worked with Dr. Daniel Leclair at the Nunavik Research Centre to understand why and identify strategies to mitigate this issue.

While botulism is a serious food safety concern, we are fortunate to have dedicated individuals like Dr. Richard Harris, Ryan Boone, and Dr. John Austin working tirelessly to keep us safe from it. END

How do mortgage rates impact housing prices? This is a common question many people have when considering the Canadian housing market. According to TD economist Rishi Sondhi, mortgage rates play a significant role in influencing housing prices. However, it's important to note that they are not the sole determining factor. Other factors such as the job market, population growth, and housing supply also contribute to the overall picture.

Currently, Canada's housing market is favoring sellers over buyers. In April, existing home sales reached their highest level since June of the previous year, and prices rose by 6% month-over-month. The supply of available homes, however, has not kept up with the demand, resulting in increased competition and a market that benefits sellers. Despite the strong demand and rising prices, the number of new listings remains low, which might seem surprising.

Sondhi explains that there are several reasons for the limited supply of homes. One of them is the presence of "forced selling," where homeowners are not compelled to sell their properties due to favorable conditions in the job market and the ability to extend their mortgage amortization in a high-interest rate environment. Some individuals with variable rate mortgages are able to extend the length of their mortgage to afford regular payments.

Additionally, investors with rental properties are opting to hold onto their properties due to the strength of the rental market. Construction timelines for new homes are also increasing, slowing down the availability of homes for sale. There may also be a psychological factor at play, with homeowners waiting to see if the market further improves before listing their homes.

Another factor affecting supply could be the affordability backdrop, which has made it challenging for individuals to move into larger and more expensive homes. This delay in move-up buying means that homeowners are staying in their current homes for longer periods, further limiting the availability of homes for sale.

As for the relationship between mortgage rates and housing prices, they are typically inversely related. When mortgage rates increase, housing prices tend to decrease. However, it's crucial to consider that mortgage rates are not the only factor influencing housing prices. The state of the job market, population growth, and housing supply all play a role.

In the first quarter of 2022, mortgage rates and housing prices rose simultaneously. This was due to the "race for space" phenomenon that occurred during the early stages of the pandemic. Urban dwellers in many Canadian cities started searching for detached, single-family homes, leading to increased demand and higher prices. The Bank of Canada responded by cutting interest rates, resulting in lower mortgage rates and further driving up housing prices.

In summary, while mortgage rates do have an impact on housing prices, they are just one piece of the puzzle. Factors such as the job market, population growth, and housing supply also play significant roles. Understanding these dynamics can help individuals make informed decisions in the Canadian housing market. END

Update on Meta's Year of Efficiency

Dear Meta Employees,

I wanted to share some exciting updates on our Year of Efficiency, which is an important step towards building the future of human connection. The main goals of this initiative are to make us a better technology company and improve our financial performance in a challenging environment so that we can execute our long-term vision.

Our efficiency work consists of various parallel projects aimed at improving organizational efficiency, significantly increasing developer productivity and tooling, optimizing distributed work, eliminating unnecessary processes, and more. I believe in being transparent about the work in progress, and while I know that many of you are enthusiastic about these changes, I also understand that the idea of upcoming organizational changes can create uncertainty and stress.

My hope is to implement these organizational changes as soon as possible this year, so that we can overcome this period of uncertainty and focus on the crucial work ahead. Here's a timeline of what you can expect in the next few months:

- Over the next couple of months, our organizational leaders will announce restructuring plans focused on streamlining our teams, cancelling lower-priority projects, and reducing our hiring rates.
- Unfortunately, with less hiring, I have made the difficult decision to further reduce the size of our recruiting team. We will inform the impacted members tomorrow.
- We anticipate announcing restructurings and layoffs in our tech groups in late April, followed by our business groups in late May. Please note that in some cases, these changes may take until the end of the year to complete.
- Our timelines for international teams will differ, and local leaders will provide more details.

In total, we expect to reduce our team size by approximately 10,000 people and close around 5,000 additional open roles that we have not yet hired for. I understand that this will be challenging, and it means saying goodbye to talented and passionate colleagues who have contributed to our success. I am personally grateful for all their efforts, as they have dedicated themselves to our mission.

We will support affected individuals in the same way we have done in the past, and we will treat everyone with the gratitude they deserve. Once the restructuring is complete, we plan to lift hiring and transfer freezes within each group.

In addition to these efficiency measures, we have other important timelines to keep in mind. This summer, we aim to complete our analysis from our hybrid work year of learning, which will allow us to further refine our distributed work model. Throughout the year, we will also introduce a steady stream of developer productivity enhancements and process improvements.

I want to reiterate that part of our efficiency work involves removing certain jobs, which is necessary to build a leaner, more technical company and improve our overall business performance. This is all in service of our long-term vision.

I understand that this update may still come as a surprise, so I would like to provide some broader context on our vision, culture, and operating philosophy. Every day, Meta strives to build a better technology company that enables people to feel closer to each other. In today's complex world, this is a fundamental human need that we believe is more important than ever. We leverage advanced technologies, such as AI, the metaverse, encryption, and business tools, to create inspiring products that enhance people's lives, help them connect, and foster growth.

Simply put, if you want to invent the future or apply the best ideas to reach people at an unprecedented scale, Meta is the best place for you.

Thank you for your continued dedication and support as we embark on this journey towards a more efficient and connected future.

Best regards,
Mark Zuckerberg END
