Several years before I started my graduate studies at the University of Toronto, I left my hometown in Philadelphia and embarked on a journey around the world. I studied development projects in Sri Lanka, took courses in classical history and archaeology in Italy, taught in England, and created art in Portugal. I was proud of my adventures and marked each new destination on a world map as a personal accomplishment. However, I also became fascinated by the fact that this map wouldn't exist if it weren't for the brave explorers who ventured into the unknown and documented their discoveries.

When I arrived at U of T in 1988, I met Alex Jones, a classics professor who seemed to understand my curiosity. He suggested that I delve into the history of cartography, which immediately sparked my interest. During my time at U of T's Institute for the History and Philosophy of Science and Technology, I had the wonderful opportunity to conduct years of research on the medieval period's history of maps and exploration.

Early maps not only depicted lands and seas but also revealed how ancient civilizations perceived the world. Their maps were often based on exploration, but also on myth, rumors, and speculation. After graduating, I stumbled upon a set of rare early maps and texts owned by a private collector. These maps fascinated me because of their unique background. They had been brought to the United States by an Italian immigrant named Marcian F. Rossi and were now in the possession of one of his descendants. Rossi's Italian lineage traced back to an admiral who had known Marco Polo, the Venetian merchant famous for his extensive travels across Asia from 1271 to 1295.

These maps had been briefly mentioned in a 1940s article but had never been thoroughly studied, so I seized the opportunity to investigate further. This marked the beginning of years of intense research and analysis, including the challenging task of translating fragments of Latin, medieval Italian, and even Chinese found on the documents. The maps themselves were created with ink on vellum and provided a previously unknown account of Marco Polo's journey. One of the texts mentioned a "land of frost" and "sea lions" and referred to the far reaches of Northeast Asia, which some maps seemed to depict as well – a region not mentioned in the traditional Marco Polo narrative. The same text also described a "remote peninsula washed by the seas" where the people lived in caves due to freezing. These descriptions, along with certain depictions on the maps, hinted at early knowledge of the western shores of North America, possibly predating Columbus by two centuries. The documents even suggested charting of the Northern Pacific Ocean and perhaps parts of Alaska, long before the first Russian expeditions took place there.

The sheer quantity of materials, including 14 maps and texts, and the numerous connections within and between them made the investigation even more intriguing and complex. With the recent publication of my book, "The Mysteries of the Marco Polo Maps" in 2014, a wider audience now has the chance to appreciate the beauty and complexity of these maps, as well as the important role that merchants and explorers like Marco Polo played in expanding our knowledge of distant lands. I like to believe that my own travels, which eventually took me to Asia after graduate school, are a reflection of Polo's curiosity about the world beyond his humble origins. END

The University of Oxford's Lunar Thermal Mapper (LTM) instrument has reached a significant milestone on its journey to the moon. It has been successfully installed on NASA's Lunar Trailblazer spacecraft at Lockheed Martin Space in Colorado, USA. This state-of-the-art camera, supported by the UK Space Agency, will provide detailed maps of the lunar surface temperature and composition with a resolution of around 50 meters.

Together with the spacecraft's High-Resolution Volatiles and Minerals Moon Mapper (HVM3), the LTM will play a crucial role in determining the abundance, location, and form of water on the moon. These findings will guide future robotic and human explorations, including the Artemis program's human landings. The presence of water on the moon holds great potential for various purposes such as drinking water purification, fuel production, and providing breathable oxygen.

The LTM will utilize four infrared channels to create temperature maps of the lunar surface, ranging from approximately -163 °C to 127 °C. Additionally, it will use eleven narrow infrared channels to identify variations in the composition of the moon's rocks and soils. This will provide valuable information about the lunar surface and potential water sources.

Meanwhile, the HVM3, developed by NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Southern California, will detect and map the form, abundance, and locations of water on the lunar landscape by analyzing spectral fingerprints. By observing the same areas at different times of the day, the Lunar Trailblazer will be able to monitor changes in the amount of water, such as its transformation into gas as the surface heats up or its accumulation as frost in shaded regions during cooling periods.

The Lunar Trailblazer mission aims to answer important questions such as whether water molecules are trapped inside lunar rocks or if significant amounts of water ice exist in the permanently shadowed craters at the lunar poles.

Selected by NASA's Small Innovative Missions for Planetary Exploration (SIMPLEX) program in 2019, the Lunar Trailblazer will launch as a secondary payload on a planned lunar lander mission led by Intuitive Machines. With support from the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council (EPSRC), the project will address the key challenges currently hindering the tidal energy sector from reaching its full potential.

By integrating these elements into holistic design processes, the project aims to significantly reduce costs, improve engineering solutions, and remove unnecessary redundancy.

This collaboration ensures that Cotide's outputs will deliver new tools, models, and processes with direct industrial impact.

completion:
Researchers from the Livestock, Environment and People (LEAP) project at the University of Oxford have conducted a study linking the dietary choices of over 55,000 individuals with the environmental impacts of their food. The findings indicate that the environmental impact of vegans is approximately one-third of that of high meat eaters. Additionally, there was a 30% difference in environmental harm between high-meat and low-meat diets across various measures such as greenhouse gas emissions, land use, water use, water pollution risk, and biodiversity loss. The participants in the study identified themselves as vegan, vegetarian, pescetarian, or meat eaters, and the environmental impact of their diets was assessed accordingly.

The research team considered the variation in environmental impact based on the production methods and sources of the food, ensuring that the results were comprehensive and not limited to specific food production techniques. The relationship between animal-based food consumption and environmental impact remained clear, despite variations in how and where the food was produced. The authors of the study argue that this finding should serve as a call to action for policies aimed at reducing meat production and consumption. The paper detailing these findings has been published in Nature Food.

The impact of our food choices on the environment is well-established. In 2015, the global food system accounted for about one-third of total greenhouse gas emissions, both directly and indirectly. Moreover, it is estimated that the food system is responsible for 70% of the world's freshwater use and 78% of freshwater pollution. Human activities, primarily related to agriculture, have affected approximately three-quarters of the planet's ice-free land, leading to significant biodiversity loss through activities like deforestation.

Lead author Professor Peter Scarborough from the Nuffield Department of Primary Care Health Sciences at Oxford University emphasizes that our dietary choices have a significant impact on the planet. Focusing on isolated data that highlights either the high environmental impact of certain plant-based foods or the low impact of certain meats can obscure the overall relationship between animal-based foods and the environment. This study, which incorporates data from over 38,000 farms in more than 100 countries, demonstrates that high meat diets have the most significant impact on key environmental indicators such as climate change and biodiversity loss. Reducing meat and dairy consumption can have a substantial positive effect on your dietary footprint.

Previous research has already indicated that plant-based diets have lower environmental impacts than meat-based diets in terms of greenhouse gas emissions, land use, and water use. It has also suggested that reducing meat intake tends to be healthier. However, these studies often make assumptions about people's food choices and do not account for variations in environmental impact depending on the source and production methods of food. Professor Scarborough and his team looked at actual eating habits, using data from a sample of 55,000 individuals in the UK who completed a food frequency questionnaire. They then connected this data to databases that estimate the environmental impacts of commonly consumed foods, considering the variations in sourcing and production methods.

The findings revealed that all five environmental impacts studied were associated with the consumption of animal-based foods. The environmental impacts of vegans were only one-quarter of those of high meat eaters in terms of greenhouse gas emissions and land use, 27% for water pollution, 46% for water use, and 34% for biodiversity. Most indicators showed at least a 30% difference between low and high meat eaters. This study reinforces previous findings, highlighting that vegan and vegetarian diets have significantly lower environmental impacts compared to fish and meat consumption. The region of origin and the methods of food production do not diminish the differences between diet groups and should not hinder policy actions aimed at reducing the consumption of animal-based foods. END

The Oxford Union Society has always been a topic of discussion. Since its establishment in 1823, it has provided a platform for Oxford students to freely engage in conversations about religion, politics, and a wide range of other important topics. Our members have passionately debated international relations, theology, genetics, nuclear policy, civil rights, and the environment, sparking intense discussions worldwide. In recent years, we have found ourselves in the spotlight simply for hosting speakers who hold differing views, which has caused discomfort for some individuals.

Unfortunately, many moderate thinkers now avoid discussing certain issues, fearing backlash from a small but vocal minority. It is important for those who accused us of "de-platforming" speakers to consider the profiles of our guest speakers and the challenging security environments under which they often speak. As we celebrate our bicentenary, we reflect on the significant debates that have resonated worldwide, the guest speakers who have faced rigorous questioning from our members, and the contributions of our alumni life members who have shaped our heritage and history.

Most notably, in late February, we hosted our bicentenary debate, welcoming back hundreds of alumni life members to celebrate 200 years of free speech at the Oxford Union.

Despite the festivities, our commitment to free speech remains stronger than ever. We echo the university's affirmation that free speech is the lifeblood of a university – it enables the pursuit of knowledge and helps us approach truth. END

There have been various explanations given for why Vladimir Putin decided to invade Ukraine, often pointing to NATO expansion and Ukraine's movement towards EU membership. Many people across the world have expressed surprise since February 24, 2022, at Ukraine's strong determination to repel the invasion. Dominating its neighbors is a throwback to Soviet times, an aspiration for imperial power, and should be seen as such.

It is evident that Putin does not recognize Ukraine's sovereignty or international law in general, which does not bode well for any peace process. However, it is important to understand that this thinking about Ukraine is deeply ingrained in both the East and the West, even if not explicitly expressed. This is not to say that nation-building hasn't faced challenges since 1991, as is also true for other former Soviet republics, including Russia.

The collapse of the USSR was a tremendous loss for Russia, and Putin himself referred to it as the worst thing to happen in the 20th century. This sentiment is reflected in the change that occurred to Russia's national anthem. Therefore, even though Ukraine has been a sovereign state since 1991, the war it has been fighting for the past 12 months (and eight years) can be seen as a war of independence. Not in the traditional sense of gaining recognition as a state, as that is already established by the international community, but as a demonstration of Ukraine's autonomy, agency, and ability to shape its own future. A future where Ukraine is always acknowledged as the sovereign nation it truly is. END

By integrating climate and biodiversity policies, we can unlock the full potential of biodiversity in supporting climate action. Some interventions aimed at mitigating climate change, like planting trees in natural grasslands or expanding bioenergy, can further strain our lands and harm biodiversity. Moreover, nature-based solutions must be accompanied by substantial reductions in greenhouse gas emissions and not be used as an excuse to delay action on emissions. We must also prioritize cooperation and engagement with local communities to ensure fair outcomes.

In the coming months, we have a unique opportunity to address the climate change and biodiversity crises in a bold and interconnected way. Let's seize this chance to create a better future for our planet and all its inhabitants. END

Around the world, more than 100 million people are forced to leave their homes due to violence and persecution. Out of these, over a quarter have crossed borders to become refugees. Drawing on Oxford University's rich history, we have a longstanding tradition of welcoming refugees, dating back to the Second World War when we provided support to refugee academics. Oxford has applied to be recognized as a University of Sanctuary, a status currently held by 24 universities across the country. A recent Harvard study has uncovered an important link between the design, maintenance, and operation of buildings and our overall well-being. Researchers from the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health's Center for Health and the Global Environment, in collaboration with SUNY Upstate Medical, conducted a national study to explore the impact of working in high-performing, green-certified buildings on employee decision-making.

The study examined 10 high-performing buildings in five cities across the United States, including Harvard's own Double LEED Platinum Blackstone South Building. Working closely with the Office for Sustainability and Harvard Real Estate, the team used the Blackstone building as a "living laboratory" to investigate how building conditions affect productivity and well-being.

The results were remarkable. Occupants of high-performing, green-certified office environments scored 26 percent higher on tests of cognitive function, experienced 30 percent fewer symptoms of sick building syndrome, and had 6 percent higher sleep quality scores compared to those in high-performing but non-certified buildings. The study also identified specific factors that influenced cognitive function scores, such as maintaining thermal comfort within the range defined by the American Society of Heating, Refrigerating, and Air-Conditioning Engineers (ASHRAE). Additionally, the presence of brighter, blue-enriched lighting, such as daylighting, in the green-certified buildings correlated with better sleep quality at night, leading to improved cognitive performance the next day. This finding confirms previous research showing the impact of lighting on our sleep-wake cycle.

"We are passionate about improving the health and well-being of people in all buildings, everywhere, every day," said Joseph Allen, Assistant Professor at the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health. "Through our 'Buildingomics' approach, we merge building science with health science to examine all the factors in the built environment that influence human health, well-being, and productivity."

The research builds upon the team's previous study, which demonstrated that cognitive function scores doubled in simulated green building environments with enhanced ventilation. This new study takes the findings from the lab to real building environments, highlighting the additional benefits of green certification even in buildings with high ventilation rates and low chemical concentrations. Factors like lighting and thermal conditions have a significant impact on the work and health of occupants.

In addition to their groundbreaking research, the Center for Health and the Global Environment recently received the inaugural grant from the Office for Sustainability's Campus Sustainability Innovation Fund. This grant will support the study and quantification of the health impacts of biophilic design, which involves incorporating nature into the built environment. The team will use a mobile virtual reality lab to simulate exposure to different indoor environments and will monitor student and staff participants in various Harvard buildings that exhibit varying levels of natural elements.

These research efforts are part of Harvard's commitment to the "living lab" initiative, which encourages projects that enhance well-being, mitigate climate impact, and address community challenges. By utilizing the campus as a test site, the Office for Sustainability and the Center for Health and the Global Environment aim to apply their findings to public health research and practical solutions.

Through their work, they are bridging the gap between scientific research and decision-makers, advocating for healthier buildings based on comprehensive scientific data. By creating healthier environments, we can all work better, sleep better, and ultimately feel better. END

Sometimes, we can learn valuable lessons right in the classroom. A great example of this is John Collins' world-record paper airplane. Last Wednesday, Collins brought his amazing design, along with his enthusiasm and a few boxes of planes, to the Graduate School of Design (GSD). Collins, whose plane set the record for distance in 2012 at 226 feet, offered a workshop that used paper airplanes as a teaching tool. He spoke to a group of students about making planes, including design, goals, and materials. As he explained the process, he encouraged students to do something that would have gotten them in trouble in high school: making and flying paper airplanes in class. 

Collins emphasized that when it comes to design solutions, they have to work. He said, "If you can wad up a piece of paper and throw it farther than your paper airplane, your plane is not good." Collins' talk covered topics such as glide ratios, center of gravity, center of lift, the boundary layer, and the Magnus effect. Drawing on his experience with origami, Collins introduced students to the complex folds of their first plane, which had a thick hexagonal front. He explained how a small fold here or there can improve flight by shifting the center of gravity or preventing a nosedive by tweaking a wing's trailing edge. Along the way, he provided insight into his process of designing 75 original planes. 

This workshop, along with the previous night's lecture at Gund Hall, was part of the new Master in Design Engineering (MDE) program offered jointly by GSD and the John A. Paulson School of Engineering and Applied Sciences (SEAS). Kevin Kit Parker, the Tarr Family Professor of Bioengineering and Applied Physics, who arranged Collins' visit, said, "My goal was to bring in someone who thinks outside the box and has taken a nontraditional path to speak to our students. Innovation can come in many forms, not just through formal education. Before being innovative, one must live a creative life, and John certainly does." 

Martin Bechthold, the Kumagai Professor of Architectural Technology and MDE co-director, explained that the program aims to train students to analyze and solve problems that span various disciplines and scales. One challenge they face is the lack of readily available data for such problems. Throughout their two years of study, students will work in multidisciplinary teams, where collaboration will be crucial for success. 

Collins, a former television producer and director whose love for paper airplanes never faded, achieved his world record by taking a different approach than the previous champion, who flew a basic dart that every kid knows how to make. Instead of relying on brute force like the dart, Collins aimed for the perfect balance of float. In a conversation after the classroom session, Collins shared one of the most valuable lessons from his achievement: you may fail in any attempt, but you're only defeated when you give up. He also offered a tip to paper plane enthusiasts frustrated by planes that don't fly well: instead of folding another one, make adjustments to the one you already have. "Treat every flight like a test flight, observe what it's doing," Collins advised. "You can improve the flight of a poorly folded plane." 

During the workshop, students had the opportunity to make three different flying forms: a plane, a flying ring, and a tumbling wing that spins as it floats on the updraft from a rectangular piece of cardboard moving at walking speed. Graduate student Seungkuk Ahn found it fascinating to take a scientific approach to such a seemingly simple problem. "This was really fun, and we learned a lot about design criteria effortlessly," Ahn shared. "The best way to learn is in person." END

If you've ever worried about toxic chemicals in your everyday environment, you wouldn't have found reassurance at the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health forum on "Hormone-Altering Chemicals: Fertility and Health Implications." Presented in collaboration with The Huffington Post and moderated by Erin Schumaker, the panel's focus was on chemicals that impact the endocrine system and their effects on fertility and childbirth. The main message of the discussion was succinctly conveyed in a video by the Environmental Working Group: "Toxic chemicals are everywhere."

During the panel, some alarming statistics were shared. Everyday products, such as personal hygiene products, medications, food packaging, and even window blinds, contain over 10,000 chemicals that have not been approved by the Food and Drug Administration. Many of these chemicals are actually banned in China and the European Union. Russ Hauser, Acting Chair of the Department of Environmental Health at Harvard Chan School, explained that these chemicals are known as endocrine disruptors, which can interfere with our metabolism, immune system, and fertility in both men and women. He emphasized that even exposure to low levels of these chemicals can have adverse effects on humans.

Tamarra James-Todd, a Professor of Environmental Reproductive and Perinatal Epidemiology at Harvard Chan School, highlighted that certain populations, such as pregnant women and minorities, are particularly vulnerable. Chemicals used in cosmetics and industrial products can disrupt glucose regulation, potentially leading to type II diabetes that can be passed on to children by pregnant women. Teenage women are also at risk because they tend to use more cosmetics and personal products than adult women. Nneka Leiba, Deputy Director of Research for the Environmental Working Group, shared that they tested 25 chemicals in teenage girls and found 16 of them to be present, all associated with endocrine disruption. This is concerning as adolescence is a critical period for the development of the brain and immune system, both of which rely on complex hormonal signaling.

These toxic chemicals are not only present in personal products but can also be found in waterproof clothing and nonstick cookware. Their ubiquity is concerning.

Pete Myers, CEO and Chief Scientist of Environmental Health Sciences, joined the panel via Skype from Europe and focused on the challenges of effective regulation. Myers, who has been working on this issue since the 1980s, emphasized that endocrine-disrupting chemicals are globally recognized as a health threat by the World Health Organization. However, they are not regulated as such in the United States. He explained that slow progress in regulation is largely due to financial interests. Taking action based on the current scientific knowledge would require removing multiple products from the market, and this doesn't align with the financial interests of those involved. Unfortunately, science-to-regulation processes often move slowly or even regress.

Despite these challenges, consumers do have some power. The Environmental Working Group maintains a database of products that are rated for their chemical safety. Additionally, last year's update of the Toxic Substances Control Act, which was introduced in the 1970s, gave more regulatory power to the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). However, the future of this act is uncertain under the new administration. Scott Pruitt's recent approval as the head of the EPA is seen by some as a potential setback since he has previously fought against regulations on toxic emissions as the Attorney General of Oklahoma. All panelists agreed that stronger government regulation is needed, but they were not optimistic about significant changes happening in the near future.

Pete Myers summed it up best when he said, "What I'd look for is a package of policies that move us into a world in which moms don't have to be chemical engineers to go shopping for their kids." END

Consuming partisan news has been criticized for increasing polarization, but new research highlights another consequence: a decline in trust in the media. In a study conducted during the 2018 US midterm elections, internet users were asked to change their default browser homepages to either the left-leaning Huffington Post or the more conservative outlet, Fox News.

Participants in the study allowed researchers to survey them multiple times and collected data on their web visits and Twitter posts. After eight weeks, it became evident that participants' trust in the media had decreased. This effect remained detectable even nearly a year later for visitors to both partisan news sites.

While exposure to partisan news led to an initial increase in visits to both sites and improved knowledge of recent events, it did not result in changes in political attitudes, opinions, or behaviors. Study co-author Andy Guess, an assistant professor of politics and public affairs at the Princeton School of Public and International Affairs, explained, "Our work adds a piece to this puzzle, showing that it's difficult for people to be persuaded by competing media outlets during an election campaign. That said, spending more time on these sites does lead to a growing distrust in the news."

The study was conducted by Guess, Pablo Barberá from the University of Southern California, Simon Munzert from the Hertie School, and Junghwan Yang from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. The researchers collaborated with the online polling firm YouGov, which initially recruited 1,551 respondents for the study. Participants were asked about their news consumption, attitudes on domestic and foreign policy issues, voting behavior, and views on President Donald Trump.

During the study, a "nudge-like" approach was implemented, where a third of the group was asked to change their browser homepage to the left-leaning Huffington Post, another third to the right-leaning Fox News, while the remaining third served as the control group, not changing anything. Fox News and Huffington Post were chosen for their significance in the current political landscape and based on empirical web tracking data.

The researchers found that participants in the Huffington Post group visited approximately one additional page on the website per day, amounting to nearly 50 seconds of additional browsing time. On the other hand, the Fox News group visited nearly four more pages per day, equivalent to an additional two minutes. Prior to the study, participants spent an average of only 34 minutes per week on any news site.

By simply changing a default setting on participants' devices (the browser homepage), the study demonstrated the power of basic digital "opt-ins" in shaping people's information consumption. The researchers suggest that social platforms, public media, and other intermediaries can learn from these findings to promote authoritative and nonpartisan sources of information. This could help address the trust crisis we currently face.

The research received funding from the Volkswagen Foundation Computational Social Science Initiative and was supported by the Princeton University Committee on Research in the Humanities and Social Sciences and the Center for International Studies at the University of Southern California. END

The Macmillan Group at the Department of Chemistry has developed a way to identify the nearest neighbors of proteins on cell surfaces. This is like shining a metaphorical searchlight into a dark cave, revealing which proteins on a cell's surface interact with one another. Proteins play a vital role in our lives, influencing everything from our thoughts to our growth and the diseases we may develop. They communicate with their neighbors to carry out important functions. However, scientists previously struggled to determine which proteins were in proximity to one another, limiting their understanding of these essential protein-to-protein communications. 

The µmap technology, created by a team of researchers from Princeton and Merck, uses a photocatalyst to mark proteins and their neighboring molecules on cell surfaces. This allows for precise mapping of the micro-environment. The applications of this technology are vast and could impact fields such as proteomics, genomics, and neuroscience. The potential for advancements in fundamental biology is so significant that David Macmillan, Princeton's distinguished university professor of chemistry, is eager to share the technology with scientists in other fields to see what they can discover.

The problem with current tagging technologies is not their ability to label proteins, but rather the difficulty in distinguishing between proteins that are far apart and those that are adjacent. This is crucial because molecules, proteins, and enzymes that communicate with each other are typically in proximity. The team developed a revolutionary approach that allows for labeling within a short distance, providing a clear understanding of the neighborhood. This has never been achieved before and is comparable to turning on a light switch and suddenly being able to see everything in biology.

Scientists from the Merck Exploratory Science Center believe that this technology has the potential to be a game-changer for both academic and industry labs worldwide. By understanding protein interactions within cellular micro-environments, researchers can make significant advancements in the field of biology.

Macmillan's group focused on two categories of human cells for their investigation. The first group served as a control, consisting of proteins with known interactions, to demonstrate that µmap can capture these interactions. The second group was more intriguing, as it centered on proteins associated with the immune system's response to cancer cells. These proteins, called pd-l1 and pd-1, play a critical role in identifying and eliminating cancerous cells. Macmillan emphasizes the unique collaboration between biology and chemistry, as their respective expertise combined to tackle a problem that neither field could solve alone.

This innovative technology is opening up a world of possibilities in understanding protein interactions and developing new therapeutics. It has the potential to revolutionize the way we approach biology and could have a significant impact on improving human health. END

Join us at the National Mall in Washington starting August 18th for an exciting new installation called "Let Freedom Ring." Created by Professor Paul Ramírez Jonas, this temporary exhibit aims to create a more inclusive and commemorative landscape on the mall. The installation features a beautiful carillon, a musical instrument consisting of spiraling bronze bells that will play the patriotic melody of "My Country, 'Tis of Thee" from a height of over 22 feet.

The inspiration behind "Let Freedom Ring" comes from the iconic 1939 performance of "My Country, 'Tis of Thee" by black opera singer Marian Anderson at the Lincoln Memorial. This performance represented a story of unity and democracy, as Anderson overcame adversity to share her incredible talent. Paul Ramírez Jonas pays homage to this moment by inviting the public to complete the song themselves. By pulling a lever, participants will trigger a 600-pound bell inscribed with "Let Freedom Ring" to strike the final note of the song. It will be a powerful and immersive experience that both you can hear and feel.

This incredible initiative, known as "Pulling Together," is the first exhibition of the Beyond Granite initiative, which aims to make the National Mall a more inclusive space. The exhibition features six projects by talented artists, including Derrick Adams, Tiffany Chung, Ashon T. Crawley, Vanessa German, and Wendy Red Star. Together, they explore stories that have been untold on the National Mall.

We want everyone to feel welcome and participate in the installation. Located near the Smithsonian National Museum of American History, the installation will be visible to over 60,000 people daily. As you pass by on the overpass above the 12th Street Expressway, accessible from the Smithsonian metro stop, we invite you to complete "America" and be a part of this ever-changing country's story.

The design of "Let Freedom Ring" is a beautiful blend of tradition and creativity. Consisting of gothic arch-like steel beams, it supports a vertical pillar holding 32 small bronze bells arranged in a spiral, with a larger bell anchored to the ground. The form of the installation was influenced by the physics of suspending heavy bells and the need to adhere to safety requirements. It even references church bell towers, which adds to its timeless charm.

At the heart of this installation is the belief in the power of promises and commitments. By engaging the public and encouraging reflection and personal connections, "Let Freedom Ring" aims to build trust and bring people together. We hope you'll join us in experiencing this extraordinary display and become a part of its powerful message.

"Let Freedom Ring" is made possible by the Mellon Foundation and is co-curated by Paul Farber, director of Monument Lab, and Salamishah Tillet, a Pulitzer Prize-winning professor. Together, they are reshaping the narrative of the National Mall and challenging the lack of diversity in its current monuments.

Come and be a part of history as we build a more inclusive and meaningful commemorative landscape together. Let freedom ring, and let your voice be heard. END

These spaces come together to showcase the diverse and sprawling nature of our industrial city. They also raise important questions about public spaces, trust, fear, and the role of civic monuments.

Ramírez Jonas explains, "We take a symbolic key to the city and actually use it to open places that represent the city. Instead of it being limited to a privileged few, now anyone can give the key to whomever they want, for any reason they want."

Ramírez Jonas believes that this project is about more than just monuments. It's about fostering deeper connections and ownership of civic symbols. Discover the Exciting Innovations of NYC Urban Design Course!

Imagine a bustling subway stop in the heart of Long Island City, just across the East River from the iconic Midtown Manhattan. This elevated platform, known as Queensboro Plaza, may seem like a steel and concrete jungle at first glance. Pedestrians navigate the busy boulevard below, hoping to cross safely amidst the fast-moving cars and trucks. Above, the constant rumble of trains creates a symphony of sound. But amidst this urban chaos, a group of passionate students from Cornell University's Department of City and Regional Planning, along with faculty and students from Cornell Tech, have embarked on a groundbreaking journey to transform this space.

In their pilot course called Urban Design Strategies and Case Studies, these visionary students have harnessed the power of technology to recapture the essence of humanity in urban design. Using augmented reality (AR) and virtual reality (VR), they have created a tangible world, making New York City their laboratory for exploration and innovation.

Led by Robert Balder, Executive Director of the Gensler Family AAP NYC, and co-instructor Sharon Yavo Ayalon, the students partnered with various New York City business improvement districts (BIDs) including Long Island City Partnership, Flatiron/23rd Street Partnership, Village Alliance, and Downtown Brooklyn Partnership. Each team focused on a specific district, conducting thorough research to devise strategies that would make these areas more inviting, safer, and vibrant.

For the Long Island City team, their proposal included pedestrian-friendly walkways with enhanced lighting and safety measures. They envisioned a space where people could find respite during their lunch breaks, surrounded by art installations, comfortable benches, and a breathtaking view. Using the Unity game engine, which they learned during the course, the team created a captivating virtual reality demonstration showcasing the different phases of their project. This immersive experience allowed stakeholders to better understand how their intervention could truly transform the urban environment for pedestrians.

Meanwhile, the Flatiron/23rd Street Partnership focused on blending technology and art to illuminate historic buildings along the Broadway corridor. By using AR on smartphones, they aimed to attract more foot traffic to local restaurants and shops, while also highlighting the architectural beauty of the area. Their innovative approach aimed to create a vibrant atmosphere, promote local businesses, and ensure pedestrian safety.

A strategic approach was taken by the Village Alliance team, whose mission was to empower community members along the University Place corridor. Instead of simply asking people what they wanted, this team sought to provide resources for self-organized projects that would benefit the community. They developed a gamified mobile application called the "Village Alliance App." This app allows individuals to crowdfund pop-up projects, provide personalized reviews for street infrastructure, and connect with other visitors, businesses, and local authorities. By giving the community the tools to take ownership, the team aimed to foster active engagement and create a vibrant, thriving neighborhood.

Lastly, in the heart of Downtown Brooklyn, another team noticed the area's revitalization as new residents moved in. To celebrate this renaissance, they created a wayfinding application called "Midday in Brooklyn." This app utilizes AR to showcase the history, present, and future of the borough. Through this engaging and informative experience, users can delve into Brooklyn's rich heritage, gain insights into its current offerings, and catch a glimpse of its exciting future.

Indeed, the field of urban design is ever-evolving, and technology plays a crucial role in its adaptation. Tools like VR/AR, 3D modeling and printing, as well as simulations of light, temperature, and sound, have the power to revolutionize the way we plan and design our environments. As Sharon Yavo Ayalon aptly states, "These advanced tools, combined with platforms like Unity, enable us to create better-balanced and more sustainable spaces."

The efforts of these determined students and their faculty mentors are a testament to the power of technology in recapturing the essence of humanity in urban design. Through their innovative ideas and immersive demonstrations, they have paved the way for a brighter, more inclusive, and harmonious cityscape.

Source: "NYC Urban Design Course: Technology Recaptures Humanity" by Blaine Friedlander, May 27, 2021. END

completion:
Discover how to build sustainable cities at an exciting workshop in NYC! Today, engineers, architects, and urban planners face unprecedented challenges such as deteriorating infrastructure, rising sea levels, and extreme weather events. On May 23rd, over 60 people gathered at the College of Architecture, Art, and Planning's studio space in New York City to explore how our built environments can help us meet these challenges head-on.

The workshop, called "Rebuilding the Built Environment," was organized by Cornell's Atkinson Center for a Sustainable Future and AAP NYC. Kieran Donaghy, the Atkinson Center's faculty director of economic development, emphasized the need for physical, social, and economic resilience in our designs. Cities and infrastructure must adapt to changing patterns of settlement and production while preserving cultural and natural values, all while being economically sustainable.

The goal of the workshop was to bring together academics, design and engineering professionals, and civic leaders to rethink how we rebuild our environments. To make this a reality, Donaghy and Robert Balder, the Gensler Family Sesquicentennial Executive Director of AAP NYC, organized a day of collaboration focused on five key topics: best-practice engineering responses to climate change, large-scale developments that prioritize social equity and environmental integrity, government infrastructure policies, financing infrastructural investments, and identifying research opportunities and collaborative opportunities.

Each panel discussion was moderated and allowed stakeholders and university partners to share programmatic needs, best practices, and opportunities for collaboration. Balder acknowledged that although there are ongoing efforts to study new technologies and institutional arrangements to respond to 21st-century threats, many communities still face a double threat of decaying infrastructure and climate change impacts due to lack of reinvestment, outdated zoning, and weak financial incentives for private sector investments.

The workshop showcased inspiring projects like BuroHappold Engineering's work on a vision for New Jersey's Gateway National Recreation Area, which includes the restoration and protection of Jamaica Bay and its surroundings. Participants were also excited to learn about Rethink Studio's plan for a fully renovated Pennsylvania Station with an expanded regional rail network. Another notable project was a collaboration among Jonathan Rose Co., Handel Architects, and New York City's Department of Housing, Preservation, and Development on a new mixed-use development in East Harlem that will provide affordable housing and become one of the largest "passive house" projects in the world.

Balder emphasized the opportunity we have to create infrastructure and communities that not only meet current needs but also serve our social, environmental, and economic needs in the future. He hopes that workshop participants will continue the dialogue and remain committed to implementing long-term solutions.

New research conducted at Cornell University has revealed a fascinating discovery about volcanic eruptions. Contrary to previous beliefs, it is not water that triggers explosive volcanoes, but rather gaseous carbon dioxide. This finding has significant implications for our understanding of volcanic hazards and can greatly improve our planning for future eruptions.

Traditionally, geoscientists thought that shallow magma and water were responsible for driving volcanic eruptions. However, using innovative research tools developed at Cornell, scientists have found that basaltic volcanoes, typically located within tectonic plates, are actually fed by deep magma within the mantle, which is stored about 20 to 30 kilometers below the Earth's surface.

This new model provides us with a clearer picture of the Earth's internal dynamics and composition. The research, which was published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, signifies a shift in our understanding of volcanic eruptions. Senior author Esteban Gazel, an esteemed professor at Cornell, explains that previous volcanic models were dominated by the idea that water was the primary driver of eruptions, but the reality is that carbon dioxide plays a much bigger role.

The breakthrough in this research was made possible by the development of a high-precision carbon dioxide densimeter and a device called Raman spectroscopy. By examining microscopic carbon dioxide bubbles trapped in crystals from volcanic eruptions, scientists were able to gain insight into the history of the magma. This new technique allows for near real-time estimations of magma storage, which was successfully tested during the 2021 eruption in La Palma, in the Canary Islands.

The scientists also developed methods to accurately assess the effect of laser heating on carbon dioxide inclusions within crystals and to measure melt inclusion and bubble volumes. These advancements are crucial for gaining a better understanding of volcanic processes and improving our ability to predict eruptions.

Understanding the drivers of volcanic eruptions is essential for developing effective plans to mitigate volcanic hazards. Currently, the only way to observe these processes is through studying earthquakes, although they do not provide a complete picture. With precise measurements that reveal where eruptions start and how magma melts and is stored, we can develop more comprehensive strategies for future eruptions.

The research team, led by Esteban Gazel and Charlotte Devitre, collaborated with scientists from various institutions worldwide. The study, titled "Oceanic Intraplate Explosive Eruptions Fed Directly from the Mantle," was also supported by funding from the National Science Foundation.

Exciting Progress in the Battle to Save Fall Creek Hemlocks

In the fight against an invasive pest wreaking havoc on hemlocks in Fall Creek and across Eastern North America, researchers have discovered a potential solution in the form of a tiny fly and a helpful beetle. These amazing creatures, no larger than a grain of rice, may hold the key to combating the Hemlock Woolly Adelgid, one of the biggest threats to hemlock populations.

The Cornell Botanic Gardens, in collaboration with Cornell's New York State Hemlock Initiative, recently released 700 silver flies in the Fall Creek South Natural Area. This release follows the introduction of beetles in that same area last year. By bringing both species together in this specific location, researchers are eager to understand if they can effectively fight the Hemlock Woolly Adelgid.

This aphid-like species feeds on hemlock branches, disrupting the tree's ability to transport vital nutrients to its canopy. If left unchecked, the Hemlock Woolly Adelgid has the potential to devastate the hemlock forests, including those in Fall Creek. These majestic trees, ranging from saplings to centuries-old giants, play a crucial role in maintaining the area's hydrology, temperature, and biodiversity.

Todd Bittner, the Director of Natural Areas for Cornell Botanic Gardens, emphasizes the importance of hemlocks in preserving the ecosystem and supporting the diverse array of plants and animals that call it home. Their dense canopy provides a cool and shaded habitat for specific species to thrive. Additionally, their branching roots filter water, improve water quality, and prevent soil erosion. The shade they create also delays snow melt, ensuring a steady flow of water for trout and other fish.

Both the beetle, Laricobius nigrinus, and the silver fly, Leucotaraxis piniperda, are native to the American Northwest and are well-suited for colder climates. These predators naturally hunt Hemlock Woolly Adelgids, and their ability to reproduce twice a year ensures a continuous supply of food as the pest population grows.

Nick Dietschler, a research support specialist from the Hemlock Initiative, explains the potential of these predators and their specialization in targeting the Hemlock Woolly Adelgid. As these species have evolved together, they are likely to find the same niches on the East Coast as they do in their native habitat.

To protect the hemlock trees, the Cornell Botanic Gardens' natural area stewards have implemented insecticide applications to over 2,000 trees across 15 natural areas. However, in preparation for introducing biocontrol agents, some hemlocks have been intentionally left untreated. This strategic decision ensures a stable population of Hemlock Woolly Adelgids, providing ample food for the predator species to establish themselves successfully.

The short-term goal is for the predators to remain in Fall Creek for three years, indicating their successful establishment. The silver fly, known for its strong flying ability, is expected to spread and assist hemlocks in the surrounding areas over time. While pesticide applications typically last five to seven years, the team plans to reassess the area in 2024 to determine if further applications are necessary after the biocontrol agents have been released.

The long-term conservation plan for Fall Creek will heavily depend on several factors, such as the establishment of predator populations, the Hemlock Woolly Adelgid populations, and the overall condition of the trees. Despite the uncertainties, the mission to preserve as many hemlock trees as possible remains steadfast. Todd Bittner believes that even if there are hundreds of hemlocks left in the area a century from now, it will be considered a success.

With the combined efforts of researchers, the Cornell Botanic Gardens, and the natural area stewards, there is hope for the survival of the iconic hemlocks in Fall Creek and the restoration of balance to this vital ecosystem. END

New Study Shows How Small Lakes and Ponds Impact Climate Predictions

Did you know that there could be billions of small lakes and ponds on Earth? However, due to a lack of mapping systems, it's hard to determine their exact number. What we do know is that these bodies of water emit significant amounts of greenhouse gases into the atmosphere. The problem is, we don't fully understand the emissions from these systems yet. 

But here's some good news: a recent study has made progress in measuring methane and carbon dioxide emissions from 30 small lakes and ponds in temperate areas of Europe and North America. The study revealed that the smallest and shallowest bodies of water show the greatest variability in emissions over time. This is a crucial step in improving climate models to predict emissions from inland waterbodies, and it highlights the need for further research on small waterbodies. 

"This study helps us understand what drives greenhouse gas concentrations and why some ponds have more variable concentrations," said Meredith Holgerson, an assistant professor of ecology and evolutionary biology. She is also the senior author of the study. Previously, Holgerson and her colleagues estimated that shallow lakes and ponds may contribute about 5% of global methane emissions. However, without accurate measurements from many water bodies, this number could vary significantly. 

It turns out that some lakes and ponds emit greenhouse gases in consistent amounts, while others are highly variable. Some ponds emit a lot, while others emit very little. Understanding these dynamics is crucial because carbon dioxide and methane are greenhouse gases that trap heat in the atmosphere. Methane, in particular, is 25 times more potent at heat trapping than carbon dioxide. 

To conduct the study, Holgerson and her collaborators at the Global Lake Ecological Observatory Network designed the research and enlisted the help of 16 study co-authors across Europe and North America. These co-authors collected gas samples from a total of 30 small ponds and lakes, which were then analyzed. Each body of water was sampled three times in three locations over the summers of 2018 and 2019. 

One key finding of the study was that the smaller the waterbody, the higher the emissions are likely to be. For carbon dioxide, samples were consistent throughout the waterbody, meaning researchers only needed to collect one sample to accurately predict the whole body of water. On the other hand, methane required samples from multiple locations to obtain accurate measurements. Shallow systems showed higher variability in methane emissions, suggesting that deeper water may prevent gases from rising to the surface. 

The presence of plant life in the water influenced the variability of carbon dioxide emissions over time, while water depth played a bigger role in methane emissions. Exciting Coincidence: Classic Weed Guide Gets an Update!

It's a remarkable story of fate! The renowned "Weeds of the Northeast" guide, written by a team of researchers from Cornell University, has finally received a well-deserved update. Since its first publication in 1997, this comprehensive identification guide has become a staple for botanists, home gardeners, landscape managers, allergists, and even pest control specialists, helping them identify invasive plant species in the region.

One of the popular perennial weeds featured in the guide is the ground ivy, also known as creeping charlie, which is commonly found in turfgrass. With over 500 species included in the original edition, the book has been a tremendous success, selling nearly 100,000 copies over the last 25 years and ranking as one of the top sellers for Cornell University Press.

However, times change, and so does the flora! In March, the press released a second edition of "Weeds of the Northeast," which adds more than 200 new species that have slowly invaded the region, including waterhemp, Japanese stiltgrass, and garlic mustard. The new edition also addresses previously omitted weeds, apologizing to the wild parsnip for its previous exclusion. Additionally, the book updates terminology and expands its coverage to include more species from the mid-Atlantic states and upper Midwest.

The creation of this updated edition is truly remarkable, thanks to an extraordinary coincidence. It's a tale of two ditommasos, Richard Uva and Joseph Ditomaso! Richard Uva, the author of the original edition, collaborated with faculty members from the departments of horticulture and crop, soil, and atmospheric sciences to develop the manuscript. They reached out to a network of researchers throughout the northeast to gather suggestions and color images of various weeds, ensuring the guide's accuracy and usefulness in the field.

Choosing which information to include in the book was no easy task. The team wanted to provide as much relevant information as possible while keeping the guide portable and user-friendly. Joseph Ditomaso, one of the team members, expressed his enthusiasm for including the wild parsnip, a common weed that surprisingly had not been mentioned in the first edition. It turns out that many others had noticed its absence too. The updated edition also features troublesome weeds like pigweed and lesser celandine, alongside familiar culprits such as swallowwort, kudzu, and common ragweed.

While these weeds can certainly be a nuisance to gardeners, Ditomaso hopes that "Weeds of the Northeast" will also foster an appreciation for them. He even uses both editions of the book in his weed biology and management course, making it a fitting resource. As an undergraduate and graduate student, Ditomaso relied on the first edition, so seeing his own name in the updated version brings him great joy. He humorously shares, "Now everybody I see here, it’s like, oh, yeah, this is my book. I’ve signed so many copies. Now I know what it feels like to be a star."

With the release of this updated edition, the "Weeds of the Northeast" guide continues to be an invaluable resource for anyone interested in identifying and managing invasive plant species. Its clear and comprehensive information, combined with the passion of the authors, ensures that it will remain a must-have for botanists, gardeners, and nature enthusiasts alike. END

This discovery has significant implications for tackling climate change and improving soil health for agriculture and food production. In fact, microbes are at least four times more crucial than any other process, including decomposition, when it comes to storing carbon in the soil.

Dr. Mario Gaudino, along with a team of scientists from multiple institutions, has received a generous funding award of nearly $30 million from the Patient-Centered Outcomes Research Institute (PCORI). This funding will support a groundbreaking study that focuses on comparing the benefits of two different heart procedures in underrepresented groups such as women, black, and Hispanic patients who suffer from coronary artery disease.

Coronary artery disease, which is the leading cause of death in the United States, occurs when the coronary arteries become narrow or blocked due to plaque buildup. Every year, over 1 million Americans undergo a procedure to restore normal blood flow to their hearts. One option is percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI), which is a minimally invasive procedure that uses stents placed in the coronary artery through a small incision in the groin or wrist. This procedure requires minimal anesthesia, and patients can typically return home the same day.

Another option is coronary artery bypass surgery (CABG), which is a more invasive procedure that involves opening the chest and may require the use of a heart-lung bypass machine. This surgery is performed under general anesthesia, and grafts are created using arteries or veins from the chest, arms, or legs to bypass the blocked coronary arteries. While CABG involves a longer hospital stay and recovery time, as well as higher rates of complications during surgery compared to PCI, it does offer longer-lasting benefits such as a reduced risk of heart attack and the need for additional interventions.

However, it is important to note that more than half of the patients facing a decision between PCI and CABG are women or individuals from racial groups that have been underrepresented in previous clinical trials. This lack of representation has left these patients with limited guidance when making an informed decision.

To address this issue, Dr. Gaudino, who is also a cardiothoracic surgeon at NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell Medical Center, will lead the Recharge (Revascularization Choices among Underrepresented Groups Evaluation) research program. This program will conduct two parallel clinical studies, Recharge Women and Recharge Minorities, with the goal of recruiting 600 participants at up to 60 study sites, primarily in the United States. Eligible patients, as determined by their local heart team, will be randomly assigned to receive either PCI or CABG. The trials will span over five years, following an 18-month feasibility phase.

Previous studies evaluating surgical options for coronary artery disease mainly focused on major adverse cardiac and cerebrovascular events, such as heart attacks, strokes, and the need for repeat procedures. However, Dr. Gaudino and his colleagues discovered through focus groups that what matters most to patients when choosing between PCI and CABG is survival and quality of life.

"Patients care most about living longer and better," said Dr. Gaudino, who is also the director of the Joint Clinical Trials Office and the director of Translational and Clinical Research in the Department of Cardiothoracic Surgery at Weill Cornell Medicine. He will oversee the Recharge program, including study startup and patient recruitment strategies. Dr. Gregg Stone, the co-principal investigator, will be responsible for data collection and analysis. Dr. Stone is the Director of Academic Affairs for the Mount Sinai Health System and a Professor of Medicine and Population Health Science and Policy at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai. END

In two separate publications, astronomers from the JWST's Early Release Science program have made exciting discoveries. They have detected hydrogen peroxide on Ganymede and sulfurous fumes on Io, both influenced by Jupiter's dominant presence.

Their findings, published in Science Advances on July 21, reveal the presence of hydrogen peroxide at Ganymede's poles. By analyzing measurements captured by the JWST's near infrared spectrometer, the team observed light absorption caused by charged particles from Jupiter and Ganymede impacting the ice covering the moon. This interaction alters the surface chemistry of Ganymede's polar caps. Dr. Trumbo explains, "This discovery shows for the first time that charged particles funneled along Ganymede's magnetic field are specifically affecting the surface chemistry of its poles."

The astronomers explain that the peroxide is produced when charged particles collide with the frozen water ice around the poles, breaking the water molecules into fragments. These fragments then recombine to form hydrogen peroxide. This process, known as radiolysis, is believed to occur primarily around the poles of Ganymede due to the moon's magnetic field, which directs charged particles towards those regions. Dr. Trumbo compares this phenomenon to Earth's magnetic field guiding charged particles from the sun to the highest latitudes, resulting in the aurora. Similarly, Ganymede's magnetic field influences charged particles from Jupiter's magnetosphere, leading to aurorae on Ganymede and impacting its icy surface.

Dr. Trumbo and Prof. Michael Brown from the California Institute of Technology also previously studied hydrogen peroxide on Europa, another of Jupiter's moons. However, they found that the peroxide was detectable over a larger portion of Europa's surface, possibly because Europa lacks a magnetic field to shield its surface from fast-moving particles near Jupiter. Dr. Trumbo suggests that these observations of Ganymede offer valuable insights into how water radiolysis influences chemistry on icy bodies throughout the outer solar system, including neighboring Europa and Callisto.

Io stands out as the only moon in the solar system with active volcanoes, thanks to the gravitational forces exerted by Jupiter. Studying Io's volcanic activity provides planetary scientists with unique perspectives that cannot be gained from studying Earth's volcanoes.

Lead author Prof. Imke de Pater, Professor Emerita of Astronomy and Earth and Planetary Science at the University of California, Berkeley, highlights the significance of these findings. She explains, "This demonstrates that the James Webb Space Telescope can contribute valuable scientific knowledge about solar system objects, even when observing very bright objects like Jupiter or very faint objects near Jupiter." Prof. de Pater and Thierry Fouchet from the Paris Observatory serve as co-principal investigators for the Early Release Science Solar System Observation Team, one of the 13 teams granted early access to the telescope.

This comprehensive study in healthy adults provides the strongest evidence to date of the link between omega-3 fatty acids and lung health. The researchers emphasize the importance of including omega-3 fatty acids in our diets, especially considering that many Americans do not meet the recommended guidelines.

Cassano, the Alan D. Mathios Professor in the College of Human Ecology and Director of the Division of Nutritional Sciences. This study adds to the growing evidence that omega-3 fatty acids, which are essential for a healthy diet, may also be important for maintaining lung health.

There is a growing interest in exploring if nutritional interventions can help prevent lung disease, according to the researchers. Previous studies have suggested that omega-3 fatty acids may be beneficial, primarily due to their anti-inflammatory properties, but robust studies on this association have been lacking. The strongest associations were observed for docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), an omega-3 fatty acid found in fatty fish like salmon, tuna, and sardines. DHA is also available as a dietary supplement.

In the second part of the study, the researchers analyzed genetic data from over 500,000 participants of European descent from the UK Biobank. They examined specific genetic markers in the blood as an indirect measure of dietary omega-3 fatty acid levels and their correlation with lung health. The results showed that higher levels of omega-3 fatty acids, including DHA, were associated with better lung function.

Here's how to harness the potential of highly reactive radical molecules to work in pairs and drive transformative chemistry: bulk them up! That's the approach of a new collaboration led by Cornell University. The researchers attached large fragments to these notoriously temperamental molecules, increasing their size to insulate them from their hyperreactive partners.

By adding groups of carbon and hydrogen atoms to the surface of these highly reactive radical molecules, they effectively gave each molecule a set of "antlers." This allowed the molecules to maintain their native reactivity while keeping their partner at a safe distance. This technique could be incredibly valuable for creating new and improved derivatives of pharmaceutical compounds.

This project, led by Professor Song Lin, emerged from the Lin group's previous experiments with synthetic electrochemistry. In that process, electrodes pass an electrical current through a chemical reaction to activate inert molecules and form chemical bonds that would otherwise be difficult to achieve. Electrochemistry is also one of the most efficient ways to generate highly reactive radicals from simple chemical feedstocks.

"We thought, hey, when we have these radicals, how can we control them as well? If we can harness them and use them to react with a pharmaceutical, they can do really cool chemistry," Lin explained. "It's our interest in electrochemistry and radical chemistry that allowed us to think about these fundamental problems."

Radicals are highly reactive, but they have the potential to bond in pairs by sharing a pair of single electrons. The challenge lies in getting them close enough to cooperate without destroying each other. The researchers' solution was to bulk up the radicals by attaching groups of carbon and hydrogen atoms to their surface, effectively frustrating them. This allowed the radicals to preserve their reactivity while maintaining a safe distance from their partner.

"We use frustrated radicals to activate carbon-hydrogen bonds and convert them into other chemical bonds, which can alter the properties of the original molecule," Lin said. "This strategy can be used to improve the efficacy of drug molecules, for example."

Lin's group collaborated with researchers from the San Francisco-based company Genentech to identify substrate targets that would enable the desired chemical reactions. They installed large functional groups on the frustrated radicals, such as trimethylsilyl, to control reactivity. It can assist in derivatizing more efficient pharmaceutical products, enhancing their biological activity, and even tracking how drugs degrade in the human body.

For many years, the financial press has been a valuable source of information for investors of all kinds. However, researchers from Cornell University have discovered that it can also be incredibly helpful for improving the algorithm behind a new financial prediction model.

In their recent paper titled "News-Based Sparse Machine Learning Models for Adaptive Asset Pricing," which was published in Data Science in April, the researchers combine expertise from machine learning, natural language processing (NLP), and finance to develop a new and easily understandable machine learning framework. This framework captures specific information about stocks and industries, allowing for more accurate predictions of financial returns compared to traditional models.

Lead author Liao Zhu, who is now working in the finance industry, explains that the text helps to organize and understand the chaotic results that algorithms can sometimes produce. The researchers hypothesize that financial news can provide valuable insights into which stocks are related to certain tradable assets.

This paper builds upon Zhu's previous research conducted during his early doctoral studies. He worked alongside Wells and Robert Jarrow, esteemed experts in investment management at Cornell University. Co-author Peter Wu also contributed to this groundbreaking research.

While it is not new to apply traditional statistical methods to market data in order to explain stock returns, nor is it new to analyze texts for sentiment analysis, this research takes a different approach. It introduces a flexible prediction framework that combines market data and text data without relying on sentiment analysis. Instead, it utilizes interpretable machine learning algorithms.

To achieve this, the researchers adopted the concept of "word embeddings" from natural language processing and applied it to financial news to create "asset embeddings" for specific tradable assets. By converting both text and market data into numerical form, the researchers were able to develop custom-designed algorithms to analyze the data.

Zhu clarifies that their algorithm does not rely on sentiment from the news, but rather uses it as a guide to determine which assets and words to consider for each specific stock or industry. This reveals more precise information about stocks and industries.

In order to develop their models, the researchers collected a vast amount of online financial news articles from 2013 to 2019 and fed them into their algorithm. This allowed them to map out specific assets and words associated with particular stocks and industries. Armed with an AI-optimized language map, the researchers gained invaluable insight into which assets and words to focus on.

Using this innovative approach, the team created two separate models. The first is called the News Embedding UMAP Sparse Selection (NEUSS) model, which predicts returns for individual stocks. The second model, the News Sparse Encoder with Rationale (INSER) model, identifies important words for each specific industry and uses them to make more accurate predictions about industry returns.

For example, the NEUSS model may conclude from financial news that an exchange-traded fund (ETF) tracking the semiconductor manufacturing sector is useful in predicting the stock returns of a particular tech company. However, it may not be as useful in predicting returns for other stocks in industries like retail or wholesale. On the other hand, the INSER model may identify the word "plant" as significant in the energy industry, but this word may not hold the same relevance for other industries such as social media.

Overall, this research demonstrates the value of incorporating financial news into machine learning models for predicting financial returns. By bridging the gap between market data and text data, the researchers have developed a more accurate and interpretable framework that can enhance investment decisions. END

Cornell's researchers have developed an innovative method to reveal the intricate nanotextures in thin-film materials using high-powered x-rays, phase-retrieval algorithms, and machine learning. This breakthrough offers scientists a streamlined approach to analyze potential candidates for quantum computing and microelectronics, among other applications. 

Scientists are particularly interested in nanotextures that are distributed non-uniformly throughout a thin film because they can give the material unique properties. Traditionally, studying these nanotextures required complex electron microscopy, which often did not preserve the sample. However, the new imaging technique, detailed in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, overcomes these challenges.

By utilizing phase retrieval and machine learning, the researchers can now transform conventionally-collected x-ray diffraction data, such as that produced at the Cornell High Energy Synchrotron Source, into real-space visualizations of the material at the nanoscale. This use of x-ray diffraction not only makes the technique more accessible to scientists but also allows for imaging a larger portion of the sample.

According to Andrej Singer, assistant professor of materials science and engineering and David Croll Sesquicentennial Faculty Fellow in Cornell Engineering, "Imaging a large area is crucial as it represents the true state of the material. The nanotexture measured by a local probe could depend on the chosen spot."

Another advantage of this new method is that it does not require breaking apart the sample, enabling dynamic studies of thin films. For example, introducing light to observe how structures evolve becomes possible. Ziming Shao, a doctoral student involved in the research, stated, "This method can be readily applied to study dynamics in-situ or operando. For example, we plan to use the method to study how the structure changes within picoseconds after excitation with short laser pulses, which might enable new concepts for future terahertz technologies." 

The effectiveness of this technique was demonstrated through testing on two thin films. In one instance, the researchers successfully validated the imaging results by studying a thin film with a known nanotexture. Additionally, when exploring a mott insulator film associated with superconductivity, they discovered a previously unseen strain-induced nanopattern that forms naturally during cooling to cryogenic temperatures.

Ziming Shao emphasized the significance of the findings, stating, "The images are extracted without prior knowledge, potentially setting new benchmarks and informing novel physical hypotheses in phase-field modeling, molecular dynamics simulations, and quantum mechanical calculations."

The research team included co-authors Lena Kourkoutis, the late associate professor of applied and engineering physics, Kyle Shen, the James A. Weeks Professor of Physical Sciences in the College of Arts and Sciences, Darrell Schlom, the Herbert Fisk Johnson Professor of Industrial Chemistry and Tisch University Professor in the Department of Materials Science and Engineering, and Hari Nair, assistant research professor of materials science and engineering.

This research was made possible with support from the U.S. Department of Energy and the National Science Foundation. END

In simple terms, a pair-density wave is like a stationary dance of paired electrons in a superconductor. These pairs form periodic crystalline patterns in space. Gu's team at Cornell, who invented the scanning Josephson tunnelling microscope, were the first to observe a pair-density wave in 2016. This new quantum matter state, known as a topological pair density wave, is composed of spin-triplet Cooper pairs.

Cooper-pair density waves differ from conventional superconductors as pairs of electrons freeze into a superconductive state rather than freely moving. Gu describes the discovery of the first pair-density wave in spin-triplet superconductors as exciting. Uranium-based heavy fermion superconducting compounds provide a promising platform for realizing topological superconductivity. This discovery also indicates that this intriguing quantum state exists in a variety of superconductors, opening up new possibilities for studying these states in different materials.
