We are thrilled to announce that Weill Cornell Medicine and Columbia University have been awarded a generous five-year grant of $9.8 million from the National Cancer Institute (NCI), a division of the National Institutes of Health. This grant will enable us to take significant steps in combating cancer disparities that are influenced by persistent poverty.

Our collaboration, which includes faculty members from Weill Cornell Medicine, Columbia University Mailman School of Public Health, Columbia University School of Nursing, and SUNY Downstate Health Sciences University, will establish a specialized research center and lead two major projects in four communities of persistent poverty in New York City.

The NCI sought to support centers that come up with innovative ways to close health equity gaps, and we are proud to be a part of that effort. While we may not be able to eliminate persistent poverty entirely, we can certainly make a difference in how it affects cancer outcomes.

The overall center will be led by a remarkable team of investigators, including Dr. Erica Phillips from Weill Cornell Medicine, and Mary Beth Terry and Phoenix Matthews from Columbia University. This initiative builds upon important collaborations between Columbia and Weill Cornell Medicine in reducing the cancer burden, which is particularly crucial as cancer remains the leading cause of premature mortality in New York City.

Through the grant, Weill Cornell Medicine's Center for Social Capital (SoCa) will embark on two complementary projects focused on promoting multi-generational cancer awareness and health in the South Bronx, North-Central Brooklyn, Washington Heights, and Western Queens. We will work closely with community partners to achieve our goals.

The first project, led by Dr. Phillips, will assess the impact of a six-week cancer education and social justice curriculum among middle school students in ten New York City public schools. This curriculum, taught by the schools' primary science teachers, will cover various aspects of cancer prevention and control through the lens of social justice, media literacy, tobacco advertising, nutrition, cancer genetics, biotechnology, and risk reduction. We will collaborate closely with Columbia investigators and the national nonprofit Math for America to enhance STEM instruction in these schools.

"As poverty often spans generations and is linked to unemployment, it is crucial to expose children to STEM careers to ensure their future success and leadership," Dr. Phillips emphasized.

The second project, led by Professor Matthews from Columbia's School of Nursing, will implement an innovative tobacco cessation trial using federally qualified health centers and patient portal technology. Our team will work directly with safety-net healthcare clinics to increase patient awareness of free smoking cessation treatments offered by the New York State Tobacco Quitline. Through an established patient portal, we will communicate directly with patients, supporting them in their efforts to quit smoking.

"Addressing smoking-related health inequalities among economically disadvantaged patients remains a top public health priority," explained Professor Matthews. "Low-income patients face numerous barriers when seeking affordable and effective smoking cessation treatments. Our approach aims to empower safety-net clinics to provide evidence-based smoking cessation counseling in a cost-effective and provider-friendly manner."

Furthermore, our team will develop a capacity-building program that accelerates the research funding and academic promotion of pre-faculty investigators dedicated to studying cancer health disparities in impoverished communities.

We are extremely grateful for this grant from the NCI, as it allows us to make a real impact on cancer disparities fueled by persistent poverty. Together, we can work towards a future where everyone has equal access to quality healthcare and the opportunity for a healthy life. END

These waves are likely caused by pairs of supermassive black holes merging. This discovery is a result of the North American Nanohertz Observatory for Gravitational Waves (NANOGrav) Physics Frontiers Center's research. They had previously detected hints of these waves, but the signal was too faint to confirm their existence. However, now, after 15 years of observations using radio telescopes and rapidly spinning pulsars, they have compelling evidence of gravitational waves that last for years to decades.

The detection and ongoing measurements of these waves will greatly advance our understanding of the universe's evolution on both large and small scales. This includes gaining insights into how often galaxies collide, what drives black hole mergers, and even the fundamental nature of gravity itself.

The newly detected gravitational waves are different from the ones detected in 2015 by the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO). The earlier waves were high-frequency and created by the collision of black holes that were 30 times more massive than the sun. In contrast, the waves discovered by NANOGrav are low-frequency and likely generated by orbiting pairs of the universe's most massive black holes. These black holes can be millions or billions of times more massive than the sun and have sizes larger than the distance between the Earth and the sun.

Supported by the National Science Foundation, NANOGrav collected data using various observatories, including the Arecibo Observatory in Puerto Rico (prior to its collapse in 2020), the Green Bank Telescope in West Virginia, and the Very Large Array in New Mexico. These ground-based observatories measured radio waves emitted by a network of 68 pulsars located within a few thousand light years of Earth. Pulsars are ultra-dense remnants of massive stars that emit beams of radio waves at precise intervals, similar to a lighthouse beacon.

One of the researchers involved in this project, Thankful Cromartie, highlighted the significance of millisecond pulsars, stating that they not only provide insights into astrophysics but also allow for the study of various physics phenomena, from gravitational waves to the behavior of matter in neutron star cores. The precision of measurements obtained from these pulsars is remarkable, approaching atomic-clock precision.

The NANOGrav collaboration's discovery of low-frequency gravitational waves is a significant breakthrough. This was made possible through 15 years of pulsar observations, effectively turning the Milky Way into a gravitational wave detector on a galactic scale. These waves cause slight deviations in the timing of pulsar beams as they stretch and compress the space between the pulsars and Earth. The researchers found consistent correlations in these timing deviations, confirming the presence of gravitational waves. Interestingly, the waves were detected as a background "hum" rather than originating from a single source. It's like hearing overlapping voices in a crowd or instruments in an orchestra.

As the measurements continue to improve, the NANOGrav project expects to identify individual pairs of supermassive black holes for further investigation. In celebration of International Women's Day, we want to introduce you to five inspiring women who are making a significant impact on the world economy. It's incredible to think that there are now over 413 million women entrepreneurs globally, a far cry from when the idea of women in business was once unthinkable.

completion:
At Shopify, we understand the importance of taking action to protect our planet and reverse climate change. While stopping emissions alone won't be enough, we recognize that there is still a significant amount of carbon in the atmosphere. We believe that no single solution can solve this problem on its own. That's why we are dedicated to scaling carbon removal technologies and putting in the necessary work.

Since we introduced our sustainability fund in 2019, we have been actively investing in carbon removal initiatives to support the growth of this emerging industry. Today, we are thrilled to announce that, together with Stripe, we are investing $11 million in carbon removal from six new companies: Arbor, Captura, Carbon to Stone, Cella, Crew, and Inplanet. This marks an exciting development in our efforts to reverse climate change, and we are inspired by the caliber and number of new companies entering the market.

Through these investments, we are providing these companies with the opportunity to demonstrate their impact and expand their operations. With the addition of these six new partners, Shopify has now backed a total of 28 companies. You can learn more about each of these new partners below.

These recent investments are just one part of the important work we have been doing this year to accelerate the carbon removal market. In 2022, our sustainability fund added nine new businesses to our portfolio, helping them bring their visions to life and increase adoption of their offerings. Through our fund activities, we have helped multiple companies raise over $50 million in capital and significantly expand their workforce, enabling them to grow their carbon removal capacity by over 1000x.

In the spring, we launched Frontier, an advance market commitment (AMC), alongside Stripe, Alphabet, Meta, and McKinsey Sustainability. As founders of Frontier, we committed to investing a combined $925 million in carbon removal by the end of 2030. This commitment stands as a signal to innovators, investors, and project developers that there is a viable market for carbon removal, and we must all work together to scale the industry.

In June, we released Planet, an app that enables Shopify merchants to offset their shipping emissions. Planet calculates the estimated shipping emissions for each order, and merchants can fund the same carbon removal companies supported by Shopify to neutralize these emissions. Since its launch, over 8,000 Shopify merchants have used Planet to offset the shipping emissions of more than six million orders, resulting in over 5,000 tonnes of carbon removal.

To further support the adoption of carbon removal, we recently published a comprehensive guide called "Buying Carbon Removal, Explained." This guide covers everything from researching suppliers to establishing carbon removal contracts and addressing concerns from finance teams. We are committed to generating demand for carbon removal, enabling new companies to prove their impact and scale, and investing millions each year to drive down future prices.

I recently had the privilege of speaking about these initiatives at the TED Countdown London session. You can watch my talk at go.ted.com/stacykauk. That's all for now. Make sure to subscribe to our mailing list for updates from us in 2023. We have even more planned for the new year as we continue our important work. END

When it comes to paying people for their work, it should be a simple process. However, for tech companies, it can be a bit more complicated. Typically, the process involves extending a job offer, the employee accepting it, and then being paid according to the agreement. Unfortunately, this often results in a confusing mess of paystubs, equity portals, and benefits portals.

At Shopify, we realized that this outdated system no longer made sense. We saw an opportunity to revolutionize compensation and create a better story. That's why we developed Flex Comp, an approach that changes how we reward talent, not just within Shopify, but beyond as well.

Flex Comp is built on three key elements: agency, clarity, and impact. We believe that employees should have agency over their total reward package. Why should a company decide how much should be in cash or equity? Now, our employees have the power to choose how they want to allocate their rewards. Whether they want to save for a house or focus on their career growth, they have the flexibility to make those decisions. We've also eliminated the one-year cliff on equity, so vesting begins immediately. And, to accommodate life's changes, we offer allocation windows a few times a year, allowing employees to adjust their choices as needed.

Clarity is another crucial aspect of Flex Comp. In the past, understanding how much you earned was a tedious process, involving multiple sources of information and complex calculations. With our user-friendly design, all aspects of total rewards are clearly laid out in one place. Now, employees have a simple and straightforward way to understand their pay.

Lastly, we believe that rewards should be tied to our mission, not external factors like market value or world events. As employees contribute to our mission and advance in their careers, their compensation will grow accordingly. We have a vision for what can exist, and we are committed to building it.

Developing Flex Comp was no easy task. We had to navigate industry-wide challenges, such as compensation tied to market value and salary disparities across different locations. However, we embrace challenges at Shopify. We set a bold vision and then work tirelessly to make it a reality. Our dedicated team, consisting of individuals from various departments, came together to bring this massive overhaul to life. Their hard work and commitment paid off, and we now have a system that works for all employees, regardless of their roles, locations, or unique needs. And we continue to innovate and improve, with room for future enhancements.

At Shopify, we believe in rewriting the story of compensation. With Flex Comp, we have created a fair and transparent system that empowers our employees and aligns with our mission. We are excited to lead the way in defining the future of compensation, not just for ourselves, but for the entire industry. END

Dear friends,

At Shopify, we have always been clear about our stance on climate change. Since introducing our sustainability fund in 2019, we have been committed to fighting this global issue together. While reducing emissions is crucial, it's important to remember that even if we stopped all emissions right now, there would still be too much carbon in our atmosphere. It's imperative that we start working on innovative climate-saving technologies to protect our future.

That's why we are excited to announce the launch of a much-needed advance market commitment (AMC) called Frontier, in collaboration with Stripe, Alphabet, Meta, and McKinsey Sustainability. The AMC model has proven successful in the past, specifically in speeding up the development of vaccines for low-income countries, saving countless lives. We are now applying this model to carbon removal at scale, making us the pioneers in this field.

As the founders of Frontier, we are committed to investing a combined initial sum of $925 million over the next nine years, starting in 2022, to purchase permanent carbon removal from companies that are developing promising solutions. Our collective demand will provide the market with the push it needs to accelerate the development of carbon removal technologies. We are truly proud to be part of Frontier and its founder advisory board.

Let me provide more details on how the AMC will work and how you can get involved. The commitment is designed to support and scale new technologies with long-term potential. We understand that this may mean paying higher prices per tonne initially. However, it will enable us to speed up the development of promising technologies that meet specific criteria, such as permanence, physical footprint, cost, capacity, and environmental justice outcomes.

Frontier is Shopify's next major step in our fight against climate change. Since launching our sustainability fund in 2019, we have made significant progress by supporting carbon removal solutions and partnering with 22 entrepreneurial, tech-driven companies. We have already committed over $32 million to climate entrepreneurs. Our support has helped our climate-forward partners, such as Carbon Engineering, Charm Industrial, Heirloom Carbon, Planetary Hydrogen, and Running Tide, raise millions of dollars, increase their carbon removal capacity, and expand their customer bases.

While our efforts have demonstrated voluntary market demand, we recognize that we cannot tackle carbon removal alone. That's why we are thrilled about the possibilities that Frontier brings to the carbon removal market. Our aim is to remove barriers and enable other companies to easily purchase carbon removal, establish high-quality standards, and play a leading role in scaling the carbon removal companies selected by Frontier.

Are you interested in joining us? Find out how to become an early Frontier buyer and help accelerate this historic carbon removal initiative at frontierclimate.com.

Together, we can make a real difference in the fight against climate change.

Warm regards,

Stacy Kauk
Head of Sustainability at Shopify END

completion:
What is "maskne"? Maskne, scientifically known as acne mechanica, is a type of acne that occurs due to excessive friction, heat, and rubbing on the skin. It is commonly experienced by athletes who have to wear masks and straps for long periods. However, with the arrival of COVID-19, maskne has become more common as wearing face coverings has become a necessary part of our daily lives.

Why does your mask cause breakouts? Acne bacteria, known as propionibacterium acnes or p. acnes, naturally exists on everyone's skin. Although it may not sound pleasant, these bacteria is a normal part of our body's natural microbiome. Normally, acne bacteria coexists peacefully with other bacteria, but when it starts to colonize in the pores and hair follicles and feed on dead skin and oil, it can lead to an acne breakout. Sweating and the humidity created by breathing into your mask provide an ideal environment for p. acnes bacteria to grow. Masks can also increase the risk of clogged pores and breakouts because they act as a barrier, not allowing the skin to "breathe" and trapping oil, sweat, dirt, and makeup in the pores. Prolonged mask-wearing can cause friction on the skin, leading to inflammation and irritation, making it more susceptible to infection. All of this can be detrimental to maintaining clear skin.

So, what can you do to prevent maskne? 
1. The CDC recommends wearing cloth face coverings to reduce the spread of COVID-19 to others. Opt for 100% cotton masks as they are effective and breathable, reducing sweat and moisture on the skin.
2. Wash your masks frequently to remove sweat, oil, and dirt buildup.
3. Reevaluate your skincare routine and products. The occlusion caused by the mask can deliver active ingredients like retinols and acids deeper into the skin, increasing the risk of compromising your moisture barrier and causing irritation and breakouts. Only apply such products at night and reduce or stop usage if irritation occurs. A simpler skincare routine might be more suitable if you have to wear a mask for extended periods.
4. Keep your skin well-moisturized to decrease friction from the mask.
5. Take a break from wearing makeup. Since the lower half of your face will be covered by the mask, consider skipping foundation or concealer in that area to eliminate one more factor that could clog your pores. If you still desire coverage, try using a tinted moisturizer.
6. Wash your face with a gentle cleanser every night to remove makeup, oil, and dirt that have accumulated throughout the day. Follow it up with a hydrating moisturizer.
7. When required to wear a mask for a long time, keep several clean masks with you and switch them out periodically.
8. Stay hydrated by drinking plenty of water. Hydration is essential for healthy skin.
9. Reduce stress whenever possible. Stress is one of the main triggers for acne, and acne itself can cause more stress, creating a vicious cycle. Finding ways to decompress is crucial, especially during this challenging time, for both your skin and overall health.
10. If you experience rashes, allergic reactions, or severe acne, consult your dermatologist for professional advice and assistance.

By following these tips, you can proactively prevent and manage maskne, ensuring your skin stays healthy and clear. END

To keep up with the rapidly changing world of commerce, our merchants need to provide the best shopping experience possible for their customers. We're excited to announce that we've made this easier by releasing subscription and post-purchase upsell apps that are now fully integrated with Shopify checkout for the first time.

This means that merchants can seamlessly sell subscription products and offer post-purchase upsells directly within Shopify checkout. By adding these new capabilities, we're making our conversion-optimized checkout even more flexible. Our checkout has been tried and tested with over 2.5 billion transactions in 175 countries, so you can trust that it's reliable.

Not only are these new apps fully integrated with our back-office, but merchants can also manage orders and use features like Shopify Payments all within the Shopify platform. We've seen a growing demand for fully integrated subscription and upsell apps, with a 61% increase from 2019 to 2020. In the past year, we've worked closely with our partners to improve the overall subscription management and buyer experience.

By taking advantage of these new app offerings, merchants can tap into the ecommerce recurring payment and subscriptions market, which is projected to reach $478 billion by 2025. Similarly, demand for post-purchase upsell apps on Shopify has also increased. By presenting offers after payment is confirmed, merchants can offer one-click product upsells without impacting conversion rates or interrupting the customer experience.

Jean-Michel Lemieux, CTO of Shopify, has emphasized the importance of the checkout experience, stating that it's been a top priority for over a decade. With these new apps, over 1 million merchants worldwide can sell recurring products and add post-purchase upsells, all without compromising the buyer experience at checkout. We believe in the value of these apps to enable flexibility, scale, and resilience for our merchants, which is why we're giving our developer partners the ability to build integrated solutions within checkout.

Before today, Shopify merchants could offer subscriptions and post-purchase upsells using apps that weren't fully integrated with our checkout and platform. But now, merchants can easily download these fully integrated apps from the Shopify app store to deliver smooth buying experiences. If merchants prefer, subscription APIs are also available for them to build custom solutions.

Regardless of which app merchants choose to install, all their orders and customer data will be securely kept within Shopify. This means that merchants can manage all their transactions in one place, gain valuable insights, and take advantage of our platform features like shipping, discounts, and more.

These new integrated subscriptions and post-purchase upsell offerings are just the beginning. They join over 5,300 publicly available apps in the Shopify ecosystem, and we're excited to see our partners continue building more integrated apps in these categories to meet the future needs of merchants and buyers. END

completion:
Budget 2023: Supporting Nuclear Power in Canada's Clean Energy Strategy

On March 28, 2023, the Government of Canada announced Budget 2023, which demonstrates its strong and clear support for nuclear power in the country's transition to clean energy while ensuring energy security. Nuclear power will play an indispensable role in this transition.

To create a level playing field for clean energy technologies, nuclear power is now eligible for a range of tax incentives in addition to being included in the clean energy investment tax credit. This allows nuclear power to compete fairly with other non-emitting sources of power.

John Gorman, President and CEO of the Canadian Nuclear Association, stated, "Today's budget signals a significant change in how the federal government is approaching nuclear power in Canada. It is no longer just an option, but instead recognized as a fundamental and necessary component of our low carbon energy system."

A new 15% refundable investment tax credit has been introduced for clean electricity, which can be applied to all sizes of nuclear power projects, including small modular reactors (SMRs), large builds, and refurbishment projects. This tax credit will be available to both public and privately owned entities, addressing concerns raised by the Canadian Nuclear Association regarding tax credits for crown corporations. It also applies to equipment that enables the transmission of electricity between provinces and territories.

Furthermore, today's budget includes a 30% investment tax credit for clean technology manufacturing, covering the manufacturing of nuclear energy equipment and the processing or recycling of nuclear fuels. This credit also supports the extraction, processing, or recycling of critical minerals.

The budget provides additional support for nuclear power, including the extension of reduced tax rates for zero-emission technology manufacturers, increased funding for regulatory reviews and approvals, and the partnership between the Canada Growth Fund and the public sector pension investment board to attract private capital to the clean economy. It also allocates $500 million over ten years to the Strategic Innovation Fund, which has previously supported SMR projects by companies like Moltex, Westinghouse, and Terrestrial Energy.

In addition to supporting nuclear power, the budget also focuses on accelerating Canada's clean energy transition in sectors like transportation, buildings, industry, and hydrogen production. This aligns with recent joint statements by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and US President Joe Biden, as well as the collaboration between Natural Resources Canada and the US Department of Energy.

The Canadian nuclear industry is encouraged by the government's commitment to increasing the role of nuclear power in the country's energy mix. While there is more work to be done to ensure equal treatment for all clean energy technologies, today's budget represents a significant step towards maintaining Canada's position as a global leader in advancing clean energy technology.

Overall, Budget 2023 reinforces the importance of nuclear power and specifies policies that foster cross-border cooperation, moving towards an integrated and mutually-beneficial North American nuclear ecosystem. END

completion:
Canada has been at the forefront of nuclear power for decades. Our nuclear plants have been powering Canadian grids since the 1960s, but our involvement in nuclear science and technology began even earlier. Canadian Nuclear Labs in Chalk River, Ontario, has been leading the way in designing, building, and experimenting with nuclear reactors since World War II. Through continuous use and refinement, we have developed a strong industry with highly skilled individuals.

At Canadian Nuclear Labs, our ongoing research focuses on how our nuclear science and technology can benefit people worldwide. We strive to save lives and improve the quality of life for all. 

When it comes to our current energy mix, more than three-quarters of Canada's electricity grid is generated by nuclear power and renewable sources like hydroelectricity. This combination is carbon emission-free and helps us build a clean, low-carbon future. Nuclear energy is clean, reliable, and affordable, making it an essential component of a sustainable energy landscape. Prominent scientists and environmentalists recognize nuclear power as one of the few reliable sources that can effectively reduce greenhouse gas emissions. 

In fact, the world's use of nuclear power already reduces carbon dioxide emissions by approximately 2.5 billion tonnes each year by avoiding fossil fuels. As nuclear power continues to work in partnership with other low-carbon sources, we can further decrease the amount of carbon dioxide released into the atmosphere. Nuclear power stations are the workhorses of our power grid, providing continuous and reliable electricity production. This steady supply allows for the expansion of other forms of power generation that may operate more intermittently.

Not only is nuclear power cost-competitive with other forms of electricity generation, but its fuel costs are low and stable. In the grand scheme of nuclear power, fuel costs make up a small proportion of the total expense. This affordability makes nuclear energy a valuable asset in enabling the growth of renewable energy sources.

Together, nuclear power, wind, and solar can help us create clean and carbon-free electricity grids. Since electricity on the grid must be used immediately after it is generated, this partnership ensures our power needs are met, even when the sun isn't shining or the wind isn't blowing. Canada's nuclear reactors provide baseload power, guaranteeing a steady supply of electricity to the grid. This stability creates room for renewables to respond to changing demand for electricity.

Exciting advancements in nuclear reactor designs are on the horizon. These improvements will enhance the capability for load following, meaning reactors will adapt to changing electricity demand throughout the day. This increased efficiency will further complement renewables, eliminating the need to burn fossil fuels to compensate for electricity supply and demand discrepancies. Such progress is critical in our fight against climate change.

Canada has always been a leader in nuclear science and technology, and we are well-positioned to continue this legacy in the development and deployment of small modular reactors (SMR). With over 60 years of innovation, a world-class regulator, and a robust domestic supply chain, our nuclear industry has the potential to capture a significant share of the emerging global market. Experts estimate that this market could be worth $150 billion per year by 2040.

By embracing nuclear power and advancing SMR technology, Canada can play a crucial role in shaping a greener, more sustainable future while also fueling economic growth. END

completion:
Climate change is one of the biggest challenges we face in the 21st century. However, there is a solution that is both reliable and affordable - nuclear power. It is the only energy source that can easily be expanded while also being low-carbon. By turning to nuclear power, we can effectively combat climate change.

To achieve our climate goals, we must stop releasing greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide into the atmosphere. There is a set limit, or carbon budget, for how much more carbon dioxide we can emit to have a 50% chance of keeping global warming under 1.5 °C. Currently, burning fossil fuels contributes about 37 gigatonnes of carbon dioxide emissions each year. To meet our climate goals, we must quickly increase our use of carbon-free energy sources, such as nuclear, solar, and wind power.

Countries around the world have committed to limiting their total carbon emissions under the Paris Agreement. However, some countries, like Germany and China, have struggled to meet these commitments. Even Canada is not on track to reduce its carbon emissions by 30% between 2005 and 2030. It is clear that we need to prioritize greener energy options to stay within the carbon budget.

There are three main strategies to achieve this. First, we need to reduce overall energy consumption, which has shown some success. Second, we should explore carbon capture technologies, like the one being used in Weyburn, Saskatchewan. However, these strategies alone are not enough to achieve a carbon-neutral future. We also need to transition away from fossil fuels and replace them with low- and zero-emission sources of energy generation.

Renewable energy sources like solar, wind, and tidal power have made significant progress in the past decade, leading to more affordable prices. However, they still make up only a small portion of Canada's total power generation. Hydroelectric power is a zero-emission option that Canada has already utilized extensively, but there are limits to damming suitable locations. Nuclear power, on the other hand, does not emit greenhouse gases during operation and has a smaller land footprint compared to other options. Canada has an abundant supply of uranium and numerous potential sites for nuclear power plants. Therefore, nuclear power has great potential in our fight against climate change.

When considering carbon emissions, it is essential to look at the entire life cycle of energy sources. This includes construction, the supply chain, operation, decommissioning, and disposal. When all these factors are taken into account, nuclear power compares favorably with renewable energy sources and far surpasses fossil fuels. According to the World Nuclear Association, the world's 445 reactors save 2.5 gigatonnes of carbon dioxide emissions annually. Future reactors will be even more efficient, further reducing emissions.

The province of Ontario in Canada provides a successful example of how nuclear power can significantly reduce carbon emissions. In the past, Ontario heavily relied on burning coal for electricity, causing substantial emissions. However, thanks to their 18 nuclear power reactors, the province was able to eliminate coal from their energy mix by 2014. This switch not only led to cleaner air but also a sharp decrease in carbon emissions, even with a 30% population growth since 1990.

By embracing nuclear power, we have the opportunity to make a significant impact on climate change. It is a reliable, low-carbon, and expandable energy source that can help us achieve our climate goals. Let's follow the examples of countries like France, Sweden, and Ontario, and transition to a greener and more sustainable energy future. END

completion:
The Canadian Trucking Alliance (CTA) commends the establishment of the Recognized Employer Pilot (REP) as a positive step towards addressing labor shortages and protecting workers in the trucking industry. This pilot aims to safeguard employees, including temporary foreign workers (TFWs), from workplace abuse. However, the CTA emphasizes the need for further action from the government to crack down on trucking sector employers who exploit the system known as driver inc, which deprives truck drivers of their rights under the labor code.

The three-year pilot, announced by Randy Boissonnault, the Minister of Employment, Workforce Development and Official Languages, will commence this September. The introduction of the REP is a positive move towards tackling labor shortages and reducing bureaucracy for recognized employers, a shift that the CTA has been advocating for in the TFW program. Nonetheless, the effectiveness of this pilot in protecting foreign workers in the trucking sector hinges on the criteria used to qualify as a recognized employer. It is imperative that a robust audit and oversight regime is in place to ensure the desired outcomes are achieved.

Stephen Laskowski, President of the CTA, emphasizes the urgent need to recruit more Canadians and foreign workers into the trucking industry, given the significant labor shortage. He believes that this announcement will help stabilize the distribution networks within various sectors of the Canadian economy. However, access to foreign labor in trucking should only be granted through a recognized employer program that strictly enforces labor compliance among participating companies. To certify the legitimacy and effectiveness of this program, the Canadian government must implement a thorough auditing system that ensures all firms are complying with the law and workers are protected from scams like driver inc.

Participation in the REP offers employers a streamlined application process, valid labor market impact assessments (LMIAs) for 36 months, and recognition on Canada's job bank to facilitate the recruitment of potential workers. Reports suggest that the agricultural sector will be eligible to participate in the pilot from September 2023, with other sectors joining in the new year. Although the CTA has yet to receive complete details on the qualification process for REP participation, Minister Boissonnault's news conference indicated that employers must have obtained at least three positive LMIA approvals for the same occupation within the past five years, supported by data from the Canadian Occupational Projection System (COPS).

The CTA has already submitted a plan to collaborate with the federal government in developing a recognized employer program for the trucking sector. This program would include labor compliance audits to ensure the protection of both foreign and domestic workers from scams like driver inc. The CTA sees this new pilot program as an excellent opportunity to implement these measures and safeguard the rights of workers in our sector. END

Alberta's Wray Ranch Receives Prestigious National Environmental Stewardship Award

August 17, 2023

Calgary, AB - We are thrilled to announce that Wray Ranch, located near Irricana, Alberta, has been awarded the Environmental Stewardship Award (TESA) for 2023 by the Canadian Cattle Association (CCA). Doug and Linda Wray, along with their nephew Tim Wray and his wife Joanne, are the proud owners and operators of Wray Ranch, and they have been recognized for their dedication to sustainable practices that promote soil health and reduce erosion.

In 1998, Wray Ranch underwent a transformative change when they converted 1,000 acres of cropland into high-legume perennial pasture, allowing for year-round grazing. Their commitment to sustainability is evident through their ongoing monitoring of soil organic matter and adjusting herd sizes or renting additional pastures to maintain the health of their land, especially during challenging weather conditions like droughts.

The Wray family's dedication to soil health goes beyond their own ranch. They actively share their knowledge and experience with the wider community through mentoring programs, speaking engagements, on-farm trials, and volunteering efforts. By prioritizing the well-being of the land over maximum profit, Wray Ranch serves as a remarkable example of sustainable and responsible farming practices.

The award was presented in person by Mike Duguid, Co-Chair of CCA's Environment Committee, and Kelleen Tait, National Leader of Livestock and Poultry with MNP, during the Canadian Beef Industry Conference (CBIC). Wray Ranch was chosen as the winner out of seven regional nominees from across Canada.

"The Wray family fully embodies what it means to be stewards of the land and sets a strong example for cattle producers across Canada. Their commitment to leaving the land in better condition for future generations is truly commendable," said Duguid. "Wray Ranch demonstrates that responsible farming practices can thrive and be essential in navigating challenging drought years. Congratulations to all the nominees for their outstanding dedication to environmental stewardship and for being an inspiration to sustainable farming practices nationwide."

We would like to express our gratitude to our Platinum Sponsor, MNP, and our Foundational Partners, Ducks Unlimited Canada, Birds Canada, and the Canadian Roundtable for Sustainable Beef (CRSB), for their support of this year's TESA program. We also want to acknowledge the contributions of our Judging Committee, Karli Reimer and Kristine Tapley from Ducks Unlimited Canada, Norine Ambrose from Cows & Fish, and Doug and Erika Fossen, the 2022 TESA recipients. completion:
The Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) is an exciting development for Canada's climate and energy security. Canada has all the necessary ingredients to become a global leader in low-carbon transportation fuels, including energy infrastructure, sustainable resources, and expertise. However, we currently lack a competitive investment environment compared to the United States, with whom we compete for investment.

For the past twenty years, the US has been successful in attracting investment in clean fuels through robust programs like tax credits. As a result, they have built a strong capacity for clean fuel production, while Canada has become increasingly reliant on imports. The Canadian Fuels Association (CFA) members are major producers of clean fuels today and have committed to producing even more in Canada since 2020.

However, the US IRA, introduced last summer, has raised concerns. This act includes generous production tax credits (PTC) for low-carbon road transportation fuels and sustainable aviation fuel, which significantly tips the scales in favor of clean fuel projects in the US. This will likely lead to more Canadian feedstocks being exported to the US, causing economic losses for Canada and jeopardizing our energy independence. Unfortunately, this comes at a time when CFA members are planning large-scale renewable projects in Canada to help achieve our climate goals by 2050.

One example of the impact of the IRA is Parkland's recent decision to discontinue plans for a renewable diesel facility in Burnaby, BC. Clearly, without investment parity, more projects are at risk of being delayed or relocated to the US. It is imperative for the Canadian government to respond swiftly, which is why we are urging the introduction of a clean fuel production tax credit in Budget 2023.

This tax credit would apply to all clean fuels produced in Canada, including ethanol, renewable diesel, sustainable aviation fuel, and hydrogen. It would provide the necessary certainty for investment, with the credit rate varying based on carbon intensity. This means that the higher the greenhouse gas reductions achieved, the greater the credit value.

Implementing this tax credit would not only bring economic benefits throughout the value chain, from feedstock providers to distribution, but it would also reduce our dependence on imports and create thousands of jobs for Canadians. The economic and climate advantages of clean fuel production in Canada cannot be ignored or risked.

In a recent speech, Environment and Climate Change Minister Stephen Guilbeault emphasized that the IRA has made the race for innovation in clean technology more competitive than ever before. Our transportation energy sector has been crucial to Canada's economic success for over a century. Now, we have an incredible opportunity to become a world leader in clean fuel production while fulfilling the evolving energy needs and climate goals of Canadians. Budget 2023 is a critical moment, and we must address the IRA to safeguard our economy, energy, and climate security. END

Canada Post is excited to announce the launch of its first-ever depot using battery-electric corporate delivery vehicles in Nanaimo, BC. This marks a significant step forward in our commitment to electrify our last mile fleet and contribute to a sustainable future for Canadians.

At the Nanaimo depot, we will be utilizing 14 fully electric cargo vans for collection and delivery services, replacing our old internal combustion vehicles. As part of our plan to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050, we have set a goal to electrify half of our national fleet of approximately 14,000 vehicles by 2030, with the entire fleet being electric by 2040.

We are proud to be investing over $1 billion to reduce emissions and accelerate the electrification of our last mile fleet. This investment has already shown significant progress towards our goal of achieving net-zero emissions by 2050. We understand that Canadians expect their postal service to take a leading role in transitioning to a low-carbon future, and we fully embrace that responsibility.

Throughout our long history, Canada Post has always adapted to meet the changing needs of Canadians and businesses. Our transformation plan includes investing billions of dollars into improving our service, capacity, and greening our operations. Whether we're delivering parcels or working towards a more sustainable future, our commitment to serving Canadians remains unwavering.

While this depot may be a small first step in our journey, it's an important one that helps build momentum towards our ultimate goal. We are dedicated to delivering sustainable solutions for our customers and playing our part in creating a stronger, greener Canada.

In addition to electrifying our fleet, Canada Post is committed to retrofitting our facilities, constructing net-zero carbon buildings, and sourcing renewable energy for our real estate and operations. Our cutting-edge parcel sorting facility, the Albert Jackson Processing Centre in Scarborough, Ontario, will operate as net-zero, with the capacity to process more than a million packages a day.

We have a long history of experimenting with electric and low-emission vehicles, and we are currently in the preliminary stage of our fleet electrification. We are introducing electric vehicles at select plants and depots to determine the best equipment, charging infrastructure, and approaches for our operational needs. Furthermore, we are also exploring other innovative and sustainable delivery options, including e-cargo trikes and compact electric cargo vehicles designed for neighborhood routes.

In the coming years, Canada Post will be actively seeking new vehicles in various classes to further enhance our sustainable delivery capabilities. We are committed to continuously improving and striving towards a greener and more efficient postal service for all Canadians. END

Investing in global health is a shared objective that has been actively pursued since 2015 when world leaders committed to providing health services for all people by 2030. However, we are currently only halfway towards meeting the target set by the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) of achieving universal health coverage by 2030. To reach this globally agreed goal, we need to put in more effort, both in implementing healthcare initiatives and investing in health.

Before the COVID-19 pandemic, the World Health Organization estimated that low- and middle-income countries needed to significantly increase their health spending to reach the health-related SDGs. An additional US$371 billion annually is required by 2030. This funding would not only allow populations to access health services but also contribute to building new facilities and training and placing health workers where they are needed.

In addition to these challenges, various factors such as conflicts, climate change, and economic instability have disrupted health services and increased the need for additional funding to achieve universal health coverage. Furthermore, preparing for future pandemics will require substantial investment, with an estimated US$31.1 billion annually, one-third of which is expected to come from international financing.

The pandemic response has already led to temporary increases in government spending, which contributed to a rise in global health spending of around $9 trillion in 2020, accounting for nearly 11% of the gross domestic product. However, it will be difficult for countries to find the necessary funds to meet the ambitious goal of universal health coverage, considering the strain on the world economy and national budgets. Development assistance will also likely be affected.

To address this enormous challenge, we need global solidarity and collective efforts. Recognizing this, the African Development Bank, the European Investment Bank (EIB), the Islamic Development Bank, and the World Health Organization (WHO) are launching a new investment platform. This platform aims to mobilize impactful and coherent investments in primary healthcare systems on a country level, improving resilience and overall health outcomes. We are also collaborating with other partners, such as the European Commission, to remove the risk from these investments and make them highly attractive for beneficiary countries. The Inter-American Development Bank is also considering joining this partnership to extend the initiative to Latin America and the Caribbean.

Why focus on primary health care? Because around 90% of essential health services can be delivered through quality primary health care. By bringing health professionals, doctors, and nurses closer to communities and local clinics, we can promote health, prevent diseases, and reduce the need for more costly secondary and tertiary services. Primary health care is crucial in reaching even the most rural and remote locations, serving as the foundation of a country's health system.

The COVID-19 pandemic and its economic repercussions have taught us the importance of investing in health services that can reach everyone, as it is central to national security, development, and prosperity. Solidarity and equity are vital components of any health service solution, and cooperation between multilateral organizations and development banks is key to addressing the challenges we face. By utilizing innovative finance mechanisms and promoting domestic funding, we aim to drive measurable impact and contribute to our shared goal of health for all without pushing countries into unsustainable debt.

We will officially launch this new investment platform in Paris during the Summit on a New Global Financing Pact on June 22-23, 2023. At this event, we will call for the generation of much-needed finances to combat health inequalities, support the climate transition, and accelerate progress towards the sustainable development goals. Good health and well-being are aspirations shared by the entire world, and to achieve them, countries and institutions must work together. By strengthening our collaboration and promoting cooperation between nations and governments, as well as the private sector, we can make universal health coverage a reality. We invite our partners to join us in this global investment platform. END

On August 18, 2023, we celebrate World Humanitarian Day by honoring the heroes who tirelessly respond to crises around the world. completion:
Introducing the "One Life, One Liver" campaign on World Hepatitis Day, a global effort is being made to raise awareness and take action against viral hepatitis. The World Health Organization (WHO) is urging for increased testing and treatment, warning that if current trends continue, hepatitis could become more deadly than malaria, tuberculosis, and HIV combined by 2040. 

Hepatitis is a disease that damages the liver and can lead to cancer, causing over a million deaths each year. Out of the five types of hepatitis, B and C are the most dangerous and responsible for most cases and fatalities. While hepatitis C can be cured, only a small percentage of those infected receive the necessary diagnosis and treatment. Similarly, a mere 10% of people with chronic hepatitis B are diagnosed and even fewer receive the lifesaving medicine. 

Under the theme of "One Life, One Liver," the WHO's World Hepatitis Day campaign emphasizes the importance of protecting our liver for a long and healthy life. Maintaining good liver health also benefits other vital organs like the heart, brain, and kidneys, which rely on the liver to function properly. It's disheartening to note that millions of people worldwide are living with undiagnosed and untreated hepatitis, despite having more effective tools than ever to prevent, diagnose, and treat it.

Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, the WHO Director-General, stresses the need for action, stating that the organization is dedicated to supporting countries in expanding the use of these tools, including cost-effective curative medications, to save lives and eradicate hepatitis. The WHO will also provide new guidance to track countries' progress towards eliminating hepatitis by 2030.

To reduce new infections and deaths from hepatitis B and C, countries must ensure access to treatment for pregnant women with hepatitis B, offer hepatitis B vaccines to newborns, diagnose 90% of people with hepatitis, and provide treatment to 80% of all diagnosed cases. It is also crucial to prioritize safe blood transfusions, injections, and harm reduction practices. Vaccination, testing, and treatment are all pivotal in safeguarding your liver from hepatitis.

Vaccinating children against hepatitis B is particularly important, as it helps limit the overall spread of viral hepatitis. In 2020, the goal of reducing hepatitis B incidence was the only health target of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) that was met on track for 2030. However, many African countries still lack access to the birth dose hepatitis B vaccine. Gavi's recent investment strategy, which includes this vaccine, will revitalize newborn vaccination programs in West and Central Africa, where mother-to-child transmission rates remain high.

WHO recommends testing pregnant women for hepatitis B during their pregnancy to prevent mother-to-child transmission. If positive, treatment should be provided, and vaccines should be given to newborns. However, a WHO report reveals that only half of the countries with a policy actually implement screening and management for hepatitis B in antenatal clinics. Similarly, while 80% of countries have policies for hepatitis B screening and management in HIV clinics, and 65% for hepatitis C, there is still progress to be made.

Increasing hepatitis testing and treatment within HIV programs is vital in protecting those living with HIV from developing liver cirrhosis and liver cancer. While there has been progress in hepatitis C treatment rates, it is slowing down. WHO advocates for seizing the opportunity of reduced medication prices to accelerate the expansion of treatment. The cost of a 12-week course to cure hepatitis C has dropped from over $90,000 to a mere $60 in low-income countries. Treating hepatitis B costs less than $30 per year or $2.4 per month.

For those who wish to maintain liver health, the WHO recommends hepatitis testing, treatment if diagnosed, and vaccination against hepatitis B. Additionally, reducing alcohol consumption, achieving a healthy weight, and effectively managing diabetes or hypertension also contribute to liver health. 

By taking action and working together, we can protect our livers and prevent the devastating consequences of viral hepatitis. Let's join forces and make a positive impact on global health. END

completion:
Sco celebrates ownership of landmark hbc building as a step towards reconciliation

March 30, 2023 - Anishinaabe and Dakota Territory, MB - The iconic HBC building in downtown Winnipeg has officially been transferred to the Southern Chiefs’ Organization (SCO). On behalf of 34 Anishnaabe and Dakota nations in southern Manitoba, SCO is excited to share new details and images of the building's transformation. This historic structure, located at the corner of Portage Avenue and Memorial Boulevard in Treaty One Territory, holds great significance.

"The formal transfer of the HBC building to SCO on the Wehwehneh Bahgahkinahgohn project is a monumental moment for southern First Nations," stated SCO Grand Chief Jerry Daniels. "While there is much work ahead, this building will soon become a home for hundreds of families, providing childcare, a health and healing center, an incredible museum, restaurants, and a space to honor survivors. This journey is a vital step towards reconciliation."

In spring 2022, SCO welcomed HBC Governor Richard Baker and Prime Minister Trudeau to our territory. Together with Southern Chiefs, the Premier, the Mayor, and community leaders, they announced plans to transform the HBC heritage building into a space that promotes economic and social reconciliation. Since then, SCO and HBC have worked closely to ensure a smooth transfer.

The Wehwehneh Bahgahkinahgohn project, meaning 'it is visible,' will revitalize the HBC building while preserving its rich heritage and contributing to the revitalization of downtown Winnipeg.

"HBC is incredibly proud to reach this milestone, officially transferring ownership of the building to SCO," said Richard Baker, Governor of HBC. "We remain committed partners to SCO as they work towards their incredible vision for this new space. We hope this inspires others to take meaningful action towards reconciliation in their own ways."

SCO has issued a request for qualifications to begin the redevelopment process, ensuring the project receives the best value through a competitive process. This redevelopment is the largest in Manitoba's history and one of the largest in Canada. The aim is to reopen the building in November 2026, coinciding with its 100th anniversary.

Nearly a century ago, the construction of the HBC building required immense effort, involving 300 men, 120 teams of horses, 20 trucks, and two steam shovels to lay the foundation. When it opened in 1926, the structure, designed by Canadian architect Ernest Isbell Barrott, was the largest reinforced concrete building in Canada, boasting over six hectares of floor space.

The Wehwehneh Bahgahkinahgohn project includes more than 300 affordable housing units for families and post-secondary students, as well as culturally safe assisted living units for First Nation elders. Families and employees in the building will have access to high-quality, licensed childcare and a rooftop garden. The project prioritizes the improvement of First Nation peoples' health and wellness through a health and healing center that integrates Western and traditional practices.

Moreover, the historic building will serve as the future governance house for the chiefs of the Southern First Nations, representing 34 Anishinaabe and Dakota nations in Manitoba. The main floor will be dedicated public space, welcoming Manitobans, Canadians, and tourists from around the world to explore a world-class museum showcasing the history of the Anishinaabe and Dakota peoples. Some artifacts reclaimed from Vatican vaults will be on display. Additionally, there will be ample space for ceremonies and commemorations, including a memorial honoring the survivors of residential and day schools and the children who never returned home. END

Update on Global Poverty in March 2023 from the World Bank

We are excited to share the latest update on global poverty estimates, which were released today on the Poverty and Inequality Platform (PIP). This update includes new regional poverty data for Latin America and the Caribbean, Europe and Central Asia, and the group of advanced countries for the years 2020 and 2021. We now have sufficient survey data available during the COVID-19 pandemic for these regions.

In total, we have added 113 new country-years of data, bringing the total number of surveys to over 2,100. As part of this update, we have made the usual changes to the input data. This includes revisions to existing welfare distributions, the inclusion of new welfare distributions, and updates to price, national accounts, and population data used for global poverty monitoring.

Overall, these changes have resulted in minor revisions to the global and regional poverty estimates. Table 1 provides a summary of the revisions between the September 2022 and March 2023 data for the reference year 2019, considering all three poverty lines.

At the $2.15 poverty line, the global poverty headcount ratio has increased slightly by 0.1 percentage points to 8.5%, which means there are now 659 million people living in poverty, 11 million more than previously estimated. This increase is mainly driven by South Asia and the Middle East and North Africa.

Similar limited changes in poverty estimates are observed at the higher poverty lines of $3.65 and $6.85, which are typically used for measuring poverty in lower-middle and upper-middle-income countries. At the $3.65 line, the global poverty headcount ratio has increased by 0.1 percentage points to 23.6%, representing 28 million more people living in poverty. At the $6.85 line, the global poverty rate has increased by 0.2 percentage points to 46.9%, with 44 million more people now living in poverty. These upward revisions are largely driven by South Asia and Sub-Saharan Africa.

This update from the World Bank revises global and regional poverty estimates from 1981 to 2019. Regional poverty estimates are now reported up to 2021, depending on the availability of sufficient data during the COVID-19 pandemic. For Europe and Central Asia, poverty data are reported until 2020, and for Latin America and the Caribbean, data are reported until 2021. Poverty data for all other developing regions are reported for pre-pandemic years.

It's important to note that while this update incorporates more recent data, it does not change the overall understanding of global poverty trends and the distribution of poverty across regions. Global poverty has been decreasing since the 1990s, albeit at a slower rate since 2014. Extreme poverty has been decreasing in all regions except the Middle East and North Africa, where conflict and fragility have posed challenges.

In 2019, approximately 60% of the world's extreme poor lived in Sub-Saharan Africa alone, while 81% of the global poor at the $3.65 poverty line lived in Sub-Saharan Africa or South Asia.

For more details on the regions covered in the post-2019 estimates, please refer to Figure 1. You can find additional information about our methodology and data sources on our website.

We are committed to monitoring and addressing global poverty, and this update helps us better understand the current situation and work towards a more equal and prosperous world. END

Empowering Youth for Sustainable Development: The Role of Media and Information Literacy in Promoting Green Skills

On August 15, 2023, we come together to celebrate International Youth Day, a global event that honors the incredible contributions of young individuals and acknowledges their immense potential to create a more sustainable and inclusive world. With the urgent challenges of environmental degradation before us, there has never been a greater need to equip young people with the tools they need to promote sustainable development.

One key way to achieve this is through media and information literacy (MIL), which empowers youth with the knowledge and critical thinking skills necessary to navigate the complex landscape of environmental issues and develop green skills that will contribute to a more sustainable future. As we mark International Youth Day, it is crucial to recognize the vital role of MIL in nurturing green skills among young individuals.

By providing youth with the ability to critically engage with media content and make informed decisions, MIL empowers them to become leaders in sustainable development. Not only does MIL enhance their understanding of environmental issues, but it also enables them to drive change, promote eco-friendly practices, and contribute to a greener and more sustainable future for generations to come.

Green skills encompass a wide range of competencies and knowledge that are geared towards environmental sustainability. These skills enable individuals to contribute to eco-friendly practices, develop innovative solutions for environmental challenges, and actively participate in the transition to a greener and more sustainable economy. Areas such as renewable energy, waste reduction, conservation, and sustainable agriculture are all covered by green skills.

MIL serves as a catalyst for the development and promotion of green skills among youth. In a world where information, misinformation, and rapidly evolving technologies abound, MIL equips young individuals with the ability to critically assess and analyze media content, discern credible sources, and make informed decisions. MIL empowers them to sift through the noise, identify reliable information, and gain a deep understanding of environmental issues and solutions.

Through various media channels, including websites, documentaries, podcasts, and social media, young people can learn about successful green initiatives, cutting-edge technologies, and inspiring stories of environmental stewardship. By developing media and information literacy skills, youth can amplify their impact by sharing accurate and impactful information with their peers, communities, and the wider world.

Media and information literacy also encourages critical thinking and problem-solving skills, which are essential for tackling complex environmental challenges. With MIL skills, young people can analyze data, evaluate policy proposals, and think creatively about sustainable solutions. By critically engaging with information, they can contribute to informed discussions and decision-making processes related to environmental issues, advocating for policies that prioritize sustainability.

MIL empowers young individuals to become agents of change by fostering innovation and entrepreneurship. Armed with accurate information and critical thinking abilities, youth can identify gaps in the market for sustainable products and services. They can develop and launch green start-ups, creating solutions that address environmental challenges while generating economic opportunities. MIL enables them to navigate the business landscape, connect with mentors, and access resources that support their entrepreneurial endeavors.

UNESCO, the leading organization promoting media and information literacy, is a strong supporter and champion of MIL initiatives worldwide. By empowering people to think critically about information and the use of digital tools, MIL helps individuals make informed choices about how they participate in peacebuilding, equality, freedom of expression, dialogue, access to information, and sustainable development. Through its support, UNESCO is dedicated to fostering media and information literacy initiatives across the globe, empowering young people to become the driving force behind a more sustainable and inclusive future.
